subject: A new look for ConnectCarolina login landing page
author: hashk
content:
Starting on April 11, you will see a new layout when you type connectcarolina.unc.edu into your browser. You’ll see the same links you’re used to seeing plus a few extra. The new page will be easier to use for those new to ConnectCarolina and for students’ family members who only occasionally log in to ConnectCarolina. 

What is the connectcarolina.unc.edu website?

This is the page that we typically refer to as the “landing page” for ConnectCarolina and it’s distinguished by the two green buttons to access ConnectCarolina as well as an announcements section and other useful links. It’s the first page that you see before logging into ConnectCarolina.   



The Changes

We‘ve simplified the page layout and made it is easier to navigate. The links work the same as they do now. Only the look is different.
Looking for the InfoPorte link? It’s in ConnectCarolina under Enterprise Reporting on the left.
For Students

The first column on the updated webpage is for students and their proxy users. Like today, students will click the big green button to get to the ConnectCarolina Student Center, and once in ConnectCarolina, everything will work the same as it does now. 

Parents or others can pay bills or see student info by clicking the blue buttons in the lower left.  (As always, students first need to give them access.)

Click the first link under the green button, Useful Links for Students to go to a friendlier version of the page students currently use.

For Faculty, Staff, and Affiliates

Important links for Faculty, Staff and Affiliates are in the middle column.  We’ve added a few extra links to online and classroom training, online documentation and the ConnectCarolina User Info website.

The third column includes Useful Links, Security Information and the Announcements section. 

Questions?

Send an email to cc_communications@unc.edu if you have questions or concerns. There is no associated outage and it will not impact registration or other work in ConnectCarolina.

subject: WOW 2018: Submit an event proposal
author: ebhooks
content:
It’s hard to believe this semester is almost over and soon we will welcome the newest Tar Heels to campus during Week of Welcome (WOW). WOW is a great opportunity for student organizations to welcome new first-year and transfer students to Carolina this fall.

During the Week of Welcome, Friday, August 17 – Sunday, August 26, 2018, your student organization has the opportunity to introduce new students to the Carolina community. Events can range from informational talks to social events. Through this opportunity, your organization can help new first-year and transfer students find their interests, meet new friends, and transition into Carolina. The WOW schedule is advertised through a Tar Heel Beginnings planner that all new students receive, on Guidebook, social media, and the New Student & Family Programs website.

Recognized student organizations are invited to submit WOW event proposals by Tuesday, April 17th at 11:59pm. In order to submit a WOW event proposal, you will need the date, time, location, event title, and brief description of your event. The event proposal form should take no longer than 5 minutes to complete. We do require organizations to have a confirmed/reserved location for your event prior to placing your event in the WOW schedule.

If you would like to submit more than two events, please email thb@unc.edu for an Excel template.

Thank you for helping support our newest Tar Heels. Your organization is part of what makes Carolina a home for students. For additional information or questions, please contact New Student & Family Programs at thb@unc.edu.

Sincerely,

New Student & Family Programs

subject: WOW 2018: Reminder to submit an event proposal
author: ebhooks
content:
This email is to serve as a reminder of the upcoming deadline to submit Week of Welcome and Tar Heel Beginnings events. New Student & Family Programs (NSFP) invites university departments, schools, and offices to submit event proposals designed to welcome and engage our newest students.

Week of Welcome: August 17 – 26, 2018

During Week of Welcome (WOW), new first-year and transfer students have the opportunity to attend a diverse array of academic and community-building programs to help them through their transition to the Carolina community.
University departments, schools, and offices are invited to submit WOW events by Tuesday, April 17th at 11:59pm.
Tar Heel Beginnings: August 27 – December 2018

Continuing with the momentum from Week of Welcome, Tar Heel Beginnings (THB) events are intentionally designed fall programs seeking to introduce new first-year and transfer students to the expectations, resources, and involvement opportunities during their first semester at UNC-Chapel Hill.
University departments, schools, and offices are invited to submit Tar Heel Beginnings events by Tuesday, April 17th at 11:59pm.
Please note that all departments, schools, and offices hosting WOW and THB events are responsible for completing all event facility reservations and related facility costs.

Event proposals for both WOW and THB must be submitted through the following online forms:

Week of Welcome Event Proposal

Tar Heel Beginnings Event Proposal

If you would like to submit more than two events, please email thb@unc.edu for an Excel template.

Thank you for helping support our newest Tar Heels. For additional information or questions, please contact New Student & Family Programs at thb@unc.edu or 919-962-8304.

Sincerely,

New Student & Family Programs

subject: The Monti @ PlayMakers -$10 UNC Students
author: rosalie
content:
The Monti and PlayMakers Repertory Company are teaming up on April 9 to present a show filled with ordinary people telling extraordinary stories. The narratives told are all completely true and centered on the theme of Home. This theme is inspired by PlayMakers’ latest production—Leaving Eden by Mike Wiley & Laurelyn Dossett—and will take place on the set of Leaving Eden during the production’s night off.

There are four requirements that all stories must follow:

All stories are true.
All stories are told without the use of notes.
All stories adhere to the twelve-minute time limit.
All stories must revolve around the theme Home.
Enjoy food from Chirba Chirba Dumplings or American Meltdown food trucks and refreshments from our bar.

UNC Students are just $10!

ABOUT THE MONTI
On April 22, 2008, The Monti debuted in the back room of a small Chapel Hill restaurant. The stories were raw, hilarious, poignant, tragic, and 100 percent real. Since then, the community-building organization has grown into an award-winning event whose stories are downloaded and viewed all over the world.

CLICK HERE TO LEARN MORE

subject: Pilot RFA “Promoting Health Equity by Including Underrepresented Participants in Research.”
author: maclay
content: The NC TraCS Institute is seeking submissions for its special pilot RFA “Promoting Health Equity by Including Underrepresented Participants in Research.” The purpose of this special RFA, sponsored by TraCS’ Integrating Special Populations Program and the Center for Health Equity Research, is to facilitate research that promotes health equity for groups who have traditionally been under-represented in health research or excluded altogether (e.g., people who live in rural areas, populations with low socioeconomic status, people with disabilities, adolescents, older adults, the LGBTQ community, African Americans, Native Americans, and Latinos). The pilot program is open to all UNC-Chapel Hill investigators and investigators at NC TraCS partner institutions: RTI, North Carolina A&T State University, and NC State University. Please see the RFA for additional information, or contact Abigail Haydon, Integrating Special Populations program manager at NC TraCS, at ahaydon@med.unc.edu.

subject: 2018 Exitos Graduation Ceremony
author: adrigibi
content:
Dear Carolina Community,

On behalf of the Carolina Latinx Collaborative and the University Office for Diversity & Inclusion, we invite you, as well as all graduating students (undergraduate and graduate/professional, including December 2017 graduates), faculty, and staff of your department to join us at the 5th annual Éxitos Latinx Graduation Ceremony on Friday, May 11, from 5:30-7:30 p.m. at the FedEx Global Education Center. This bilingual event serves to celebrate the work and dedication that students have devoted to the Latinx community. Students do not have to identify as Latinx to participate.

Professor Nilda Peragallo Montana, Dean of the UNC-Chapel Hill School of Nursing, will deliver the keynote. Following our tradition, all participating students will receive a unique Éxitos Latinx stole as a small token of appreciation for their commitment.

Families and friends will have the opportunity to connect with the people who have guided the graduating students on their Carolina journey, take pictures with Rameses, and enjoy Latinx-inspired cuisine. We will also livestream the event on Facebook.

RSVP required. Please register here.

subject: Powerful Skills to Help Your Teen to Handle Stress One Moment at a Time
author: kmeason
content:
Making Friends with Yourself: A Mindful Self-Compassion Program for High School Teens (14-18 year old)
Sponsored by the Program on Integrative Medicine

Information Session: Thursday, April 19, 2018 from 6-7 PM

The purpose of the information session is to answer any questions folks have about the class, and to dispel any apprehension teens have about taking the class. It is NOT required, and open to anyone who is interested in taking it, and their parents. (No obligation to take the class if they come to the informational session).

UNC now offers a mindful self-compassion class for adolescents, ages 14-18. Mindful Self-Compassion brings together the benefits of mindfulness and self-compassion:  Mindfulness teaches us to be present with difficult emotions, and self-compassion helps us to respond to these emotions with greater kindness and self-care.

Through developmentally appropriate activities and meditations, teens learn specific tools, which help them, navigate the emotional difficulties of this life stage with greater ease.  A preliminary research study on this program has demonstrated significant decreases in depression, anxiety, perceived stress and negative mood from before to after taking this course.

Space is limited!

Sessions are 1 ½ hours, held once a week for six weeks focused on experiential practice and self-reflection

Class Dates: Thursdays, April 26 through June 14, 2018

Instructors: Kate Murphy and Laura Prochnow Phillips

Time: 5:00-6:45PM

Location: UNC Center for Rehabilitation Care, 1807 Fordham Blvd., Chapel Hill NC 27514

FREE NEARBY PARKING AVAILABLE

If interested in registering your teen, please click here. 

The Promise of Self-Compassion for Stressed-Out Teens– New York Times 02-20-18, Karen Bluth discusses how “Making Friends With Yourself: A Mindful Self-Compassion for Teens and Young Adults,” how the program lowered stress in middle and high school participants.

For more information, please call 919-966-8586 or email mindfulness@med.unc.edu

Please visit our website for additional course information like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter!

subject: CTSA Conversations: What is the NEW Research Coordination and Management Unit (RCMU) and how can it support your research?
author: maclay
content:
NC TraCS newly developed Research Coordination and Management Unit (RCMU) is now ready and available to help you meet your research goals! 

What is the NEW Research Coordination and Management Unit (RCMU) and how can it support your research?

As part of the NC TraCS Institute, the RCMU provides professional, experienced study coordinators and project managers equipped to perform a wide range of study coordination services to investigators across UNC and the UNC HealthCare System. The mission of the RCMU is to support investigators in conducting rigorous, high-quality clinical and translational research while ensuring regulatory compliance, procedural efficiency, and data collection best practices.

Visit our website: rcmu.unc.edu or contact us at rcmu@unc.edu.

To learn more about this new service, check out the TraCS CTSA Conversations Series, https://tracs.unc.edu/index.php/calendar/2612 

An ongoing goal at the UNC TraCS Institute is to consistently and regularly create and act upon ideas of how to best align our collective resources with the needs of your research. The CTSA Conversations Series is one way in which we can learn about what is important and of interest to researchers.



NC TraCS 

https://tracs.unc.edu/

subject: UNC Girls Health Study-Seeking Female Adolescent Participants (ages 8-11)
author: rac12
content:
Parents and Mental Healthcare Providers:

Purpose: Researchers are currently seeking female participants (ages 8-11) for an important study on relationships, stress, and health in adolescent girls called the UNC Girls Health Study.

 

Eligibility: We are seeking girls (ages 8-11) who have had stressful life experiences, depressed mood and/or depressive symptoms, and/or self-injury, including cutting.

 

Study Length: Participation will include a one-time, 6 hour visit to our lab in Chapel Hill with a parent. Adolescents will complete several activities, including an interview, questionnaires, computer games, watch a movie, and do a role play task. We can schedule visits to our near-campus location on Finley Golf Course Road any day of the week. Parents earn $75 for the 6 hour study. Participants earn $335 for all aspects of the project, including $175 for the visit.

 

Contact: For more information, please contact our Recruitment Coordinator, Andrea Wiglesworth, at 919-966-7405 or by email at GirlsHealthStudy@unc.edu

 

This research study (IRB#13-3714) was approved by the UNC-CH Behavioral

IRB (non-biomedical) on October 16th, 2017.

subject: Professional Development Grant Applications Now Open
author: mbanks
content:
Professional Development Grant Applications Now Open

The Employee Forum’s Professional Development Grant application process is now open.

The grant provides permanent University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill employees additional funding to help cover professional development opportunities. 

Grants cover up to $500 of allowed expenses.  Funding must be for individual benefit, relate to the employee’s position, and meet a professional development purpose (not departmental).

The grant covers work-related education and training and can be used for conferences, certificates, non-credit classes, or similar instructional opportunities. In other words, it covers anything related to or contributing to the professional skills of the individual employee and not already covered by other resources at the University. Specifically, the grant is designed for expenses incurred prior to the opportunity (e.g., registration, materials, travel) that an employee’s department or cannot cover. Courses for academic credit are not eligible for this grant. Please see the University's tuition waiver page.

Full or part-time permanent SHRA or EHRA non-faculty employees are eligible for this grant. We encourage applicants to seek funding from departmental/unit sources, if available, prior to submitting this application. There are a number of sources of university forms and sources of support; please exhaust these other options before applying for the Professional Development Grant.

Grants are open this round until June 30, 2018.

Please apply!

Application criteria and other relevant information are available here.

subject: Registration Process Change for Carolina Courses Online (CCO)
author: brinkerj
content:
Remember, the registration process has changed for students enrolling in Carolina Courses Online (CCO) for the Summer 2018 or Fall 2018 semesters. Currently enrolled students will register for CCO inside ConnectCarolina during their regular enrollment appointments. It is no longer necessary to contact the Friday Center for Continuing Education directly for CCO enrollment requests.

CCO courses are the same courses offered on campus, just in an online format. Full-time undergraduates may register for two CCO courses in the summer and one CCO course in the fall semester; part-time students may register for two CCO courses in any term.

To find Carolina Courses Online when registering, log into ConnectCarolina and click on the green "search for classes" button. Next, choose the appropriate term, then click on the magnifying glass to search by class attribute and look for "Carolina Courses Online," as in this screen shot:






If you have any questions during the enrollment process, we're here to help. Call 919-962-1134 or email CCO@unc.edu.



Jessica Brinker
Director, Office of Credit Programs
William & Ida Friday Center for Continuing Education

subject: DO YOU HAVE PROBLEMS WITH LOW MOTIVATION? DO YOU FIND IT HARD TO ENJOY THINGS IN YOUR EVERYDAY LIFE?
author: memclamb
content:
DO YOU HAVE PROBLEMS WITH LOW MOTIVATION?

DO YOU FIND IT HARD TO ENJOY THINGS IN YOUR EVERYDAY LIFE?

The Department of Psychiatry at both Duke and UNC-CH are working together on a research study to help develop new interventions for people who are experiencing low levels of motivation and pleasure.

 

We are looking for people between the ages of 18-50 who are not currently taking any psychiatric medications and/or not currently in psychotherapy and are experiencing symptoms of low motivation and pleasure. Symptoms of low motivation and pleasure can include not wanting to be with other people, not wanting to participate in activities that you previously enjoyed, and feeling numb to the joys of life. Volunteers must be willing to provide informed consent to complete an initial clinical interview, questionnaires regarding mood, anxiety, quality of life, brain scans before and after treatment, and the possibility of two additional brain scans during treatment.

There is no cost to participate.
You will receive up to 15 psychotherapy sessions from a Duke clinician.
You will receive compensation for the portions of the study you complete.
To see if you qualify, complete this online survey: https://redcap.unc.edu/surveys/?s=NN99MR9EA8UNC-CH Biomedical IRB approved on 3/9/18 IRB Number: 16-2268

subject: Sexual Assault Awareness Month
author: sgist
content:
Throughout the month of April, student organizations and University departments will be hosting events in recognition of Sexual Assault Awareness Month (SAAM). This month provides us with an opportunity to raise awareness of the many resources available on campus and in the community, discuss the impact of sexual violence, and identify ways that we can help prevent it.

A full schedule of trainings, programs, and events has been planned for the month. Visit safe.unc.edu for more information on these events and for details about resources on campus for those who have experienced sexual violence.

Participating organizations and departments include the Carolina Women’s Center, Equal Opportunity and Compliance Office, Student Wellness, Delta Advocates, One Act, Project Dinah, UNC Gender-Based Violence Research Group, Carolina Advocates for Gender Equality, Feminist Students United, Omega Phi Beta, Student Government, and the Orange County Rape Crisis Center.

This message is sponsored by: Carolina Women’s Center and the Equal Opportunity and Compliance Office

subject: April 2- 6: Celebrating Carolina's Graduate and Professional Students
author: flewis
content:
Dear Members of the Graduate Community –

Today marks the beginning of National Graduate and Professional Student Appreciation Week. I am so pleased to share that The Graduate School and the Graduate and Professional Student Federation (GPSF) are partnering to recognize the many contributions graduate and professional students make to research, teaching, and service at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. While one week cannot sufficiently express how much our graduate students mean to Carolina, I hope you will all join me in celebrating their impact.

The week’s events include a research/policy conference with a coffee and donut welcome on Monday, a screening of “The PhD Movie” on Tuesday, the annual graduate student recognition celebration on Thursday and much, much more. For all campus event details, click here.

Throughout this week, I would encourage you to do the following:

Wear your button(s) with pride – “Carolina Graduate Student” and “Carolina Loves Graduate Students” buttons will be distributed at this week’s events. You may also stop by our office in Bynum Hall!
Promote the hashtag #CarolinaLovesGraduateStudents on social media with a photo featuring Carolina graduate students (with fellow students, faculty advisers, lab groups, etc.)
Attend our events throughout the week as your schedule allows – and look out for school-specific events happening as well
Promote this week of appreciation with faculty, staff, and students throughout the University
Thank you very much for all that you do here at Carolina.

Best regards,

Steve


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Steven W. Matson, Ph.D. ? Dean
The Graduate School ? The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
214 Bynum Hall, CB# 4010, Chapel Hill, NC 27599-4010
(919) 962-6311 ? smatson@bio.unc.edu
Visit us: gradschool.unc.edu

Throughout this week, I would encourage you to do the following:

Wear your button(s) with pride – “Carolina Graduate Student” and “Carolina Loves Graduate Students” buttons will be distributed at this week’s events. You may also stop by our office in Bynum Hall!
Promote the hashtag #CarolinaLovesGraduateStudents on social media with a photo featuring Carolina graduate students (with fellow students, faculty advisers, lab groups, etc.)
Attend our events throughout the week as your schedule allows – and look out for school-specific events happening as well
Promote this week of appreciation with faculty, staff, and students throughout the University
Thank you very much for all that you do here at Carolina.

Best regards,

Steve

content:

On March 30, 2018, at 6:04 a.m., faculty elections ballots were sent from facgov@qualtrics.unc.edu to 3,800 faculty. These messages passed through the University’s phishing filter, but were still flagged by Microsoft as a possible phishing attempt. The email carrying the subject line “2018 Faculty Elections Ballot” is not a phishing email. Please click the link to "Take the Survey" as you normally would. subject: Director Named for UNC Institute for the Environment
author: briordan
content:
Date:       April 2, 2018 

To:           Deans, Directors, and Department Chairs

From:      Terry Magnuson, Vice Chancellor for Research

Re:          Director Named for UNC Institute for the Environment

Dear Colleagues,

I am very pleased to announce that Michael Piehler, MSPH, PhD, has been named director of the UNC Institute for the Environment (IE) and will begin serving in that role on July 1, 2018.

Mike currently serves as Interim Executive Director of the UNC Coastal Studies Institute.  He is a professor at the UNC Institute of Marine Sciences, holding joint appointments in the College of Arts & Sciences’ Department of Marine Sciences and the Gillings School of Global Public Health’s Department of Environmental Science & Engineering (ESE).  He also serves as Director of Graduate Studies & Admissions for the UNC Curriculum for the Environment & Ecology.

With the appointment of Mike Piehler, the Institute for the Environment is poised to play an enhanced role as UNC’s pan-campus institute for environmental research, outreach and impact, and it will serve as an active, engaged catalyst for environmental activities.  Mike’s appointment represents a key step in the University’s campus-wide goal of enhancing and integrating environmental research and studies. 

As you may know, Carolina has been engaged in a multi-year pan-campus planning process to re-imagine the role of environmental studies, research and programs at UNC – a process that led to Dean Kevin Guskiewicz’ announcement in January that the College will launch a new Environment, Ecology, and Energy Program (E3P), enhancing and elevating its Curriculum for the Environment & Ecology. 

Under Mike’s leadership, IE will conduct and facilitate interdisciplinary environmental research, focus the University’s resources on significant environmental topics, and serve as a front door for environmental research, outreach, and engagement at UNC.  Mike will work in close partnership with environmental programs and centers across campus, such as the College’s new E3P program, the School of Public Health’s ESE Department, and the School of Medicine’s Toxicology Department and Center for Environmental Medicine, Asthma & Lung Biology, with the goal of integrating faculty, students, and staff in research, education, and engagement on pressing environmental issues that face communities in North Carolina and throughout the world.

Mike received his Ph.D. in Environmental Science and Engineering from Carolina, and, since 1998, has served as a faculty member at UNC’s Institute of Marine Science.  His research concentrates on the ecology and biogeochemistry of land-water interfaces and is focused on understanding the connection between human activity and the function of natural systems.  His work is funded by a diverse portfolio of federal, state, and regional sponsors, and he serves on a variety of scientific advisory panels for governments, non-government organizations, and industry. 

Mike will assume the directorship from David Peden, MD, MS, who has served as IE’s interim director since July 1, 2017 and led a successful transition period following the departure of the Institute’s previous director, Larry Band.  Dave serves as director of UNC’s Center for Environmental Medicine, Asthma & Lung Biology; Senior Associate Dean for Translational Research in the School of Medicine; and the Harry S. Andrews Distinguished Professor of Pediatrics in the School of Medicine, and has held a variety of other senior administrative positions at Carolina.  

The Institute for the Environment is charged with supporting the University’s multi-disciplinary community of environmental researchers, enhancing collaboration, sharing knowledge, and developing solutions to critical environmental problems facing North Carolina and the world.  It works with partners across the University and externally to coordinate and deliver 21st century programs that provide students with experience and skills they can use to thrive in a growing global economy.  It takes environmental discoveries and knowledge and puts them into practice by engaging and serving communities here in North Carolina and around the globe.

Please join me in welcoming Mike Piehler to his new role at the Institute for the Environment and thanking Dave Peden for his capable stewardship as IE’s interim director.

subject: Learning and Development Award for Supervisors
author: kirkkm
content:
The Office of Human Resources invites you to nominate a supervisor or manager for the Outstanding Encouragement of Learning and Development (OELD) award.

The OELD award was created in 2004 by the Chancellor's Task Force for a Better Workplace to promote a more engaged, productive, and effective workforce. The award recognizes supervisors who actively support their employees’ professional development.

Nominations for the OELD award are open to SHRA and EHRA supervisors who have held at least one year of continuous University service. All employees are encouraged to complete the online nomination form for their deserving supervisors.

The award is presented annually to one supervisor and includes 24 hours of paid time off and a plaque. Managers and supervisors who were nominated in previous years are eligible to be nominated again.

The Office of Human Resources is now accepting nominations for the 2018 OELD award through April 11. For more information, or to nominate someone, please visit hr.unc.edu/oeld.

For more information, contact William Frey in OHR at 919-962-9685 or will_frey@unc.edu.

subject: Continuing Education Programs and Registrations Report, 2016-2017
author: rrblanch
content:
On behalf of Jessica Brinker, Interim Director, William & Ida Friday Center for Continuing Education:

 

I am pleased to share this year’s continuing education report which shows programs supporting Carolina’s mission of public service and instruction. In the 2016-2017 reporting year, UNC-Chapel Hill departments and outreach units engaged a record 448,736 individuals in North Carolina and around the world in continuing education activities. The 2016–17 Continuing Education Programs and Registrations report can be seen at:

 

https://fridaycenter.unc.edu/files/2018/03/2016-2017-Continuing-Education-Programs-and-Registrations-Final-Report.pdf

 

For the one-year period ending June 30, 2017, 28 units of the University reported information on 3,753 noncredit continuing education courses of various kinds, in which 448,736 individuals enrolled. The previous year’s figures were 3,496 courses and 395,500 registrants.

 

In 2016-17, courses were offered in 59 counties in North Carolina, 26 states other than our own (including the District of Columbia), and 51 foreign countries.

 

Courses were conducted in a variety of formats. Online course offerings continued to be in demand. These courses comprised 51 percent of the registrant total, followed by classroom courses at 24 percent of the registrant total.

 

The breadth of continuing education programming and the diverse clientele it serves are illustrated by the programming highlights shown in the last part of the report, which some units chose to provide along with their data.

 

It is clear from this report that we are helping individuals at the local, state, and international level achieve personal and professional educational goals through the continuing education opportunities offered by the University. Through the annual compilation of this report, the Friday Center is proud to play a role in supporting the University’s commitment to lifelong learning and outreach.

 

If you have any questions please don’t hesitate to contact me at Jessica_Brinker@unc.edu.

 

Jessica Brinker

Interim Director, William & Ida Friday Center for Continuing Education

Director of Credit Programs

University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

100 Friday Center Drive, Campus Box 1020

Chapel Hill, NC 27599

T: 919-962-2646

subject: INFORMATIONAL Research Study Recruitment
author: bshackne
content:
Do you currently have knee osteoarthritis? Are you between the ages of 40 and 75 years old?

We are inviting people with knee osteoarthritis who are 40-75 years old to join our research study.

We are testing whether a short, intense exercise program (called high intensity interval training) helps people with knee osteoarthritis.

 

The study involves:

Three in-person visits to collect information about your health and your arthritis symptoms. These visits occur before, at the mid point and after the exercise training program.
Participation in 12-weeks of one-on-one exercise training on UNC main campus.
Each exercise training session lasts 30 minutes.
Study participants must complete two sessions each week for a total of 12 weeks.
The exercise program is tailored to you based on your current fitness level and is guided by our well-trained exercise staff.

Participants will receive up to $114 for completing the research study.

If you are interested in more information, please contact Malia Blue at:  mnm3303@email.unc.edu  or (919) 962-1663.

This study (IRB # 16-2996) was approved by the UNC Biomedical IRB on 5/9/2017

This message is sponsored by: Thurston Arthritis Research Center/UNC Exercise and Sport Science. INFORMATIONAL email will only be sent to those who have indicated that they do want to receive mass email. To set your informational mass email preference, sign into the UNC Directory at http://dir.unc.edu, login with your Onyen, and select Update Personal Information

subject: Sexual Harassment Workshop
author: davidgu
content:
Dear Faculty, 

The Carolina Seminar Series, The Carolina Women's Center and WISDOM (Women in Science Deserve Opportunities and Mentoring) present a 2 Part Series on Sexual Harassment in Academia. 

For Part 1, a webinar, Dr. Karen Kelsky will share what she learned from conducting the Sexual Harassment in the Academy Survey, including thoughts on the range and scope of sexual harassment in the academic setting, patterns of predation, options for survivors, recommendations to institutions, and particular vulnerabilities of women of color and of queer and transgender women. There will be a 30 min Q&A at the end. This is a brown bag lunch event. 

Part 2 will be a workshop geared towars faculty of all gender and ranks. Through interactive discussion and activities led by campus and community facilitators, the workshop will address the continuum of harassment, how bystanders can intervene effectively, and UNC resources and reporting options around sexual discrimination and harassment. Lunch will be provided. 

The webinar will be April 18th from 12:00pm -1:30pm and the workshop will be April 24th from 12:00pm-4:00pm. Both sessions will be located in the Hitchcock Room in the Sonja Haynes Stone Center. To RSVP for one or both sessions email Grace David at grace_david@med.unc.edu. Space is limited. 

We hope to see you there!

subject: Do you want to learn to slow down and enjoy your life more?
author: kmeason
content:
Mindful Self-Compassion with Karen Bluth and Laura Prochnow Phillips
- Sponsord by the Program on Integrative Medicine-
Limited space is still available!
Do you ever feel like you are too hard on yourself?

That you have a harsh self-critic inside your head that follows you wherever you go??

Are you a caregiver and feeling burned out?

Then this course is for you!

The UNC Program on Integrative Medicine is excited to be offering the Mindful Self-Compassion (MSC) course this spring. Combining the skills of mindfulness and self-compassion, this course provides a powerful tool for emotional resilience. This course has been offered internationally over the last several years and been met with enormous popularity and success, and here at UNC since last fall. Two of the four trained facilitators in North Carolina are here in Chapel Hill and will be teaching this course (Dr. Karen Bluth and Laura Prochnow Phillips).

This course is open to those both new to mindfulness practice and seasoned practitioners.

Class Dates: Wednesdays, April 4 through May 23, 2018, from 6-8:30pm

Instructors: Karen Bluth, Ph.D. & Laura Prochnow Phillips

Location: North Carolina Memorial Hospital, 101 Manning Drive, Chapel Hill, NC 27514 (The Chapel in the UNC Cancer Center)

 To register, please click here!

Free parking available, if needed

For questions, please call 919-966-8586 or email mindfuless@med.unc.edu

Please visit our website  for additional course information and like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter!

subject: DDD - Reorganization of Procurement Services Organization
author: jlkelly
content:
To:          Deans, Directors and Department Chairs


From:    Travis Henderson, Director of Procurement Services

Re:         Reorganization of Procurement Services Organization

 

Procurement Services is announcing several minor organizational changes to strategically align existing resources, consolidate related activities and ensure a focus on operational excellence and continuous improvement. Effective immediately, Procurement Services will consist of four functional units: Purchasing Services, eProcurement and Materials Management, Accounts Payable and Travel Services, and Procurement Services Operations. 

Jessica Hwang-Strickland will manage the new Procurement Services Operations unit, which will focus on P-Card operations, capital asset management, metrics and continuous improvement. As part of this merger of functions, several staff moves will take place: Beverly Braxton and Hua Shen will move to this unit from Purchasing Services and will continue to support P-Card operations.

The new eProcurement and Materials Management unit will be managed by Ammar Yameen, and will focus on logistics and eProcurement functions.  Logistics will now include the following:  surplus store, central receiving, mini storeroom and the dental stockroom.  Al Jeter, longtime manager of surplus store operations, has been promoted and will lead all logistics operations, including central receiving, surplus property and the general storeroom, with the exception of the dental stockroom, which will continue to be led by Kris Tilley. 

Systems and Operations will be renamed as Accounts Payable and Travel Services and will continue to be led by Janet Rupert.

Purchasing Services will remain under the leadership of Bernard Law.

During the next several weeks, we will update our website and staff listings to reflect these changes.  During this transition period, if you have any questions or concerns about the reorganization, please contact Travis Henderson at travishenderson@unc.edu.

 Note:  This memo was sent to Major Organizational Unit (MOU) Financial Leads, University Business Managers and the Research Administrative Support Group (RASG) Listserv.

subject: DEADLINE EXTENDED - Hettleman Prizes for Artistic and Scholarly Achievement by Young Faculty
author: briordan
content:
TO:       Members of the Faculty
             UNC-Chapel Hill                                                                

FROM: Chancellor Carol L. Folt

DATE:  March 27, 2018

RE:       DEADLINE EXTENDED - Nominations for Hettleman Prizes for Artistic 
             and Scholarly Achievement by Young Faculty

 =========================================================

I invite you to submit nominations for the 2018 Hettleman Prizes for Scholarly and Artistic Achievement by Young Faculty.  These prizes, made possible by the generosity of Phillip (UNC Class of 1921) and Ruth Hettleman, recognize scholarly and artistic achievement by junior tenure-track, or recently tenured, members of the faculty.  Four recipients will be selected for the awards of $5,000 each.

Those eligible to be nominated are assistant professors in their third or fourth years who have been recommended for reappointment for a second term, any second term assistant professor, and any associate professor who will not have been in rank as an associate professor for longer than three years at the end of this academic year.

Nominations should include electronic submission of the following, unless otherwise noted:

Nominating Letter
Nominations may be made by appointing units or by members of the University community from within or outside the nominee’s department.  The nominating letter should explain why the nominee’s work is “groundbreaking.”

Nominee’s Curriculum Vitae
Documentation
Articles that the nominee has written, papers that the nominee has given, and/or photographs of art that the nominee has produced.  Electronic and digital submissions are preferred.  If hard copy submission is necessary, please submit seven copies.

Letters of Evaluation
These letters can come from within or outside the nominee’s department, as well as from other institutions.  Letters from the outside do not have to be written explicitly for the Hettleman Award; they can be ones collected for tenure and promotion decision, reappointment considerations or letters written for other awards.  Letters should emphasize and critically evaluate the distinctive contribution of the nominee’s scholarship to his or her discipline.  They must make clear to an audience of intelligent laypersons the scholarly or artistic significance of the nominee’s work.  It is hoped that each scholarly project will already be in the public domain, but manuscripts accepted for publication or in galley form will be considered. 

The new deadline for submission is Monday, April 16, 2018. Please submit electronic nominations to Hettleman_award@unc.edu and hard copy material to the Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research, 312 South Building. 

Vice Chancellor for Research Terry Magnuson and the selection committee, which is comprised of six professors -- three from the Division of Academic Affairs and three from the Division of Health Affairs – will forward a list of recommendations to me. The announcements of the prizes will be made at the first Faculty Council meeting of the fall term of 2018.

Thank you for taking the time to help recognize and reward the work of Carolina’s most promising young faculty.

subject: Healthy women needed for research study
author: jlphilli
content:
Reproductive Endocrinology at NC Women's Hospital

 

We are currently seeking healthy women to participate in research studies.  Several opportunities are available that offer monetary compensation, ranging from $25-200.

 

You may be qualified if the following applies to you:

- Between the ages of 18-35

- Having regular menstrual cycles, every 25-35 days

- Not using birth control pills, hormonal contraceptives or IUD

- Not currently pregnant, or trying to become pregnant

-Flexible schedule

 

The ultimate goal of this research is to better understand the factors that allow implantation to occur so that we may improve clinical outcomes of fertility patients.  If you are interested, please feel free to contact us for more information at uncreproductive@gmail.com.

 

Biomedical IRB study #05-1757 “Molecular Regulation in Reproduction;” approved 01/22/2018

subject: DEADLINE EXTENDED - Hettleman Prizes for Artistic and Scholarly Achievement by Young Faculty
author: briordan
content:
TO:       Members of the Faculty
             UNC-Chapel Hill                                                                

FROM: Chancellor Carol L. Folt

DATE:  March 27, 2018

RE:       DEADLINE EXTENDED - Nominations for Hettleman Prizes for Artistic 
             and Scholarly Achievement by Young Faculty

 =========================================================

I invite you to submit nominations for the 2018 Hettleman Prizes for Scholarly and Artistic Achievement by Young Faculty.  These prizes, made possible by the generosity of Phillip (UNC Class of 1921) and Ruth Hettleman, recognize scholarly and artistic achievement by junior tenure-track, or recently tenured, members of the faculty.  Four recipients will be selected for the awards of $5,000 each.

Those eligible to be nominated are assistant professors in their third or fourth years who have been recommended for reappointment for a second term, any second term assistant professor, and any associate professor who will not have been in rank as an associate professor for longer than three years at the end of this academic year.

Nominations should include electronic submission of the following, unless otherwise noted:

Nominating Letter
Nominations may be made by appointing units or by members of the University community from within or outside the nominee’s department.  The nominating letter should explain why the nominee’s work is “groundbreaking.”

Nominee’s Curriculum Vitae
Documentation
Articles that the nominee has written, papers that the nominee has given, and/or photographs of art that the nominee has produced.  Electronic and digital submissions are preferred.  If hard copy submission is necessary, please submit seven copies.

Letters of Evaluation
These letters can come from within or outside the nominee’s department, as well as from other institutions.  Letters from the outside do not have to be written explicitly for the Hettleman Award; they can be ones collected for tenure and promotion decision, reappointment considerations or letters written for other awards.  Letters should emphasize and critically evaluate the distinctive contribution of the nominee’s scholarship to his or her discipline.  They must make clear to an audience of intelligent laypersons the scholarly or artistic significance of the nominee’s work.  It is hoped that each scholarly project will already be in the public domain, but manuscripts accepted for publication or in galley form will be considered. 

The new deadline for submission is Monday, April 16, 2018. Please submit electronic nominations to Hettleman_award@unc.edu and hard copy material to the Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research, 312 South Building. 

Vice Chancellor for Research Terry Magnuson and the selection committee, which is comprised of six professors -- three from the Division of Academic Affairs and three from the Division of Health Affairs – will forward a list of recommendations to me. The announcements of the prizes will be made at the first Faculty Council meeting of the fall term of 2018.

Thank you for taking the time to help recognize and reward the work of Carolina’s most promising young faculty.

subject: University Policy Management System Transition
author: akintola
content:
The University’s new policy management system is scheduled to go live on Thursday, March 29, 2018.

After completing a competitive RFP process last year, the Office of Ethics Education and Policy Management selected PolicyStat, a web-based, policy management application that provides automated workflow for the creation, editing, review and approval of policies, and also serves as a central location for the publication of University policies as required under the University’s Policy on Policies, effective January 7, 2017. 

The new system will simplify the process of policy management for responsible parties and streamlines access to a comprehensive repository of policy information.

The Office of Ethics Education and Policy Management currently offers training on the University’s new policy framework and has also scheduled training on the new policy management system. To register, please visit: http://policies.unc.edu/training.

Beginning on March 29th, the current link to a limited list of University policies (https://policies.unc.edu/all-policies) will redirect to https://unc.policystat.com/.  If your School, Department or Unit currently links to any policies listed on, please be sure to update your links to those specific polices.

If you have any questions or concerns about a specific policy, please reach out to the Responsible Unit or Issuing Officer.  If you have any questions about the transition, PolicyStat or general policy questions, please refer to our transition information page online, email our office at policy@unc.edu or give me a ring at the number below.

Best,

Tinu



Atinuke O. Diver, J.D.

Associate Director for Ethics Education and Policy Management

Office of the Chancellor

University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

Stay up-to-date with UNC Policy News!

 

134 ½ East Franklin Street, Suite 110

Campus Box 4110

Chapel Hill, NC 27599-4110

Phone: 919-445-8364

Web: policies.unc.edu

subject: INFORMATIONAL FOR A RESEARCH STUDY:
author: khmills
content:
Investigators at the UNC Center for Environmental Medicine, Asthma and Lung Biology 

are screening asthmatic individuals to see how they respond to wood smoke inhalation when riding a stationary bicycle.

 


Contact

Call 919-843-6598 or e-mail smokescreen@med.unc.edu


Requirements
You must be between 18 and 45
You must have mild asthma
Women who are pregnant or nursing a baby cannot participate
You must not any orthopedic limitations
You must not smoke


Time Commitment

There is a 4 hour long General Screening visit (IRB #98-0799). Then there are 3 visits over a 1 month period. The first visit will last about 4 hours, the next visit will be for a full day, and you will return the following day for about 2 ½ hours.


Compensation

Complete General Screen research study visit $75

3 Smokescreen research study visits at EPA building on UNC campus for up to $400.00


 

IRB #15-1775: To identify persons who are susceptible to wood smoke particulate-induced inflammation and examine the role of GSTM1 and other factors in this susceptibility.

 

Approved 01/18/2018 by the Biomedical Institutional Review Board.

subject: 2018 Travel Updates and Restrictions
author: shia
content:
Date:  March 26, 2018

To:   Deans, Directors and Department Heads, University Business Managers, MOU Financial Leads

From: Janet Rupert, Director of Systems and Operations

Subject:  2018 Travel Updates and Restrictions

Along with recent mileage updates, the North Carolina Office of State Budget and Management (OSBM) has released some additional travel guidelines and restrictions for 2018.  University faculty, staff, students, affiliates, and independent contractors may be reimbursed for transportation expenses incurred while traveling on University business.  They must abide by the following restrictions:

Meal reimbursements.  Travelers are only eligible for reimbursement of meals when they make an overnight trip.  Partial day reimbursement is possible when the partial day is the day of departure or return for a trip, but it must be in conjunction with an overnight trip taken.  This differs from past years, where a day trip could have meals reimbursed.  No excess reimbursement will be allowed for meals unless there are predetermined charges, or the meals were for out-of-country travel.

University travelers may claim reimbursement for the following meals if:

Breakfast: depart duty station prior to 6 a.m.
Lunch: depart duty station prior to Noon (day of departure) or return to duty station after 2:00 p.m. (day of return).
Dinner: depart duty station prior to 5:00 p.m. (day of departure) or return to duty station after 8:00 p.m. (day of return).

Clarification to UNC Policy on Excess Lodging Expenses.  Excess lodging expenses must be justified if hotel rates, excluding taxes and surcharges, exceed $300 per night (or $400 per night, if staying in one of the following high-cost cities: Boston, New York City, San Francisco and the Bay Area, Washington DC, and Los Angeles).  If those limits are exceeded, travelers must complete Form 1302.1.1f Excess Lodging Justification and obtain their supervisor's approval and signature before travelling.  Only five justifications are acceptable to claim excess lodging reimbursement:

the hotel is where the conference is located
the hotel is in a high-cost area (and documentation is provided showing this hotel was the most reasonable price)
the safety and security of the traveler was unattainable at the current allowance (a statement due to this effect must be provided and documentation is provided showing this hotel was the most reasonable price)
The hotel had a discounted rate because it was suggested by the conference
The traveler shared this room with a colleague

The signed form should be submitted with the travel reimbursement.

Although this State policy was in effect as of Jan. 1 of this year, the new requirements of the excess lodging form, as well as the necessity of an overnight stay for meal reimbursement, will not be effective for the University until the release date of this memo.  No retro actions need to be taken for previous travel.

subject: Participants wanted for exercise/dietary supplement research
author: trexlere
content:
Hello, my name is Eric Trexler.  I am a doctoral student in the Department of Exercise and Sport Science, and I am currently recruiting participants for a research study, entitled “Performance effects of citrulline malate and beetroot juice supplementation.”

We are looking for healthy, recreationally active men between the ages of 18-35. To qualify for this study, you must be a non-smoker who typically exercises at least two hours per week. In addition, you must not be using supplements or prescription drugs that may influence performance. The purpose of this study is to determine if acute supplementation with the commercially available dietary supplements citrulline malate and/or beetroot juice influence leg strength or muscular endurance.

As a participant, you will be required to sign an informed consent document stating you understand all of the procedures and rights as a research subject, and to fill out questionnaires regarding your health, diet, and physical activity history. The study includes 4 lab visits over the course of 12-30 days.

Your first visit will involve filling out some paperwork and becoming familiarized to the leg extension strength test. At the final three visits, you will consume either citrulline malate, beetroot juice, or a placebo, in random order. Strength testing will be repeated at each visit, two hours after supplement ingestion, to assess leg strength and endurance. During testing, we will noninvasively measure blood flow, muscle size, and oxygen consumption. We will also draw a small amount of blood from a vein in your arm before and after the exercise. All testing will take place in the Neuromuscular Research Laboratory and Applied Physiology Laboratory, which are both located in Fetzer Hall.

If you complete the study, you will receive up to $75 in compensation, along with free strength testing. If you are interested or have questions, please contact Eric Trexler by phone or email.

 

Eric Trexler

trexlere@live.unc.edu

919-962-2163

 

This study (IRB #17-2666) was approved by the UNC Biomedical IRB on 3/8/2018

subject: Implementation of Central Pool for Terminal Leave Payouts, Effective July 1, 2018
author: briordan
content:
Date: March 26, 2018

To: Deans, Directors, and Department Chairs

From: Andy Johns, Senior Associate Vice Chancellor for Research             
           Dwayne Pinkney, Senior Associate Vice Chancellor for Finance & Operations

Re: Implementation of Central Pool for Terminal Leave Payouts, Effective July 1, 2018

The University continuously strives to improve its administrative processes and procedures in order to increase efficiency and effectiveness. In keeping with this goal, the University will implement a central pool for the payout of terminal leave effective July 1, 2018. This central terminal leave payout pool will fund any unused vacation and bonus leave that is eligible for payout upon an employee’s separation from the University. Composite benefits and severance pay are already paid from a separate central pool and will continue to operate with no changes.

 The central terminal leave payout pool will be funded by an assessment of 1.2% of all SHRA and EHRA Non-Faculty employees’ salary funding sources, for each pay period, using a new account code (516130). This rate was determined by reviewing past leave payouts over the past five fiscal years. The total payouts from this central pool will be reviewed annually and the rate will be increased or decreased to adjust for higher or lower than expected payouts.

The existing central composite benefits and severance pay rates will remain unchanged for fiscal year 2018-19 and will also continue to be reviewed annually. A summary of the applicable rates is listed below.

Any terminal leave payouts that are due to employees that separate from the University July 1, 2018 or later will be paid from the central pool and departments will no longer be responsible for those charges. Although this new Terminal Leave Payout assessment may have an impact on how schools and departments plan and budget, we anticipate that the change will provide for greater financial predictability as departments will pay for terminal leave payouts incrementally in advance rather than at the time of employee separation which may not always be anticipated.

Composite Benefits Fund

Expense Account Code: 516120
Salary Base: EHRA and SHRA Salaries paid from Non-State Funds
Rate: 0.50% (Unchanged from prior FY)

Severance Pay Pool

Expense Account Code: 512510
Salary Base: SHRA Salaries paid from Non-State Funds
Rate: 1.00% (Unchanged from prior FY)

Terminal Leave Payout Pool

Expense Account Code: 516130
Salary Base: EHRA Non-Faculty and SHRA paid from All Funds
Rate: 1.20% (New)

subject: 2018 Exitos Graduation Ceremony
author: adrigibi
content:
Dear Carolina Community,

On behalf of the Carolina Latinx Collaborative and the University Office for Diversity & Inclusion, we invite you, as well as all graduating students (undergraduate and graduate/professional, including December 2017 graduates), faculty, and staff of your department to join us at the 5th annual Éxitos Latinx Graduation Ceremony on Friday, May 11, from 5:30-7:30 p.m. at the FedEx Global Education Center. This bilingual event serves to celebrate the work and dedication that students have devoted to the Latinx community. Students do not have to identify as Latinx to participate.

Professor Nilda Peragallo Montana, Dean of the UNC-Chapel Hill School of Nursing, will deliver the keynote. Following our tradition, all participating students will receive a unique Éxitos Latinx stole as a small token of appreciation for their commitment.

Families and friends will have the opportunity to connect with the people who have guided the graduating students on their Carolina journey, take pictures with Rameses, and enjoy Latinx-inspired cuisine. We will also livestream the event on Facebook.

RSVP required. Please register here.

Please contact Josmell Perez at josmell@unc.edu if you have any questions.

Thank you,

The Carolina Latinx Collaborative

subject: Couples Counseling
author: pentel
content:
Are you interested in learning skills to improve/strengthen your relationship?

Do you disagree on topics related to being in a same-sex relationship (e.g., who to come out to or how to find a supportive social network?)

I specialize in working with couples and am conducting a small treatment research study of a no-cost couple therapy program. To be eligible for this pilot study, you and your partner must meet the following criteria:

-Living together more than 6 months
-Age 21 or older
-Identify as cisgender (biological/birth sex aligns with gender identity)
-Identify as female
-Have a certain level of distress in your relationship, including stress related to living in a heteronormative society (this will be assessed on the phone screen)

While we would hope for this program to be available to all couples, for the purpose of this initial pilot study we can only recruit a small sample of 12 couples. We hope to expand this program in the future. If you are not eligible for ACCESS, we can provide referrals to other appropriate couples counseling resources.

Questions? Interested in setting up an initial phone screening call to determine eligibility? Contact Kim (she/her) at ACCESSprogram@unc.edu or check out our website at: http://ACCESSprogram.web.unc.edu. All inquiries are confidential.



Study Title: ACCESS: Affirming Couple Counseling to Engage Same-Sex partners. UNC-CH IRB #: 17-2482, Nonbiomedical. Date Approved: October 17, 2017.

subject: Voter Registration Information
author: kcrandol
content:
If you are planning to vote in the upcoming primary elections for U.S. Congress, the North Carolina legislature, and depending on your precinct, local elections, you must be registered to vote by Friday, April 13, 2018.

To register to vote in North Carolina, you can access voter registration forms online through the North Carolina State Board of Elections. You may also pick up a hard copy form at Davis Library or in the Student Government Suite: Carolina Union, Room 3109. Student Government is also providing online voter registration assistance through https://unc.turbovote.org/.

Completed forms dropped off at the front desk of the Student Government Suite will be delivered to the Orange County Board of Elections, free of charge. If you choose to mail your own form, please remember to postmark it no later than the deadline of April 13, 2018. Forms can be mailed from any mailbox on campus, including the U.S. Post Office located in UNC Student Stores.

The national voter registration form for registering to vote in other states may be accessed here.

One-stop early voting in Orange County will run from Thursday, April 19, 2018, until Saturday, May 5, 2018. The University will send more information about early voting locations, dates and times in April.

subject: Participants Needed: Paired Work Tasks, Perceptions and Experiences in Vocal Duets
author: jkwest
content:
Participants Needed: Paired Work Tasks

Paired Work Tasks. We are interested in how people interact on various types of work tasks. You will work in groups and with a partner to complete multiple tasks. This study will last approximately 60 minutes. You will also be given the opportunity to earn entries into a raffle for a $100 Amazon gift card.

Due to the nature of recruitment for group studies, there is a possibility that you will not be able to complete this task if other participants miss their appointments or there are more participants that needed. In that event, you will receive a payment of $5 for your time and will be able to sign up again in the future.

Location: McColl 4402

Duration: 60 minutes

Pay: $12 + raffle tickets

IRB # 18-0771

Exclusions:

----                                                                                                                                       

Participants Needed: Perceptions & Experiences in Vocal Duets

Perceptions & Experiences in Vocal Duets. You are being asked to participate in a research study about the perceptions and experiences of vocal duets. You will be paid $8.00 at the completion of the study, which is estimated to take you about 30 minutes or less.

All studies will take place in the Behavioral Lab (McColl 4402). Please visit our website at, https://kf-c4dr.sona-systems.com, to register for this study.

Location: McColl 4402

Duration: 30 minutes

Pay: $8

IRB # 17-2407

Exclusions: must be 18 or older; must not have completed Perceptions & Experiences of Vocal Duets study

___                                                                                                                                       

This project (Center for Decision Research, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, IRB # 11-1187) was approved by the Non-Biomedical IRB on 7/20/2017

subject: Class project
author: yasminv
content:
Dear students,

You are receiving this email on behalf of UNC Public Health Epidemiology 600 course. Please consider helping our students get some real world epidemiology experience by filling out the questionnaires they have designed in order to answer some interesting public health questions. The following links will allow you to access the specific survey of the team listed and the topic covered by the survey precedes the link. Your participation is greatly appreciated and these surveys take less than 5 minutes to complete. Thank you!

Team 1: We are interested in how frequently students visit Campus Health: https://unc.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_4ZnoQ9Rfq5QPOQZ


Team 3: Our survey covers awareness of mental health symptoms: https://unc.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_1WT1CNfFbFxw1qB

Team 34: We are doing a survey about campus safety and possible correlation to educational opportunities: https://unc.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_0OQf574cPRNBFgp

Team 38: In this brief 25-question survey you will be asked questions regarding human papillomavirus (HPV): https://unc.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_ezWQmdF9RZGtESp


This EPID 600 class project has been reviewed by the UNC Office of Human Research Ethics and determined not to be research (Study #: 13-2923). The data collected will only be used for the class project and will be kept confidential. Once the project is completed, the data will be deleted. If you have any questions, please contact (Team 1: katchan@live.unc.edu; Team 3: rajeen@live.unc.edu; Team 38: erinsley@live.unc.edu; Team 34: davisnm@live.unc.edu) and  Dr.  Yeatts, Karin_Yeatts@unc.edu.

 If you have any questions, please direct them to the appropriate team member listed above.

subject: WOW 2018: Submit an event proposal
author: ebhooks
content:
It will soon be time to welcome new first-year and transfer students to Carolina this fall. New Student & Family Programs (NSFP) invites the University community to submit event proposals designed to welcome and engage our newest students. Below are two opportunities to get involved:

Week of Welcome: August 17 – 26, 2018
During Week of Welcome (WOW), new first-year and transfer students have the opportunity to attend a diverse array of academic and community-building programs to help them through their transition to the Carolina community.
Recognized student organizations, University colleges, schools and departments are invited to submit WOW events by Tuesday, April 17th at 11:59pm.
Tar Heel Beginnings: August 27 – December 2018
Continuing with the momentum from Week of Welcome, Tar Heel Beginnings (THB) events are intentionally designed fall programs seeking to introduce new first-year and transfer students to the expectations, resources, and involvement opportunities during their first semester at UNC-Chapel Hill.
Recognized student organizations, University colleges, schools, and departments are invited to submit Tar Heel Beginnings event by Tuesday, April 17th at 11:59pm.
Please note that all departments and student organizations hosting a WOW and THB events are responsible for completing all event facility reservations and related facility costs, as well as abiding by all University policies and procedures. 

Event proposals for both WOW and THB must be submitted through the following online forms:

Week of Welcome Event Proposal

Tar Heel Beginnings Event Proposal

If you would like to submit more than two events, please email thb@unc.edu for an Excel template.



Thank you for helping support our newest Tar Heels. For additional information or questions, please contact New Student & Family Programs at thb@unc.edu or 919-962-8304.



Sincerely,

New Student & Family Programs

subject: Something not quite right? You may be eligible to participate in a study in the Prime Research Program.
author: grewen
content:
The UNC Department of Psychiatry is conducting a research study to find out more about mental illness.  If you have had any of the following symptoms in the past few months, are between 12-30 years old, and have not been diagnosed with psychosis, you may be eligible to participate in a study in the Prime Research Program.

 

Do you sometimes feel confused about what is real or imaginary?
Have you felt that things happening around you have a special meaning just for you?
Are you feeling confused by things you hear or see?
Have you noticed unusual coincidences or connections that others do not seem to notice?
Do you ever feel like you just know what others are thinking or that others somehow know what you are thinking?
Are you worried that others are talking about you or laughing about you?
Do you think that others are trying to hurt you?
Do you have a close relative with a psychotic disorder and you’ve had a drop in function over the past year?

 

You may be eligible to receive free study related medical evaluations and monetary compensation.  Study participation includes multiple visits lasting 2-8 hours over 2 years.  These visits will take place at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

 

Visit us at our www.PRIME.unc.edu and click on 'Simple Survey' or call (877) PRIME19 or (877) 774-6319.

 

The Project is funded by the National Institute of Mental Health

 

14-2055 Approved 6-11-2015

Committee on the Protection of the Rights of Human Subjects

The BioMedical IRB

University of North Carolina

subject: Message from Chancellor Carol L. Folt
author: janerc
content:
Dear Carolina Community:

I am writing to share with you that Phyllis Petree, chief audit officer, will retire at the end of September after 23 years of faithful service to Carolina. I appreciate Phyllis’ countless contributions that have enhanced and improved University operations. Phyllis is a trusted adviser to me, our senior administrators and the Board of Trustees. She will conclude her devoted tenure having served five chancellors and dozens of other University leaders.

A 1978 alumna, Phyllis returned to Carolina in 1995 as the director of internal audit, and has transformed the audit function to meet the growing needs of the campus community and to ensure we remain accountable to the taxpayers of North Carolina. Under Phyllis’ leadership, the internal audit office has provided expansive consulting and advisory services across the University. I know all campus leaders will join me in thanking Phyllis for the depth and breadth of her counsel, careful analysis and attention to detail in every matter.

Over the past two decades, Phyllis has worked diligently to ensure that the University’s processes and procedures are best in class. Phyllis streamlined our audit processes and developed the first internal audit charter; internal audit manual; and finance, infrastructure and audit committee charter. She implemented risk-based internal audit schedules and projects. She developed a strategic plan and key performance indicators for the internal audit office. She also commissioned the first external quality assessment review to evaluate the internal audit office’s conformity with the International Standards for the Professional Practice of Internal Auditing.

Phyllis has always approached her work with the utmost integrity, and her keen understanding of campus operations and steady guidance will be missed. Vice Chancellor for Finance and Operations Jonathan Pruitt will chair the search committee for the next chief audit officer, and I am grateful that Phyllis will remain in the position until her successor is hired.

Please join me in thanking Phyllis for her steadfast leadership and commitment to Carolina and wishing her well in retirement.

Sincerely,

Carol L. Folt
Chancellor

subject: Apply for University Leadership Education and Development (ULEAD)
author: kwbryant
content:
Dear Faculty and Staff:

We want to encourage high-performing, high-potential managers to apply for the annual University Leadership Education and Development (ULEAD) program. ULEAD gives participants the tools and skills they need to meet the challenges of the changing higher education landscape and take the next step in their careers. The program emphasizes strategic thinking, innovation, communication, and teamwork. This is an excellent opportunity to participate in a proven professional development program specific to higher education.

Pre-program elements of ULEAD begin in late spring, and the program runs through the fall semester. The curriculum includes a series of classes, a 360 multi-rater assessment, peer coaching, and team projects designed to contribute in real and innovative ways to improving university effectiveness. Participants receive the benefit of learning from the world-renowned faculty of the Kenan-Flagler Business School, as well as other highly regarded professionals.

To provide the maximum opportunity for interaction and networking, ULEAD selects 19 representatives from UNC-Chapel Hill, four from NC Central University, and one from the UNC System Office. Participants must be high-performing, highly motivated managers who are directly responsible for at least one supervisor or for a program of significant size and complexity. Applicants are nominated by their managers and must receive approval from their Dean, Vice Chancellor, or designee.

Applications will be accepted for ULEAD through April 5. The program is extremely competitive, so we encourage applicants to ensure their application materials best reflect their development goals and achievements.

For the online application and full program schedule, as well as more information on ULEAD, visit https://hr.unc.edu/ulead/. This program is sponsored by the Office of Human Resources in the Division of Workforce Strategy, Equity and Engagement.

If you have questions or wish to find out more about ULEAD, please contact William Frey in the Office of Human Resources at 962-9685 or will_frey@unc.edu.

Sincerely,

Felicia A. Washington
Vice Chancellor for Workforce Strategy, Equity and Engagement

Linc Butler
Associate Vice Chancellor for Human Resources

subject: LEAVING EDEN: A North Carolina Fable, 10% Off at PlayMakers
author: rosalie
content:
Get ready to run to the river at PlayMakers. With your UNC Faculty/Staff Discount, you get 10% OFF tickets to the final mainstage production of the PlayMakers season. Immerse yourself in the music of North Carolina, past and present, with Leaving Eden, a new play by Mike Wiley with music by Laurelyn Dossett.

Be swept along to the fictional town of Marah, North Carolina, where black families worked in its cotton mills during 1930s and the Latino immigrants work in its processing plants today. Echoes of love, violence, and racial tension rumble in word and music born from being needed but not wanted and the quest for the restless to make a home.



Playwright Mike Wiley was just named a Distinguished Alumnus of UNC-Chapel Hill for his compelling works of documentary theatre, sharing dynamic portrayals of pivotal moments in African-American history. Meanwhile, Laurelyn Dossett’s multifaceted music career has seen her tour with the North Carolina Symphony and collaborate with Grammy Award-winning Rhiannon Giddens and the Carolina Chocolate Drops.

Leaving Eden is the rightful descendant of the Carolina Playmakers’ storied tradition of oral history-style folk plays, originated by UNC’s “Proff” Koch in 1918. It is also PlayMakers’ first full commission in its 40+ years as a professional theatre company.

Leaving Eden runs April 4 through 22. To save even more, make a point to see the show while it’s still in previews, April 4–6, when tickets are already up to 20% less.

NEW THIS SEASON: Login with your ONYEN and receive the faculty/staff discount online! Or you can always visit or call the Box Office: 919.962.7529.


For more information, visit our website.

 

Photo of the cast of Leaving Eden by HuthPhoto

Don’t let the school year pass you by without catching the latest show at PlayMakers: Leaving Eden, a new play by Mike Wiley with music & lyrics by Laurelyn Dossett.

Be swept along to the fictional town of Marah, North Carolina, where black families worked in its cotton mills during 1930s and undocumented immigrants work in its processing plants today. Echoes of love, violence, and racial tension rumble in word and music born from being needed but not wanted and the quest for the restless to make a home.

 

 This brand new play is a theatrical event years in the making. #ThinkTheatre and immerse yourself in the kind of storytelling experience that has remained central to humanity since the the first “big fish” story ever told.

Join us for this a musical journey across time, as the citizens of one small town remain restless for a place they can truly call home. Leaving Eden is on stage April 4 through 22.

NEW THIS SEASON: Login with your ONYEN to purchase tickets online! Or you can always visit or call the Box Office: 919.962.7529.



For more information, visit our website. 



Photo of the cast of Leaving Eden by HuthPhoto

subject: Needed 5-10 years old children for a hearing study
author: mdev
content:
HEARING RESEARCH STUDY                                                                             

 We are currently recruiting listeners for a hearing research study.

 Your child may be eligible to participate in this research study if:

-he or she is between the ages of 5-10 years old

-he or she has normal hearing

-he or she has no history of ear problems

 

The purpose of this research study is to obtain a better understanding of hearing.

 Participants will sit in a soundproof room and listen to sounds presented over headphones. The research study will take approximately 1-2 sessions of one hour each and takes place in Marsico Hall. Your child will be compensated for his or her time at a rate of $15/hour.

 

If your child is interested in participating in this research study please contact us atHearingLab@med.unc.edu.

 

This study has been approved by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill's Biomedical Institutional Review Board: Study #86-0059. The title for this IRB study is "Development and Plasticity in Normal and Impaired Ears". The most recent approved IRB modification date is 11/13/2013.

 

This email is sponsored by: Hearing Research Lab

subject: Reservation Requests for Venues Managed by Carolina Performing Arts
author: msteffen
content:
Starting on Monday, April 2, 2018 requests to reserve Memorial Hall, Gerrard Hall, Historic Playmakers Theatre, and the CURRENT ArtSpace + Studio for the 2018-19 academic year (August 21, 2018 - August 19, 2019) will be accepted through the online request form found at www.carolinaperformingarts.org/about/venues/venue-rental-information/. Please visit this page for more information about specific venues, including information about cost.

Requests that are received at any point on April 2nd will be randomly ranked for preference. There is no advantage to being the first person to submit a request on April 2nd or to submitting duplicate submissions. All requests received after April 2nd will be filled in the order in which they are received.

All events must be scheduled at least forty-five days in advance. Due to high demand, groups will be allowed a maximum of one Friday or Saturday use of Memorial Hall per semester.

For more information or to inquire about the availability of specific dates before placing a request, please contact Mark Steffen at msteffen@email.unc.edu.
