subject: Earn $20! Calling i2b2 users for a Case Study
author: wanchen6
content:
Dear all,

My name is Wanchen Zhao, a research assistant at UNC Center for Health Equity Research and a second-year graduate student in Information Science at The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. I am conducting a case study for a newly designed visual query system to see how users interact with the system to refine the initial query in order to select a satisfactory cohort for a given research and we will use the data collected to improve our interface.

You are eligible to participate in the study if:

you are at least 21 years of age,
you are either in the medical related research area or tech related research area,
you must have undergone i2b2 training and used the i2b2 interface.
This study is set to last between 45 to 60 minutes, where you will perform a given set of tasks on a visual query system and undergo a semi-structured interview to discuss your experience. You will receive a $20 compensation for your time and effort that can contribute directly towards shaping the newly designed visual query interface, helping us make a potential contribution to the i2b2 consortium.

If you are interested in learning more about this study or signing up to participate, please respond to this email at wanchen6@live.unc.edu.

Thank you for your time and consideration. We look forward to hearing from you.

Study approved by the UNC IRB on 3.8, 2018 (Study # 18-0266, Non-Biomedical)

 

Sincerely,

Wanchen Zhao
Master of Information Science candidate 2018
School of Information and Library Science
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

wanchen6@live.unc.edu

 

Faculty advisor: David Gotz, PhD
School of Information and Library Science
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

gotz@unc.edu

subject: Take part in an online search behavior study and earn $15!
author: choiboge
content:
Have you used a search engine like Google? (Who haven’t, right?) Then you can be a part of a research study that looks into how task characteristics and individual differences can influence search behavior when people are searching. We will ask you to complete a couple of tasks in a 60-minute long study session and as an exchange of participation, you will receive $15 in cash!



This study will take place on-campus, in the Interactive Information System Lab (IISL) in Manning Hall. You will not be offered any special consideration for participating in this study. This is purely voluntary.



If you are interested in participating, please email choiboge@live.unc.edu



Eligibility
A participant must be at least 18 years old.
A participant must be currently working at UNC-Chapel Hill.
A participant must be fluent in both spoken and written English.



IRB study number: 17-3304



Thank you,
Vivian Bogeum Choi, Graduate Research Assistant
School of Information and Library Science
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

subject: Infant/Toddler Development Study
author: sallie7
content:
Parents and Infants Engaged (PIE) Study

IRB #17-0292; Non-Biomedical IRB Approval Date: March 25th, 2017

 

Do you want to learn more about your infant’s development?

How:

Participate in a research study to better understand early signs of developmental concerns in infants 11 through 16 months of age and test a free home-based intervention.

What you do:

Complete a brief screening tool about your infant:

Go online to complete the screening tool at https://is.gd/PIEstudy

OR ask for a paper copy by contacting the study by email at PIEstudy@unc.edu or by calling 919-842-9582 at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

What will happen next:

We are looking for infants who show high risk on the screening tool to offer a free developmental assessment.
If the assessment results confirm that your child is a good candidate for the intervention, we will invite you to participate in that part of the study. The intervention will be provided in your home for 1 hour per week for 12 weeks. A coach will help you use strategies to help your child develop.
We will offer information for other intervention services if needed. You can decide at any point whether to continue with the study.

 

Principal Investigators: Drs. Linda Watson and Grace Baranek, Department of Allied Health Sciences, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

Contact us: PIEstudy@unc.edu or 919-842-9582

subject: MUSC 364 Summer Jazz Workshop | Summer School Course Satisfying the Experiential Education Requirement (June 18-22, 2018)
author: anderssr
content:
SUBJECT:  MUSC 364 Summer Jazz Workshop | Summer School Course Satisfying the Experiential Education Requirement (June 18-22, 2018)

UNC Summer School and the Department of Music MUSC 364 will offer the UNC Summer Jazz Workshop (https://music.UNC.edu/SummerJazzWorkshop) Monday-Friday June 18-22, 2018. The course applies to Summer School Session II, earning 3.0 credit hours, and it satisfies the "Experiential Education" requirement at UNC.  There are two ways to attend and receive college credit:

1. As a student in MUSC 364 studying music related journalism, jazz history, and learning basic music skills. These students learn journalism using social media, write blogs about the evening concerts, study jazz history, and learn rudimentary music skills. They are not required to perform in a combo during the workshop.

2. As a performer in MUSC 364 studying jazz theory, improvisation, playing in a combo, participating in group lessons and jam sessions, and performing in the final Friday afternoon Student Combo Concert.

ABOUT THE WORKSHOP: The UNC Summer Jazz Workshop (https://music.UNC.edu/SummerJazzWorkshop) is a partnership between UNC Summer School and the Department of Music that began in 2011 and has drawn students from across the country since then. This unique five-day program caters to students of a variety of ages -- high school students, college students, and adults who want to study and be immersed in a high-paced jazz program which provides instruction in jazz theory, improvisation, small group playing, and group lessons. Rising high school seniors, college students, and adults have the option to enroll in MUSC 364 to earn 3.0 hours of college credit, while those in the Community section of the workshop participate in a separate track of morning classes. In the afternoon, those in the MUSC 364 Performance and the Community classes join together in the jazz combos, lessons, and evening concerts. Each evening, Monday through Thursday, the faculty and guest artists give concerts, and students attend the performances. On Friday evening, the student combos will perform. All concerts are free and open to the public. Refreshments are served each afternoon between classes. The students receive UNC SJW T-shirts and water bottles.

CONCERT SCHEDULE: This year the featured guests will be The Dominican Jazz Project (http://dominicanjazzproject.com/about), a Latin jazz group featuring artists from the Dominican Republic. Below is a link to the concert schedule.

https://music.unc.edu/summerjazzworkshop/concert-schedule

SJW VIDEOS

Workshop Overview
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rShRdpcRBfg

Lynn Seaton Trio Concert (2013) 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uOvWy3Sb7lY

Student Combo Concert (2015)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rSvNXkqPgHU

DAILY SCHEDULE MUSC 364 JOURNALISM/JAZZ HISTORY/BASIC MUSIC SKILLS

9:30-10:45am Jazz History
11am-11:30am Basic Music Skills
11:30-12:20 LUNCH
12:20-1:30pm Observe Beginning Improvisation
2-3:15pm Journalism Class
3:30-4:30pm Observe Group Lessons
4:45-5:30pm Interviews with faculty, guests, students
5:30-7pm DINNER
7-9pm Evening concerts (Monday-Thursday)
4-7pm Friday Final Student Combo Concert

DAILY SCHEDULE MUSC 364 PERFORMERS

9:30am-10:40am Jazz Theory and Skills
10:55am-12:05pm Improvisation and Jazz History
12:05-1:45pm LUNCH/practice time
1:45-3:15pm Jazz Combo
3:30-4:30pm Group Lessons
4:45-5:30pm *Sit in with the Faculty Jam Session (optional)
5:30-7pm DINNER BREAK/practice time
7-9pm Evening Concerts (Monday-Thursday)
4-7pm Friday Final Student Combo Concert

SUBMIT AN APPLICATION TO ATTEND
http://music.unc.edu/summerjazzworkshop/apply/

Thank you,

Dr. Stephen Anderson, D.M.A.
Professor, Composition and Jazz Studies
Director, UNC Summer Jazz Workshop
Department of Music, CB #3320
The University of North Carolina
Chapel Hill, NC 27599-3320
anderssr@email.unc.edu
https://music.UNC.edu/SummerJazzWorkshop

subject: Participate in a research study to help improve the UNC Libraries' website
author: sjarnold
content:
We're conducting a research study to help improve the organization of the UNC Libraries' website. The survey will give you an opportunity to tell us about the Library services you use most often.  The survey should take you approximately 10 minutes. There is no risk to you by participating. If you are 18 years old and over you are eligible to participate. There is no direct benefit to you for participating in this study. If you complete the survey, you will be entered in a drawing based on chance in which each participant has equal odds of receiving one of three $50 Amazon gift cards.

At the end of the survey, you will be asked to provide your email address if you wish to enter the drawing. It will not be linked to your survey responses. Each participant who provides an email address has equal odds of receiving a gift card.

By clicking on this link (http://go.unc.edu/library-survey) and completing the survey, you agree to be a participant in this study.

If you have any questions regarding this survey, you may contact Sarah Arnold via email at sjarnold@unc.edu.

Note: this survey may not display correctly on some mobile devices.

subject: Take part in an online search behavior study and earn $15!
author: choiboge
content:
Have you used a search engine like Google? (Who haven’t, right?) Then you can be a part of a research study that looks into how task characteristics and individual differences can influence search behavior when people are searching for information using a search engine. We will ask you to complete a couple of tasks in a 60-minute long study session and as an exchange of participation, you will receive $15 in cash!

 

This study will take place on-campus, in the Interactive Information System Lab (IISL) in Manning Hall. You will not be offered any special consideration for participating in this study. This is purely voluntary.

 

If you are interested in participating, please email choiboge@live.unc.edu

 

Eligibility
A participant must be at least 18 years old.
A participant must be currently working at UNC-Chapel Hill.
A participant must be fluent in both spoken and written English.

 

IRB study number: Non-Biomedical 17-3304
IRB approval date: 03/01/2018

 

Thank you,
Vivian Bogeum Choi, Graduate Research Assistant
School of Information and Library Science
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

subject: Organizational Changes in Facilities Services
author: sboyle
content:
TO:          Deans, Directors and Department Chairs
                University Business Managers

FROM:     Anna Wu, Associate Vice Chancellor for Facilities Services

SUBJECT: Organizational Changes in Facilities Services

DATE:      March 16, 2018

Effectively immediately, the Facilities Services Engineering Services, Construction Services and Management, and Facilities Planning and Design departments will be restructured and transition from three departments into two. This reorganization will allow us to align related roles within primary reporting units while allowing for operational efficiencies. We will continue to maintain our current levels of service and support to the University campus in these areas.

Engineering and Construction
The Engineering Services and Construction Services and Management departments will be merged into one unit. Greg Driver, currently executive director of Engineering Services and University Engineer, will oversee this consolidated group of Facilities functions in his new position of executive director of Engineering and Construction. This department will provide the following services: Facilities Engineering, Energy Management, Construction Management and Construction Services.

Facilities Planning and Design
Engineering Information Services will be managed as a division of the Facilities Planning and Design department under the leadership of Executive Director and Assistant University Architect Evan Yassky. Facilities Planning and Design will now provide the following services: Project Planning and Management, Design Services, Interior Design and Space Planning, and Engineering Information Services.

The Facilities Services website will be updated to reflect this new departmental structure in the coming week. If you have any questions or concerns about these organizational changes, please contact Greg Driver at greg.driver@fac.unc.edu or Evan Yassky at evan.yassky@facilities.unc.edu.

subject: Total WellBeing Wellness Expo TODAY
author: kwbryant
content:
Join us TODAY from 11 a.m.-2 p.m. for the 2018 Total WellBeing Wellness Expo!
The 2018 Total WellBeing Expo will bring almost 100 exhibitors to the Rams Head Recreation Center with information on how to stay healthy, happy and safe from head to heel. See website for a full list of exhibitors.

The Expo will also feature many opportunities to try something new, have fun, and win prizes. This year, you have the chance to win prizes for participating in wellness activities. Prizes include Fitbits, North Carolina Football Club home opener tickets, and water bottles. Earn a raffle entry for each healthy activity you participate in!

Plus you can enjoy lunch at the Rams Head Dining Hall for a reduced price of $5 between 11 a.m.-2 p.m.

Activities below are free to all UNC-Chapel Hill faculty and staff.

Health Check: 9:30 a.m. – 1:30 p.m.

Walk-in appointments begin at 9:45 a.m. and are offered on a first available basis.

Know your cholesterol, blood glucose/A1c, blood pressure, body mass index, and waist circumference in just 15 minutes!

Be sure to bring your State Health Plan insurance card to the Expo. You will NOT be able to receive a full screening without your health insurance ID card.

Provided by the NC State Health Plan. Please note: Individual results are NOT shared with your employer or the State Health Plan. 

Fitness Demonstrations 11:15 a.m. – 2 p.m.

Get ready to move! Join the Fitness Corner for a variety of 20-30 minute group exercise demonstrations throughout the day.

11:15 a.m. – Line Dancing (Join the dance party! It’s not all honky tonk)
12:00 p.m.—Title Boxing (Pick up some total knockout moves)
12:45 p.m. —Muscle Cut (Work all your muscles, even the little ones)
1:30 p.m. —Tai Chi (Regain focus and find peace)
Open walk at the Rams Head indoor track (2nd floor) 11 a.m. – 2 p.m.

Cooking Demonstrations: 11:15 a.m. – 1:30 p.m.

A chef from Carolina Dining Services will be teaching you how to make Baked Chicken Pitas with Hummus Slaw! It’s so good you won’t even notice it’s not fried. 

Demos will be held at the following times:

11:15 a.m.
12:00 p.m.
12:45 p.m.
1:30 p.m.
Questions?

For questions about the 2018 Total WellBeing Expo, please email hr@unc.edu.

subject: Research Study for Juulers, vapers, cigarette smokers, or hookah smokers
author: bgbradfo
content:
Researchers from the UNC School of Medicine and the Center for Environmental Medicine and Lung Biology plan to examine cells from the nose and lungs of volunteers who use a Juul or other vaping device, smoke cigarettes or hookah. They will also draw blood. There is a good deal of scientific information available on the effects of regular cigarette smoking, but very little on the effects of other inhaled tobacco and nicotine products, such as Juuls, other vaping devices and hookahs. 

 

You may be able to be in this research study if you;

Are between the ages of 18 and 50
Have NO significant health problems, including asthma, chronic lung disease, cardiac disease, or any immune deficiencies
Women who are pregnant should not participate
Can come to the UNC campus in Chapel Hill for two visits, lasting 1 to 3 hours
 

If you complete all research study procedures, you will be compensated $140.00. You will receive an additional $40.00 for completing a four week smoking diary for a total of $180.00.

 

Please review study at:    http://www.med.unc.edu/cemalb/studies/study-template

 

Call 919.966.2879 or email tcorsrecruit@unc.edu for more information

 

This is sponsored by the Center for Environmental Medicine, Asthma and Lung Biology

 

Approved 2/5/2018 by the Biomedical Institutional Review Board.    IRB # 13-3454

subject: School of Education offers ImagineLab teen summer camps
author: mrhobbs
content:
School of Education offers ImagineLab Teen Summer Camps

Two tech-centered summer camps for middle and high school students are being offered by the UNC-Chapel Hill School of Education. Children of UNC-affiliated families qualify for an extended early-bird discount.

The ImagineLab camps offer students opportunities to build skills, connections, and confidence in their own abilities to become designers, makers and innovators, and make lasting friendships along the way. All students have the opportunity to create a digital portfolio showcasing their innovations.

The “Game Changers” and “Dream Builders” camps will be held for ten weeks, June 11th through Aug. 17th, at the Carolina Center for Educational Excellence, located adjacent to Smith Middle School on Seawell School Road in Chapel Hill. Camp will conclude with a Youth Innovation Showcase on Friday, August 17th where campers can earn awards and prizes for their innovations.

Students will have the chance to learn code, compose original songs, program robots, build their own games, create virtual worlds in Minecraft, design and build their own costumes and props, write their own digital books, build their own apps, produce their own videos, print in 3D, explore an immersive virtual reality learning lab, and pitch their creations in an innovation showcase.

Among the activities:

Build your own cardboard arcade and play with friends
Build and program bots such as Sphero or Ozobot
Design and play your own games, soundtracks and animations
Build and engineer in Minecraft
Create art designs with Pearler
Maker projects with Nintendo Switch Labo
Code your own apps in MIT App Inventor
Explore virtual reality design in Google Blocks
Create digital music and video production
Create your own digital books and comic books
Prototype designs using 3D printing

Each camp costs $399/week. Early bird discount of $25 per week is extended through March 30th. Campers are not required to attend all weeks. Families may purchase weeks as desired. Limited scholarship funding is available for families who demonstrate financial need.

For more information and to register, visit http://ccee.unc.edu/summercamp/

subject: Infant/Toddler Nap Study
author: pagejm
content:
Subject: Early Development and Sleep Research Study
Hello, The Frohlich Lab, a leader in brain network dynamics at UNC, has an exciting research study that your infant/toddler between the ages of 12-30 months can participate in with just 2 short sessions.
 In this research study, we are examining sleep characteristics in infants/toddlers that may have:
-Language delays (i.e., no words at 18 months, limited vocalizations at 12 months)
-Delays in social communication or play                   
-Autism or who are at-risk for autism (have a sibling with autism). 
Children develop and change rapidly during infancy and toddlerhood. We know that sleep is a critical aspect of health and brain development. However, little has been done to document patterns of sleep in young children or examine how brain activity during sleep may differ in children with delays and children with autism.
~You may be eligible if:
Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months with language delays (i.e., no words at 18 months, limited vocalizations at 12 months)
. Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months with delays in social communication or play
.  Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months with an autism spectrum disorder.
Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months who has an older sibling with an autism spectrum disorder.
 
~We schedule the two visits at your convenience and you will be with your child at all times. Each visit will take about 2- 2 ½ hours. The types of activities involved:
. A visit to your home at your convenience: Infant developmental assessments
. A visit to the nap room: Non-invasive recording (brain rhythms) during a midday nap. Your child will be playing with a variety of toys and taking a nap. This location offers free parking. We will compensate you $75 for your time. For more information, or to see if your child is eligible, please call Jessica Page at 919-445-0227 or email jessica.page@unc.edu or EDS@med.unc.edu.  You can find out more on our website at http://www.frohlichlab.org/. We look forward to your participation! The Frohlich Lab                         This study was approved by the UNC biomedical IRB on 1/17/18 (IRB # 15-1829)

subject: Hearing research study
author: hlang
content:
HEARING RESEARCH STUDY                                                                           


We are currently recruiting listeners for a hearing research study. You may be eligible to participate in this research study if:

-you are between the ages of 19–50 years old

-you have normal hearing

-you have no history of ear problems

The purpose of this research study is to obtain a better understanding of hearing. Participants will sit in a soundproof room and listen to sounds presented over headphones.  The research study will take approximately 2–5 sessions of one hour each and takes place in Marsico Hall.  You will be compensated for your time at a rate of $15/hour.


If you are interested in participating in this research study please contact us at HearingLab@med.unc.edu


This study has been approved by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill's Biomedical Institutional Review Board: Study #86-0059. The title for this IRB study is "Development and Plasticity in Normal and Impaired Ears". The most recent approved IRB modification date is 3/8/2018.

subject: Nominations open for 2018 Thomas Jefferson Award
author: turnerkm
content:
The Office of Faculty Governance, on behalf of the Committee on Honorary Degrees and Special Awards, is now accepting nominations for the University’s 2018 Thomas Jefferson Award.

This award, established in 1961, is given annually to “that member of the academic community who through personal influence and performance of duty in teaching, writing, and scholarship has best exemplified the ideals and objectives of Thomas Jefferson.”  Any active member of the faculty is eligible, including those participating in the phased-retirement program.

Full information about the award (including criteria, eligibility, a list of past recipients, and directions for how to submit a nomination) is available here on the Faculty Governance website.

The deadline for nominations is March 27, 2018.  The award will be presented at a future Faculty Council meeting. 

Please contact Kadejah Murray, university program associate, at kadejahm@email.unc.edu if you have any questions about the nomination and selection process.

subject: Research study for adults with osteoarthritis or joint pain, aching or stiffness
author: bahorski
content:
Are you an adult with osteoarthritis or pain, aching, or stiffness in your knees or hips? 

You may be interested in a research study to help researchers learn about partner support and physical activity.  

The UNC Thurston Arthritis Research Center is conducting a research study for people with hip or knee osteoarthritis (or arthritis-related joint symptoms) and their spouse or partner. We are interested in learning how couples discuss and overcome barriers to increasing physical activity. Research shows that becoming more active can help people manage joint pain and stiffness, in addition to having other health benefits.

Participants will attend a 2 ½ hour, one-time meeting that may help them make changes to lead a more physically active lifestyle. Couples can earn up to $150 for participating in the study.

Couples will be asked to:

Participate in a videotaped conversation with their partner about physical activity
Complete an activity based on the recorded conversation
Fill out brief questionnaires
Couples will not be engaging in any physical activity during the session

You may be eligible to participate if you are…

An adult with osteoarthritis or joint symptoms, such as pain or stiffness, in your hips or knees
At least 40 years of age
Married to or living with your partner
English speaking
Doing less than 150 minutes of physical activity per week

In addition, both you and your partner must be willing to join the study and attend the study meeting together in Chapel Hill, NC.

For more information or to find out if you are eligible, please call our toll free number at (844) 966-7538. To fill out our online screening survey, go to http://go.unc.edu/PALIS. You can also email us at palis@med.unc.edu.

This study (IRB # 16-2207) is approved by the Office of Human Research Ethics Biomedical Institutional Review Board until August 8, 2018.  This announcement was first approved by the Institutional Review Board on 1/31/17.

This message is sponsored by the Thurston Arthritis Research Center.

subject: Mindful Self-Compassion with Karen Bluth and Laura Prochnow Phillips
author: kmeason
content:
Mindful Self-Compassion with Karen Bluth and Laura Prochnow Phillips

Do you ever feel like you are too hard on yourself? That you have a harsh self-critic inside your head that follows you wherever you go?? Are you a caregiver and feeling burned out?

Then this course is for you!

The UNC Program on Integrative Medicine is excited to be offering the Mindful Self-Compassion (MSC) course this spring. Combining the skills of mindfulness and self-compassion, this course provides a powerful tool for emotional resilience. This course has been offered internationally over the last several years and been met with enormous popularity and success, and here at UNC since last fall. Two of the four trained facilitators in North Carolina are here in Chapel Hill and will be teaching this course (Dr. Karen Bluth and Laura Prochnow Phillips).

This course is open to those both new to mindfulness practice and seasoned practitioners.

Limited space is still available!

Class Dates: Wednesdays, April 4 through May 23, 2018

Instructors: Karen Bluth, Ph.D. & Laura Prochnow Phillips

Location: North Carolina Memorial Hospital, 101 Manning Drive, Chapel Hill, NC 27514 (The Chapel in the UNC Cancer Center)

To register, please click here

Free parking available, if needed

For questions, please call 919-966-8586 or email mindfuless@med.unc.edu

Please visit our website  for additional course information and like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter!

subject: Girls ages 12-14 needed for research study!
author: ehburnet
content:
Girls ages 12-14 needed for research study!

Starting at puberty, girls are over two times more likely to be diagnosed with a mood disorder than boys. The goal of the EVOLVE study is to understand the impact of changing hormones, stress, and brain activity on mood symptoms during the pubertal transition.

We are currently seeking adolescent females between the ages of 12 and 14 who are undergoing a healthy pubertal transition and are not currently taking any prescription medications (including hormonal contraceptives).

Participation includes:

One enrollment and interview session
8 weekly hormone measurements at your home
One lab session involving the assessment of brain activity during a computer task and mental stress test
Study duration is 10 weeks

Your child may receive up to $150 in compensation.

For more information, please visit the EVOLVE study website evolvestudy.web.unc.edu, or contact Dr. Elizabeth Andersen at (919) 904-4876.

Click here to check eligibility: UNC EVOLVE Study


This research study was approved by the UNC Biomedical IRB (#17-2173). This email text was approved by the IRB on 03/05/2018.

subject: Cleaning out offices? Request your temporary recycling bin today!
author: willconn
content:
Moving offices or doing a file purge? Please reserve temporary bins for recyclables by filling out an OWRR service request or calling 919-962-4699.

OWRR can deliver as many bins as needed, and these bins can accommodate higher-than-normal volumes of recyclables without filling up the permanent recycling bins too quickly. Temporary bins can be emptied multiple times before they are taken away. Please contact us at least 48 hours before you will need the bins delivered.

Please follow the regular recycling guidelines for mixed paper. By North Carolina Statute, all University records belong to the public, even if they are confidential. However, not all documents must be kept in perpetuity. Please follow the University Archives and Records Management Services (UARMS) Record Retention Schedule and Guidelines when purging files.

If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to contact OWRR at 919.962.1442, email recycling@facilities.unc.edu or visit go.unc.edu/officecleanout.

subject: March Carolina Conversation
author: adrigibi
content:
Dear Carolina Community:

Please join us for the March Carolina Conversation, titled “Navigating Unlawful Harassment and Uncomfortable Situations in the Workplace.” The event will be held on Wednesday, Mar. 21, from 4 – 5:30 p.m. at the Student Union’s Aquarium Lounge.

This session will provide an inclusive and interactive dialogue about sexual harassment in the workplace. We will explore types of conduct that could be considered harassment and how to navigate and address potential harassment. We will also discuss the power dynamics that often allow harassing behavior to escalate and/or persist, as well as steps that can be taken to foster an environment in which harassment is not tolerated. Audience participation will be strongly encouraged.

“Navigating Unlawful Harassment and Uncomfortable Situations in the Workplace” will be presented by Brandon Washington, director of the Equal Opportunity and Compliance Office, and Adrienne Allison, director of Title IX Compliance.

All faculty, staff and students are encouraged to participate in this critical discussion. Details are provided in the linked flyer.

Upcoming 2018 Carolina Conversations discussion topics will include:

April: “What Does It Mean to be a Public University?”

TBD: “Talking About UNC History”

Dates for these monthly sessions will be announced soon. For more information about Carolina Conversations, please visit go.unc.edu/carolinaconversations.

Sincerely yours,

 

Felicia A. Washington
Vice Chancellor for Workforce Strategy, Equity and Engagement


G. Rumay Alexander
Associate Vice Chancellor for Diversity and Inclusion and Chief Diversity Officer

subject: Participants wanted for baseball pitching study
author: haydeng
content:
Hello, my name is Brett Pexa and I am a doctoral student in the Human Movement Science Curriculum at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. The research team I am working with consists of Dr. Eric Ryan, Dr. Joe Myers, Dr. Tony Hackney, and Dr. David Berkoff. We are reaching out to you in hopes that you can participate in a research study entitled “Non-invasive Assessment of Overuse Injury Mechanisms in the Adolescent Athlete.”

 

We are looking for healthy male baseball players between the ages of 13 – 18. To qualify for this study, pitcher must be or have been your primary or secondary position. You must not be injured, or have pain or discomfort that has limited your baseball participation for the last 3 months. You can have no previous shoulder or elbow surgery in the past year, and must be able to pitch the age recommended amount of pitches based on USA Baseball’s Pitch Smart guidelines. The purpose of this research study is to determine if ultrasound imaging of the infraspinatus, a shoulder muscle, can show how muscles recover following a bout of baseball pitching.

 

As a participant, you will be required to sign an informed consent document stating you understand all of the procedures and rights as a research subject, and to fill out questionnaires regarding your baseball participation, injuries, and training. The study includes 4 testing visits over the course of 6 days. Your first visit will involve filling out the paperwork and performing the baseline assessment which will consist of a finger stick blood draw, shoulder range of motion and strength measures, and an ultrasound image of your infraspinatus, a muscle critical to baseball pitching. These images are taken with an ultrasound machine. Diagnostic ultrasound creates an image using sound waves, so no radiation or damaging imaging will be used with this study.

 

Following the baseline testing, you will immediately pitch an age prescribed amount of pitches based on USA Baseball’s Pitch Smart guidelines. Once the pitch count is reached, the same testing procedures will be performed again.  You will be asked to return on day 1, day 3, and day 5 following your bout of pitching, where the exact same assessments will be performed.   

 

Participants can receive up to $100 dollars in compensation. If you are interested or have questions, please contact Brett Pexa by phone or email.

 

Brett Pexa

919-843-2014

pexa@live.unc.edu

 

IRB # 16-2714

Biomedical

Approved: 9/14/17

subject: Recruitment for  Muscle Quality and Aging Study
author: haydeng
content:
Hello,

    My name is Hayden Giuliani and I am a research coordinator in the Department of Exercise and Sport Science at UNC.  I am conducting a study that is examining how the quality of your muscles influences how your muscles change size when they contract and how this may influence how strong you are and how fast you walk.  For this study, we are looking for adult males between the ages of 65-74 years to complete two visits at the Neuromuscular Research Laboratory in the Department of Exercise and Sport Science that will last approximately two hours (visit 1) and 40 minutes (visit 2). To qualify, you must have a BMI of 30 or above (formula and link below) and do not exercise for more than 3 hours per week. 

    You will perform submaximal and maximal leg extension exercises of your thigh muscles with sensors taped to your muscles, and size and quality of your thigh muscles will be measured using ultrasonography while you are at rest, and during the strength assessments. For completing both visits associated with this study, you will receive $60 and free health information from the testing.  Please let me know if you have any questions and if you are interested in participating in our study. You can email me at haydeng@live.unc.edu or call me at 919-843-2014.

 

BMI = Weight (lb) ÷ Height (in) ÷ Height (in) × 703

https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/educational/lose_wt/BMI/bmicalc.htm  

 

 

Thank you for your time and I look forward to hearing from you!

 

Hayden Giuliani, MA, ATC, CSCS

Research Coordinator

Department of Exercise and Sport Science

UNC Chapel Hill

 

IRB #16-1523

Biomedical

Approved: 10/10/2017

author: ecline
content:
Greetings!

Ever visited a UNC library? If you’re an undergrad, this survey is for you!

I am a graduate student in the School of Information and Library Science, currently researching user perceptions of libraries. My survey is part of a research study (#17-3170, reviewed by the UNC IRB on 2/12/18), the purpose of which is to better understand the perceptions undergraduates have of the libraries here on campus. Participation in this survey is entirely voluntary, and you may decide to stop taking the survey at any time.

Participants will be entered in a drawing to win one of three $25 Amazon gift cards. Answers are anonymous, and no identifying information will be collected, save an email address at the end if you would like to be entered in the gift card drawing. However, email addresses will not be attached to other response data in any way, and they will not be saved after the drawing is finished.

Undergraduate students at UNC

We are recruiting teens age 14-17 to participate in a research study to test two different courses for lowering stress and improving health and wellbeing in teens. subject: 2-Step Verification Required for Heelmail on March 21
author: hashk
content:
Beginning on Wednesday, March 21, students will be required to use 2-Step Verification to access Office 365 -- this includes Heelmail.

Enroll now for 2-Step for Heelmail
Don't wait until March 21 -- you can opt-in and begin using 2-Step for Office 365 now! It's easy to enroll:

Visit onyen.unc.edu and click on "2-Step Verification for Office365."
Follow the quick on-screen prompts to turn on 2-Step.
Visit office.unc.edu to complete 2-Step enrollment. Note: you will need your mobile device to complete this step.
Duo and Microsoft: Two ways to 2-Step
For Office 365/Heelmail, the University uses the built-in Microsoft tool for 2-Step Verification. For all other uses, such as student financials in ConnectCarolina, the University uses Duo Security. Each of the two platforms has its own separate registration process. You need to complete the steps above to enroll in 2-Step for Office 365, even if you have already registered for Duo.

Having more than one way to verify your identity might seem confusing at first, but these two industry-standard tools are the most effective ways to protect your accounts. To learn more about 2-Step at UNC, visit its.unc.edu/2-step.

Need help? 
If you need help with the registration process, use the documentation available at: help.unc.edu/help/mfa/. You can also live chat with the ITS Service Desk, call 919-962-HELP or visit us in person for assistance.

Please note that any staff members with an active student affiliation will also be subject to this 2-Step requirement.

subject: Calling i2b2 users for a Case Study
author: wanchen6
content:
Dear all,

My name is Wanchen Zhao, a research assistant at UNC Center for Health Equity Research and a second-year graduate student in Information Science at The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. As a part of the research project for my master’s paper, I am conducting a case study for a newly designed visual query system to see how users interact with the system to refine the initial query in order to select a satisfactory cohort for a given research and we will use the data collected to improve our interface.

You are eligible to participate in the study if:

you are at least 21 years of age,
you are either in the medical related research area or tech related research area,
you must have undergone i2b2 training and used the i2b2 interface.
This study is set to last between 45 to 60 minutes, where you will perform a given set of tasks on a visual query system and undergo a semi-structured interview to discuss your experience. While there is no compensation provided for the successful completion of the study, your time and effort can contribute directly towards shaping the newly designed visual query interface, helping us make a potential contribution to the i2b2 consortium. 

If you are interested in learning more about this study or signing up to participate, please respond to this email at wanchen6@live.unc.edu.

Thank you for your time and consideration. We look forward to hearing from you.

Study approved by the UNC IRB on 2.26, 2018 (Study # 18-0266, Non-Biomedical)

 

Sincerely,

Wanchen Zhao
Master of Information Science candidate 2018
School of Information and Library Science
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

wanchen6@live.unc.edu

 

Faculty advisor: David Gotz, PhD
School of Information and Library Science
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

subject: Sexual Harassment Workshop
author: davidgu
content:
Dear Faculty, 

The Carolina Seminar Series, The Carolina Women's Center and WISDOM (Women in Science Deserve Opportunities and Mentoring) present a 2 Part Series on Sexual Harassment in Academia. 

For Part 1, a webinar, Dr. Karen Kelsky will share what she has learned from conducting the Sexual Harassment in the Academy Survey, including thoughts on the range and scope of sexual harassment in the academic setting, patterns of predation, options for survivors, recommendations to institutions, and particular vulnerabilities of women of color and of queer and transgender women. There will be a 30 min Q&A at the end. This is a brown bag lunch event. 

Part 2 will be a workshop geared towards faculty of all genders and ranks. Through interactive discussion and activities led by campus and community facilitators, the workshop will address the continuum of harassment, how bystanders can intervene effectively, and UNC resources and reporting options around sexual discrimination and harassment. Lunch will be provided. 

The webinar will be April 18th from 12:00pm-1:30pm and the workshop will be April 24th from 12:00pm-4:00pm. Both sessions will be located in the Hitchcock Room in the Sonja Haynes Stone Center. To RSVP for one or both sessions email Grace David at grace_david@med.unc.edu. Space is limited. 

We hope to see you there!

subject: Share Feedback About the LFIT Program at UNC
author: jtblount
content:
Share Feedback About the LFIT Program at UNC!
This survey is being conducted by members of Embody Carolina and the Undergraduate Executive Branch of Student Government in collaboration with the professionals at the UNC Center of Excellence for Eating Disorders to gather student feedback on the Lifetime Fitness curriculum at UNC for a campus project.

The survey was determined to be exempt from needing IRB approval as it falls under the category of exempt research. Some questions in this survey ask about eating disorders and disordered eating behaviors and could be triggering. If you become uncomfortable during the survey, you are welcome to end at any time. The survey is anonymous and you will not be contacted about your responses.

The survey should take around 10 minutes to answer. If you complete the survey, you can enter to win a prize, including an Amazon Echo product, UNC apparel, Beats headphones, a bluetooth speaker, or a copy of Redemption by Adam Lucas. Each prize has a value between $28 and $150. Should you wish to enter the drawing, your email will not be connected to your survey responses.

The survey can be found at this link. Responses should be submitted by March 9, 2018 at 11:59 pm. 

If you have any questions about the survey or our project, please reach out to the Executive Branch at executivebranch@unc.edu and your message will be forwarded to the necessary party.

Further, if you are concerned about your or a friend’s relationship with food or exercise, resources are available at UNC Campus Health Services, the UNC Center of Excellence for Eating Disorders, and online at the National Eating Disorders Association website.

subject: Paid Research Opportunity for Runners
author: fjgood
content:
The UNC Neuromuscular Research Lab is conducting a research study on running-related injuries. We are recruiting healthy, physically active volunteers for participation in this study.

If you decide to participate, you will be asked to report to the Neuromuscular Research Lab for 1 testing session and the Applied Biomechanics Lab for 1 testing session.  Each session will last approximately 1 hour. 

During the Neuromuscular Lab testing session you will be asked to complete maximal strength and musculotendinous stiffness assessments of your knee and ankle. During the Applied Biomechanics testing session, you will be asked to complete single leg hopping at 3 different frequencies for 30 seconds and run for 2 minutes at a comfortable speed on a treadmill while lower extremity biomechanics will be collected.

There are some risks associated with participating in this research study, but they are not greater than the risks associate with normal physical activity/exercise.

Subjects will be required to meet the following inclusion criteria:
Age 18-40 years
No injury to either leg in the past 6 months
No history of surgery to either leg
Not currently pregnant
Run a minimum of 15 miles/week for the 3 previous months
No history of chronic neurological condition
You will receive $25 for study completion.

If you meet the criteria above and are interested in participating, or if you would like more information about the study, please contact FJ Goodwin via email at fjgoodwin@unc.edu

Approved Biomedical IRB Information:
Title: "Neuromechanical contributions to lower extremity stiffness during hopping and running in healthy runners"
IRB Number: 17-0098
Approval Date: 10/16/2017

subject: 3/10: FREE "Faith in our Lives" conversation with UNC's own Dr. Bart Ehrman
author: rosalie
content:
Faith in Our Lives: Why We Follow




Join us at a FREE panel discussion in the Kenan Theatre between two national luminaries in the world of religious scholars: 

• Dr. Robert Franklin, former President of Morehouse College and Director of the Religion Program at The Chautauqua Institution, alongside 
• Dr. Bart Ehrman, national best-selling author and Religious Studies professor at UNC-Chapel Hill. 

Dr. Franklin and Dr. Ehrman will engage with audiences and exlore how faith and belief serve us both personally and collectively, as well as what may be risk when doctrine plays too little or too large a role in our lives. 

Saturday, March 10

4:00pm-5:30pm

Joan H. Gillings Center for Dramatic Art

For more info and to share the event on Facebook, Click Here

 



Also, LAST CHANCE! Enrich the conversation and don't miss out on PlayMakers Repertory Company's two rotating shows on Faith & Following taking place before and after the talk. The Christians and Tartuffe share the stage until March 11. 

Get your tickets at http://playmakersrep.org/rep-2018

The Center for Functional GI and Motility Disorders is in the process of validating a symptom diary that will be used in a future research study. We are recruiting men and women between the ages of 45 – 80 who do not have fecal incontinence. Participation in this research study involves filling out a paper daily diary for four weeks and answering questionnaires before and after the research study. No intervention is involved in this research study.

You can earn up to $100 for participation in this research study.

For more information about this research study, please contact Stefanie Twist at sjeremia@med.unc.edu or 919-843-6961

subject: Project Uplift & Uplift PLUS
author: adrigibi
content:
Dear Faculty and Staff,

Each summer, the University Office for Diversity and Inclusion (D&I) sponsors PROJECT UPLIFT and UPLIFT PLUS. Project Uplift is an experiential weekend program for academically gifted rising high school seniors from underrepresented populations, held during Summer Session I.  Uplift PLUS is a five-week program during Carolina’s Summer Session II, in which participants live on campus, attend SAT/ACT coaching sessions, and take English 100 – a 3 credit hour course.

These programs provide an opportunity for members of the campus community to get involved and contribute to the rich diversity of Carolina’s applicant pool.  We hope that your unit/school/division will consider getting involved in one or more of the following ways:

PROJECT UPLIFT (Summer Session I):

Provide faculty support for a mock classroom – 1 hour
This session will expose students to the general UNC academic experience.
Participate in the resource/college fair – 1.25 hours
This fair will expose students to campus departments and colleges from across the state.
Lead an experiential learning session – 1.5 hours (lab, simulation, group project)
This session will offer hands-on learning opportunities for participants.

You can participate in multiple sessions. To find detailed information about each session, to see examples of past sessions, and to sign up, please click here. 


UPLIFT PLUS (Summer Session II):

Experiential Learning Session – 1.5 hours (lab, simulation, group project)
This session will offer the 35 Uplift PLUS participants an in-depth, hands-on, learning opportunity with the goal of exposing participants to a variety of academic subject areas.
These sessions should be more detailed and differentiated than Project Uplift sessions

You can register for multiple sessions that build upon each other. To find detailed information about each session, to see examples of past sessions, and to sign up, please click here. 


Please sign up no later than Friday, April 20. 

Thank you for your continued support of Diversity & Inclusion. Please contact AC Locklear at aclockear@unc.edu if you have questions.

Sincerely,

 

Dr. G. Rumay Alexander
Associate Vice Chancellor, Diversity and Inclusion/Chief Diversity Officer

subject: DEADLINE SOON: $10,000 GRANT FOR FACULTY SCHOLARS
author: clarec
content:
The Carolina Women's Center announces that it is now accepting applications for the 2018-2019 Faculty Scholars Program. The program awards three separate grants of $10,000 each to support scholarly or creative research consistent with the priorities of the Carolina Women’s Center. Thus, projects may focus on a wide range of questions. They could explore gendered identities and experiences, including but not limited to femininities, masculinities, and gender non-conforming identities and experiences; intersectional analyses of gender; difference and diversity within and between categories; and gender equity and gender equality. Projects might also bring a gendered analysis to bear on topics seemingly not connected to gender. We welcome projects from all disciplines and methodologies.

Proposals are welcome from all full-time faculty (fixed-term, tenured, or tenure-track) and from part-time faculty with at least a .5FTE appointment, regardless of gender identity or expression. Applicants should have a minimum of three years of service by the start of the grant in any department, center, or school of the University. Applicants must have an endorsement from their chair, director, or dean that describes how the project will contribute to the applicant’s career development.

Applications are due Friday, March 23 by 5pm. More information and application materials are available from the CWC's website, and Clare Counihan, the program coordinator for faculty and staff, can answer questions.

Please share widely with colleagues and departments.

subject: Hearing research study
author: hlang
content:
Hearing Research Study

We are currently recruiting listeners for a hearing research study.

You may be eligible to participate in this research study if:

- you are between the ages of 19–50 years old

- you have normal hearing

- you have no history of ear problems

The purpose of this research study is to obtain a better understanding of hearing. 

Participants will sit in a soundproof room and listen to sounds presented over headphones. The research study will take approximately 2–5 sessions of one hour each and takes place in Marsico Hall. You will be compensated for your time at a rate of $15/hour.

If you are interested in participating in this research study please contact us at HearingLab@med.unc.edu


This study has been approved by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill's Biomedical Institutional Review Board: Study #86-0059. The title for this IRB study is "Development and Plasticity in Normal and Impaired Ears." The most recent approved IRB modification date is 3/1/2018.

subject: Calling i2b2 users for a Case Study
author: wanchen6
content:
Dear all,

My name is Wanchen Zhao, a research assistant at UNC Center for Health Equity Research and a second-year graduate student in Information Science at The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. As a part of the research project for my master’s paper, I am conducting a case study for a newly designed visual query system to see how users interact with the system to refine the initial query in order to select a satisfactory cohort for a given research and we will use the data collected to improve our interface.

You are eligible to participate in the study if:

you are at least 21 years of age,
you are either in the medical related research area or tech related research area,
you must have undergone i2b2 training and used the i2b2 interface.
This study is set to last between 45 to 60 minutes, where you will perform a given set of tasks on a visual query system and undergo a semi-structured interview to discuss your experience. While there is no compensation provided for the successful completion of the study, your time and effort can contribute directly towards shaping the newly designed visual query interface, helping us make a potential contribution to the i2b2 consortium. 

If you are interested in learning more about this study or signing up to participate, please respond to this email at wanchen6@live.unc.edu.

Thank you for your time and consideration. We look forward to hearing from you.

Study approved by the UNC IRB on 2.26, 2018 (Study # 18-0266, Non-Biomedical)

 

Sincerely,

Wanchen Zhao

School of Information and Library Science
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

subject: Funding Support
author: rrblanch
content:
The Ackland Art Museum offers funding to support either a new course or revisions to an existing course that directly engages with the Museum's collection. The Ackland's objective in offering these funds is to further integrate the practice of teaching with works of art into the academic curriculum of the University. Support for these grants comes from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

The maximum grant available is $5,000. Tenured or tenure-track faculty, fixed term faculty, or lecturers in any discipline may apply. The Ackland's expectation is that the course developed with these funds will be taught three or more times. The course should be taught for the first time during or before the 2019-2020 academic year, and at least twice more within the next five years.

Applicants should submit:

1.  A brief description of the course's objectives, its relationship to the applicant's teaching and research interests, the course's significance for the curriculum, and the type of course (e.g. first year seminar, honors seminar, undergraduate lecture course, graduate course, etc.). The description should include a discussion of the role that works of art will play in the course and the relevant objects or area(s) of the Ackland's collection. 

2.  Proposed budget and planning timeline. Budget may include expenses such as: instructor salary; graduate student assistance; supplies; course materials; and research related expenses.

3.  Letter of support from the applicant's department chair. 

4.  2-3 page CV.

 

Applications are due April 2, 2018.

Recipient will be notified April 30, 2018.

Funds will be available after July 1, 2018.

Submit applications to either:

Ackland Art Museum

Academic Programs: Course Development/Course Enhancement Grants

CB#3400

OR

acklandlearn@unc.edu

subject: Administrative Review of Winston Crisp, Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs
author: ddd3
content:
To:        Members of the UNC-Chapel Hill Faculty, Staff and Students

From:    Dean Fouad Abd-El-Khalick, Review Committee Chair

Date:     March 1, 2018

Re:        Administrative Review of Winston Crisp, Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs

On behalf of the committee appointed to review the performance of Winston Crisp, Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs at UNC-Chapel Hill, I invite your participation in the review process. The other committee members are Vin Steponaitis (Secretary of the Faculty), Elizabeth Adkins (Student Body President), Madelyne Percy (GPSF President), Christopher Faison (Men of Color Initiative, College of Arts and Sciences), Kara Simmons (Office of University Counsel), Rumay Alexander (Associate Vice Chancellor, Diversity / Multicultural Affairs), Niklaus Steiner(Center for Global Initiatives), Michelle Brown (Athletics / Provost Office), Lee May (Advising, College of Arts and Sciences), and Shayna Hill (Chair, Employee Forum).

As required by University regulations, the Chancellor has requested a review of Winston Crisp, Vice Chancellor for Students Affairs, and assess his ability to work effectively with the many relevant constituencies – students, faculty, staff, alumni, and other administrative leaders on our campus and in the UNC system.

We encourage you to contribute to this review in the following different ways:

The committee has scheduled two open sessions to receive comments. These times are:
Wednesday March 14th – 3:00-5:00 – 311-A South Building
Wednesday March 21st – 9:00-11:00 – 205 South Building

 If you wish to meet with the committee, please contact Debbie Deese in the Office of the Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost (debbie_deese@unc.edu or 962-7882), and she will schedule a specific time (usually about 10-15 minutes) within that time period. Note that while all comments during these sessions will be kept strictly confidential, a master list of attendees will be kept as part of Mr. Crisp’s personnel file. Requests must be made before March 9th.

 

You may provide written comments to the chair or other committee members. The review committee will treat your comments as strictly confidential. By law, all written communication – whether on paper or by email – becomes a confidential part of Mr. Crisp’s personnel file. As such, comments are open to examination by him. University regulations prohibit consideration of anonymous letters in the review process. All written comments should be sent to: Fouad Abd-El-Khalick, c/o Debbie Deese, 218 South Building, CB # 8000 or by emailing debbie_deese@unc.edu


 

You may telephone or meet privately in person with committee members. Oral communications (by telephone or in person) and the committee's notes generated from these conversations do not become part of Mr. Crisp’s personnel file but may be reflected in the committee’s report without identifiers.

 

The deadline for submitting comments regarding Mr. Crisp’s performance to the committee is April 2, 2018.

subject: Research study for individuals with mild asthma and allergies.
author: bgbradfo
content:
IRB #15-1938:  Effect of gamma tocopherol enriched supplementation on response to inhaled Ozone during exercise 


 

SUBJECT:  INFORMATIONAL: Research study for individuals with mild asthma and allergies.

The purpose of this study is to help determine if pretreatment with Vitamin E (active supplement) will affect the lung response to inhaled ozone while walking on a treadmill in individuals with mild asthma and allergies.  Ozone is a common form of air pollution.  Vitamin E is naturally available in certain foods, and as a nutritional supplement.

It is known that asthmatics can have decreased levels of Vitamin E in the fluid in their lungs and this deficiency has been linked to increased severity of asthma attacks.  This suggests that Vitamin E supplementation may improve acute and chronic asthma.

A number of animal, cell culture and epidemiological studies support the idea that supplementation is useful in allergic airway disease. However, despite these studies and widespread public and scientific enthusiasm regarding use of such agents in asthmatics, there are little human data to support or refute the use of supplements for either acute or chronic allergic airway disease.

This research study is considered a cross-over study, which means that you will take the Vitamin E active supplement for one session, and then take placebo for another session. 

 

Subjects must be otherwise healthy but have mild asthma and allergies. Pregnant or nursing females are excluded. Individuals who are unable to exercise, have had a recent respiratory infection, or have more than 2 asthma exacerbations per week will also be excluded. Study participation will include 10 visits over 9 weeks. There is an initial screening visit which is separate from the study visits.

 

Contact

·       (919) 966-2879 or email  bgb10@unc.edu

·        submit a questionnaire at  www.med.unc.edu/cemalb

Requirements

·       You must be between 18 and 45.

·       You must be a healthy person with allergies and mild asthma.

·       Able to walk briskly on a treadmill.

Women who are pregnant, trying to become pregnant, or nursing a baby cannot participate.

Time Commitment

·       A one-time visit for our Screening Protocol (IRB #98-0799)
·       Research study participation will consist of 7 visits over a period of 5 – 16 weeks (depending on scheduling needs).
Compensation

·          Screening Protocol visit $75.00

·          Complete 7 study visits $1,115.00

 

             Approved 8/30/2017 by the Biomedical Institutional Review Board.  IRB # 15-1938

 

This e-mail is sponsored by the UNC Center for Environmental Medicine, Asthma and Lung Biology

subject: Adult Peanut Allergy Study
author: dhamilto
content:
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill’s Food Allergy Initiative is conducting an industry sponsored phase one clinical trial for peanut allergy. The purpose of this study is to find out if an investigational vaccine for peanut allergy is safe and tolerable for people suffering from peanut allergy. The product being investigated is a vaccine which is injected under the skin in your arm or in your upper arm muscle. The drug being used for this study is ASP0892 (ARA-LAMP_vax), and is not yet approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA).
You may be eligible for this study if you:
• Are between 18 and 55 years of age
• Have a diagnosed peanut allergy
You should not participate in this study if you:
• Have any severe uncontrolled disease (lung, endocrine, renal, cardiac, or immune) or disease which prevents you from using epinephrine.
• Are pregnant or nursing or thinking of becoming pregnant.
• Are currently receiving immunotherapy treatment
• Have asthma which is not well controlled
• Have a mental condition such as schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, major depressive disorder or take medication for depression.
Other criteria will be determined over the phone with a study coordinator and at the first clinic visit.
The study participation will require you to attend our UNC clinic for 13 visits over a period of 8 to 9 months. Most visits will last approximately 4 hours but some visits will take as long as 6 to 8 hours. Study participants will be paid up to $1300 to compensate for time needed for completion of all study activities. A parking voucher will be given to cover the cost of parking at each visit.
It is important to know that this letter is not telling you to join this study. Your participation is voluntary. If you would like to learn more about this study, please contact the study coordinator, Deanna Hamilton, RN at 919-962-4405 or dhamilto@email.unc.edu.
This research study has been approved by the Biomedical UNC-CH IRB: Study #16-1928 (approved 8/26/17)

subject: Changes to EHRA Faculty Salary Increase Request Processes
author: kwbryant
content:
To:          Deans, Directors, and Department Heads
               School/Division HR Officers and Secondary Contacts 

From:     Ann Lemmon, Assistant Provost for Academic Personnel

cc:          Robert A Blouin, PharmD, Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost
               Ron Strauss, DMD, PhD, Executive Vice Provost and Chief International Officer  

The Academic Personnel Office (APO) is updating the faculty salary increase request process to include increases that are below the current delegated thresholds (5% when the base salary is/will be at or above $100,000, and below 20% when the base is below $100,000), effective 3-1-2018.  This change is being implemented to make the faculty salary increase process consistent with University processes, and to address an increased error/re-processing rate.

Faculty salary increases that are below the thresholds will need to be submitted, in Excel format, to APO (apo@unc.edu) in the same manner as those increase requests that are above threshold. 

Requested increases will be reviewed by Laurie Boudler, HR Consultant, and approved on a weekly basis by Assistant Provost for Academic Personnel, Ann Lemmon.
Once reviewed and approved, APO will email an approval notification with the final Faculty Salary Increase Request form attached, indicating that the increase can be entered into ConnectCarolina by your HR office.
A one-month retroactive effective date for these salary increases will be fine.
Special circumstances should be discussed with APO at the time of submittal, and a determination will be made upon review.
A separate memo with detailed information on the revised process will be sent to all School/Division HR Officers.

subject: Research Study
author: kseabolt
content:
Researchers Perceptions Regarding Institutional Review Boards: A Helping Hand or Putting Up Roadblocks?

Principal Investigator: Kim Boggess, MD

Researchers at the Office of Human Research Ethics at the University of North Carolina aim to study the current perceptions researchers have of Institutional Review Boards (IRBs) in the United States.  You must be 18 years old or older and have conducted human subjects research in order to participate in this study.  Participation in this research study involves a one-time demographic and study questionnaire which should take approximately 15 minutes total to complete.  Survey results will be completely anonymous to protect your identity.  We will not be able to link your responses to you.  Only the research team will receive your anonymous responses.  You may skip any questions that you do not feel comfortable answering.  Your participation is completely voluntary. 

If you agree to participate in the study, please click on the link below to begin the survey:

 

https://unc.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_4Z6LfS4Wy2SOXnn

 

If you have any questions about this study, please contact Shahila Sriskanda, MS, CIP (shahila@email.unc.edu) or Kathy Seabolt, CIM, CIC, CIP (kseabolt@email.unc.edu).  If you have any questions or concerns about your rights as a subject in this study, contact the UNC Office of Human Research Ethics at 919-966-3113.

subject: Onset 9 Clinical Trial
author: dezube
content:
ONSET 9 (Biomedical UNC IRB # 17-1083) is recruiting now. The primary objective of this study is to assess the efficacy and safety of Novolog compared to Faster-acting Novolog (FIASP). It is an eight month study. The study will provide Degludec (basal insulin), blood glucose meter and strips.  Novolog or Faster-Acting Novolog (meal time insulin) will be provided at randomization. There is also a nominal payment for office and phone visits.

The basic inclusion criteria is:
Type 2 Diabetes for 10 years 
Treated with basal and bolus insulin for 1 year with or without Metformin

Age 18 and above
A1c 7.0-10.0%

Biomedical UNC IRB approval # 17-1083 approval 9/19/2017

If interested please contact:

Milana Dezube, BSN, RN

Nurse Research Coordinator

Diabetes Care Center

University of North Carolina

Office: (984)974-3014

Email: milana_dezube@med.unc.edu

subject: DEADLINE EXTENDED! Fulfill gen eds, electives, and earn up to 15 Honors credits studying abroad!
author: madelina
content:
HONORS GLOBAL OPPORTUNITIES: SUMMER + FALL 2018
What are YOU doing this summer and fall?

Any UNC student with at least second-year status and a 3.0 GPA can study abroad with Honors Carolina and earn Honors credits. Financial aid can be applied, and need-based scholarships are available.



SUMMER 2018 | APPLICATION DEADLINE: MARCH 4, 2018

Shakespeare through Performance in London + Oxford
Explore Shakespeare through performance and literature. Attend performances each week, and live in the shadow of the British Museum, National Gallery, Bodelian Library, and Tolkein's meeting room. Apply here!
Faculty Director: Chris Armitage



Time, Tides, and Measurement of the Cosmos in London
Study Aristotle, Copernicus, Galileo and other scholars who expanded the ancient field of astronomy. Explore the birthplace of modern mechanics and the trove of historical devices at the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich. Apply here!
Faculty Director: Christopher Clemens



Jewish Life and the Holocaust in Poland 

Visit the heartland of pre-war Jewish life and the sites where the events of the Holocaust took place. Deconstruct competing narratives built in different postwar periods to understand how the region's historical significance affects contemporary politics & national identities. Apply here!
Faculty Director: Karen Auerbach



Sustainability and Storytelling in Germany, Spain, and Denmark
Visit the most climate-friendly cities in the world to study the political, social, and economic factors that are facilitating the transition from fossil fuels to renewable energy. Explore how these countries have emerged as world leaders in transitioning away from fossil fuels. Apply here!
Faculty Directors: David Salvesen, Tom Linden

 

FALL 2018 | APPLICATION DEADLINE: MARCH 4, 2018

Honors Semester in London

Attend seminars within the shadow of the British Museum, conduct research at the British Library, and learn from professors who make London their home. Personalized internship opportunities are available in fields ranging from impact investing to healthcare and grassroots service organizations. Apply here!
Faculty Director: John Rubin

Honors Semester in Cape Town
Explore a dynamic society in transition and immerse yourself into the living history of South Africa by working directly with institutions that are helping to create a democratic civil society. Personalized internship opportunities are available, including ones at the Red Cross Children's Hospital and local environmental agencies. Apply here!
Faculty Director: Silvia Tomášková

**We have been watching the development of the water crisis in Cape Town for over a year. As recommended by partners in Cape Town and the government of the Western Cape, we continue to think running the program will benefit our students and long-standing partners there. We feel it is important to continue with the program; our withdrawal would deepen a crisis situation should people stay away rather than visit, learn, and participate as active, responsible community members learning how to solve global issues.



FELLOWSHIPS | APPLICATION DEADLINE: MARCH 1, 2018

Robinson Honors Fellowship

Delve deeply into the history and culture of Europe and the Mediterranean from 520 BCE to 1920. Pursue projects that explore YOUR interest in art, literature, music, history, politics, economics, philosophy, and religion. Note that projects can be experiential or research-oriented. Fellowship provides up to $6,000 to support domestic or international learning experiences. Find out more here!

Questions? Contact: honorsburch@unc.edu
Schedule an appointment to discuss an Honors Global program here!

subject: Couples Counseling ACCESS Program
author: pentel
content:
Are you interested in learning skills to improve/strengthen your relationship?

Do you disagree on topics related to being in a same-sex relationship (e.g., who to come out to or how to find a supportive social network?)

I specialize in working with couples and am conducting a small treatment research study of a no-cost couple therapy program. To be eligible for this pilot study, you and your partner must meet the following criteria:

Living together more than 6 months
Age 21 or older
Identify as cisgender (biological/birth sex aligns with gender identity)
Identify as female
Have a certain level of distress in your relationship, including stress related to living in a heteronormative society (this will be assessed on the phone screen)
While we would hope for this program to be available to all couples, for the purpose of this initial pilot study we can only recruit a small sample of 12 couples. We hope to expand this program in the future. If you are not eligible for ACCESS, we can provide referrals to other appropriate couples counseling resources.

Questions? Interested in setting up an initial phone screening call to determine eligibility? Contact Kim (she/her) at ACCESSprogram@unc.edu or check out our website at: www.ACCESSprogram.web.unc.edu. All inquiries are confidential.

Study Title: ACCESS: Affirming Couple Counseling to Engage Same-Sex partners. UNC-CH IRB #: 17-2482, Nonbiomedical. Date Approved: October 17, 2017.

subject: Sota-Insulin
author: dezube
content:
The SOTA-Insulin trial (IRB # 17-2542) is recruiting now. The primary objective of this study is to assess the efficacy and safety of Sotagliflozin, a SGLT2 agent in patients with Type 2 diabetes treated with basal insulin and 0-2 oral diabetes agents compared to placebo.  It is a year long study and will provide Lantus, blood glucose meter and strips and a nominal payment for office and phone visits.

The basic inclusion criteria is:

Type 2 Diabetes treated with basal insulin (Lantus, Levemir, Novolin-N, Humulin-N, Degludec)
0-2 oral medications for treatment of diabetes excluding SGLT2 compounds, or GLP-1 agonists
Age 18 and above
A1c 7.5-<11.0%

UNC IRB approval # 17-2542 approval 2/1/18

If interested please contact:

Milana Dezube, BSN, RN

Nurse Research Coordinator

Diabetes Care Center

University of North Carolina

Office: (984)974-3014

Email: milana_dezube@med.unc.edu

subject: CITY Clinical Trial
author: dezube
content:
CITY (Continuous Glucose Monitoring, CGM in Young Adults, IRB # 17-2306)  is recruiting now. The primary objective of this study is to assess the efficacy and safety of CGM compared with blood glucose monitoring in adolescents and young adults with type 1 diabetes (T1D). We are recruiting 18 to 24 year olds at our site. It is a year long using the Dexcom G5. If you complete the trial, you get to keep the Dexcom G5 system. We supply all CGM supplies during the trial.

The basic inclusion criteria is:

T1D diagnosis defined as diagnosis under 10yo OR a history of positive T1D related antibodies
Age between 18-24 years old
Cannot have been on a CGM currently or within the last three months
A1c 7.5-11.0%
Multiple Daily Injection or Pump for the last three months

UNC IRB# 17-2306 approved 11/28/17

 

Please contact: 

Alex Kass, BSN, RN

Nurse Research Coordinator

Diabetes Care Center

University of North Carolina

Office: (984)974-3009
