subject: Going Viral Symposium: Impact and Implications of the 1918 Influenza Pandemic
author: lcwarren
content:
Dear Colleagues,

We are delighted to announce and invite you to attend Going Viral: Impact and Implications of the 1918 Influenza Pandemic, a national, interdisciplinary symposium April 4 – 6, in Chapel Hill, to mark the 100th anniversary of the 1918 influenza pandemic that killed ~50 million people worldwide. Among more than 20 featured speakers are Howard Markel (Univ. of Michigan), acclaimed social and cultural historian of medicine and public health, and Ralph Baric (UNC-Chapel Hill), global expert in virology and immunology. Gina Kolata, New York Times science and medicine reporter, will deliver the keynote lecture  based on her best-selling book, Flu: The Story of the Great Influenza Pandemic of 1918 and the Search for the Virus that Caused It.

Professionals, practitioners, researchers, students and others from many fields will be energized by this timely symposium offering perspectives from the vantage points of medicine, health, social sciences and the humanities. Expert speakers from epidemiology, virology, communications, literature, history, ethics, policy and more will look backward and forward to understand the 1918 global influenza pandemic and prevent one with similar or greater virulence in the future. We aim to place the pandemic within the historical context of its time while also recognizing immense changes in society, medicine and public health since 1918. While the potential for another catastrophic global pandemic exists, there are many reasons to anticipate dramatic new discoveries and aspire to a goal of global prevention.

Co-sponsors include UNC’s Gillings School of Global Public Health, UNC’s Institute for Global Health and Infectious Diseases, UNC Libraries, the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences and RTI International; with the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of Natural History collaborating.

Registration is now available for the events listed below, via the Going Viral symposium website (https://sph.unc.edu/nciph/1918-flu-symposium/). Registration deadline is March 22nd, 2018.

Going Viral symposium, featuring 20+ speakers over 1.5 days

Thurs., April 5, 8:30 am – 4:35 pm and Fri., April 6, 8:30 am – 12:15 pm, at the UNC Friday Center (capacity=400)

Poster exhibition

Thurs., April 5, 4:45 – 6:00 pm, at the UNC Friday Center

Student researchers, post-doctoral scholars, practitioners and others will present posters on research or practice relevant to the symposium theme.


Keynote lecture by Gina Kolata, book signing and reception

Thurs., April 5, 6:00 – 8:00 pm, at the UNC Friday Center (free and open to the public, space permitting)

FREE Pre-symposium reception and program at Wilson Special Collections Library, UNC-Chapel Hill (capacity=120)

Wed., April 4, 6:00 pm – 8:00 pm (free and open to the public, but separate registration required here)

“O Lost!  UNC-Chapel Hill, Thomas Wolfe and the Great Influenza Pandemic of 1918”

Featuring an exhibition of rare materials from the Library’s North Carolina Collection, including the Thomas Wolfe Collection, the University Archives and the Health Sciences Library

The pre-symposium program will highlight how the 1918 pandemic affected both the UNC-Chapel Hill community and the life and work of Thomas Wolfe, UNC alumnus and author of the classic American novel, Look Homeward, Angel. Featured speakers are Howard E. Covington Jr., historian and biographer; and Paula Gallant Eckard, PhD, director of American Studies, associate professor of English, UNC-Charlotte; editor, Thomas Wolfe Review; past-president, Thomas Wolfe Society

See the full symposium agenda and REGISTER online (by March 22) via the symposium website here.

Regular          $175 ($185 with CEUs)

(faculty, postdocs, industry professionals, interested members of the general public)    


Students         $60 ($70 with CEUs)


(professional, graduate, undergraduate)                                                                   


Explore a Virtual Exhibit on the 1918 influenza pandemic by UNC-Chapel Hill’s Health Sciences Library: https://exhibits.lib.unc.edu/exhibits/show/going-viral/going-viral


Share stories: The Going Viral discussion website is a place to share recollections and artifacts related to the 1918 flu epidemic.

Questions? Please email 1918flu@unc.edu

subject: Research Study - Researchers Perceptions Regarding Institutional Review Boards: A Helping Hand or Putting up Roadblocks?
author: kseabolt
content:
Researchers Perceptions Regarding Institutional Review Boards: A Helping Hand or Putting Up Roadblocks?


Principal Investigator - Kim Boggess, MD


Researchers at the Office of Human Research Ethics at the University of North Carolina aim to study the current perceptions researchers have of Institutional Review Boards (IRB) in the United States.  You must be 18 years old or older and have conducted human subject's research in order to participate in this research study.  Participation in this research study involves a one-time demographic and study questionnaire which should take approximately 15 minutes to complete.  Survey results will be completely anonymous to protect your identity.  We will not be able to link your responses to you.  Only the research team will receive your anonymous responses.  You may skip any questions that you do not feel comfortable answering.  Your participation is completely voluntary.  


If you agree to participate in the study, please click on the link below to begin the survey:


https://unc.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_4Z6LfS4Wy2SOXnn


If you have any questions about this study, please contact Shahila Sriskanda, MS, CIP (shahila@email.unc.edu) or Kathy Seabolt, CIM, CIC, CIP (kseabolt@email.unc.edu).  If you have any questions or concerns regarding your rights as a subject in the study, contact the UNC Office of Human Research Ethics at 919-966-3113.

subject: Subjects needed for study on ACL rehabilitation
author: troyb
content:
The UNC Neuromuscular Research Lab is seeking paid volunteers for a research study on anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury and reconstruction surgery. Individuals who have injured their ACLs are at a heightened risk of developing knee osteoarthritis, partly because of weakness and dysfunction in the quadriceps muscle. Current rehabilitation approaches are often not effective for restoring quadriceps function due to a neuromuscular factor called arthrogenic muscle inhibition and the fact that the best ways to treat it are unclear.

 Applying vibration to a muscle improves its function and may be an effective way to treat quadriceps dysfunction following ACL injury and reconstruction. The purposes of this research study are to determine if two types of vibration (whole body vibration and local muscle vibration) improve quadriceps muscle function, proprioception (sensation of how your joints are positioned), and walking gait biomechanics in individuals with ACL injuries.

 If you decide to participate, you will be asked to report to the Neuromuscular Research Laboratory on the UNC-Chapel Hill campus for 3 testing sessions. One session will last approximately 45 minutes while the other two will last about an hour and a half. During these testing sessions you will be asked to complete 3 separate tests: 1) quadriceps muscle function, 2) walking gait biomechanics, and 3) sensory function/proprioception. You will then receive an intervention (whole body vibration, local muscle vibration, or control/no vibration) designed to improve these characteristics, and these tests will be repeated. You will also be asked to complete 3 online surveys regarding the details of your initial injury and surgery, your level of physical activity, and any symptoms you currently experience.

 There are some risks associated with participating in this research study, but they are not greater than the risks associated with normal physical activity/exercise.

 To be eligible to participate, you must meet the following inclusion criteria:

Age 18 – 35 years
History of ACL injury and reconstruction in only 1 of your legs within the last 6 months to 5 years
No history of ACL graft rupture or revision surgery
No history of injury to either leg within the last 6 months other than ACL injury and reconstruction surgery
No history of neurological disorder such as stroke, multiple sclerosis, or cerebral palsy
Cleared by a physician for return to physical activity, and currently physically active, participating in at least 20 minutes of physical activity 3x per week
Not currently pregnant
 Your total participation in the study will last approximately 3 hours and 45 minutes, and you will receive $125 for participating.

 If you meet these inclusion criteria and are interested in participating, please contact Chris Johnston at cdjohnst@email.unc.edu.

 This study was approved by the UNC-CH Biomedical Institutional Review Board on 5/18/2015 (IRB# 15-0838).

subject: Paid Vision Core Study
author: cbv33
content:
Vision Core Study: Neurophysiological correlates of static and dynamic vision assessments 

The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill’s Department of Exercise and Sport Science is seeking volunteers for a research study examining relationships among various assessments of visual system function and performance. We are looking for volunteers who meet the following criteria 

Must be between 18 and 30 years of age 
Must participate in 30 minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity at least 3 days per week. 
The study will consist of: 

One in-person session lasting approximately two hours where you will be asked to complete the following: 
Two questionnaires 
7 non-invasive visual function and performance assessments 
Brief balance test 
Brief electroencephalography assessment (consists of wearing a special cap while standing) 
You will receive $20 as compensation for your time. 
At your earliest convenience, please reply to this email at visioncore@unc.edu to let me know if you wish to participate. If we do not hear back within one week, we will follow-up with a brief reminder email. 

If you have any questions about this study before you make a decision to participate, please do not hesitate to ask by replying to this email, or by calling 919-962-0409 and asking to speak with someone from the Gfeller Center Vision Core. We hope you will consider participating in this study and we look forward to hearing from you! 

 

Thank you, 

 

Christina B. Vander Vegt, MS, ATC 

Doctoral Student and Research Assistant

Mathew Gfeller Sport-Related Traumatic Brain Injury Research Center

 

This study was approved by the Biomedical IRB on [11-15-2017] (IRB# 17-1471) 

This message is sponsored by the Department of Exercise and Sport Science

subject: HPTN 083 – HIV prevention study for men and transgender women
author: alpierce
content:
Are you:
At least 18 years of age?
A man or transgender woman who has sex with men?
HIV negative and generally healthy?
Are you interested in taking medications that may prevent HIV?

You might be eligible for the TRIUMPH (Truvada or Injectable Medication to Prevent HIV) study also called HPTN 083. “Step up to PrEP up”.

UNC is conducting a research study that is looking to compare oral Truvada as pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) with a long-acting injectable medication Cabotegravir in HIV-uninfected men and transgender women who have sex with men. This will require taking oral medication daily and receiving periodic injections.  Both medications have been generally safe and tolerable.  All visits will take place at the UNC Clinical Translational Research Center (CTRC) which is next to UNC Hospitals. 



Other study procedures will include, but may not be limited to: blood and specimen collections for STI testing and health monitoring, completing questionnaires, discussing health information, and receiving HIV counseling. The study will require monthly visits and participants are compensated for taking part in the study. 

For more information, please visit prevention4me.org or e-mail us your contact information at prevention_study@med.unc.edu.

This study titled "A Phase 2b/3 Double Blind Safety and Efficacy Study of Injectable Cabotegravir Compared to Daily Oral Tenofovir Disoproxil Fumarate/Emtricitabine (TDF/FTC), For Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis in HIV-Uninfected Cisgender Men and Transgender Women who have Sex with Men” was approved by the UNC Biomedical Institutional Review Board, IRB# 16-1026, initial approval date 09/13/2016.

subject: Something not quite right? You may be eligible to participate in a study in the Prime Research Program.
author: grewen
content:
The UNC Department of Psychiatry is conducting a research study to find out more about mental illness.  If you have had any of the following symptoms in the past few months, are between 12-30 years old, and have not been diagnosed with psychosis, you may be eligible to participate in a study in the Prime Research Program.

 

Do you sometimes feel confused about what is real or imaginary?
Have you felt that things happening around you have a special meaning just for you?
Are you feeling confused by things you hear or see?
Have you noticed unusual coincidences or connections that others do not seem to notice?
Do you ever feel like you just know what others are thinking or that others somehow know what you are thinking?
Are you worried that others are talking about you or laughing about you?
Do you think that others are trying to hurt you?
Do you have a close relative with a psychotic disorder and you’ve had a drop in function over the past year?

 

You may be eligible to receive free study related medical evaluations and monetary compensation.  Study participation includes multiple visits lasting 2-8 hours over 2 years.  These visits will take place at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

 

Visit us at our www.PRIME.unc.edu and click on 'Simple Survey' or call (877) PRIME19 or (877) 774-6319.

 

The Project is funded by the National Institute of Mental Health

 

14-2055 Approved 6-11-2015

Committee on the Protection of the Rights of Human Subjects

The BioMedical IRB

University of North Carolina

You might be eligible for the TRIUMPH (Truvada or Injectable Medication to Prevent HIV) study also called HPTN 083. “Step up to PrEP up”.

UNC is conducting a research study that is looking to compare oral Truvada as pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) with a long-acting injectable medication Cabotegravir in HIV-uninfected men and transgender women who have sex with men. This will require taking oral medication daily and receiving periodic injections.  Both medications have been generally safe and tolerable.  All visits will take place at the UNC Clinical Translational Research Center (CTRC) which is next to UNC Hospitals. 



Other study procedures will include, but may not be limited to: blood and specimen collections for STI testing and health monitoring, completing questionnaires, discussing health information, and receiving HIV counseling. The study will require monthly visits and participants are compensated for taking part in the study. 

For more information, please visit prevention4me.org or e-mail us your contact information at prevention_study@med.unc.edu.

This study titled "A Phase 2b/3 Double Blind Safety and Efficacy Study of Injectable Cabotegravir Compared to Daily Oral Tenofovir Disoproxil Fumarate/Emtricitabine (TDF/FTC), For Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis in HIV-Uninfected Cisgender Men and Transgender Women who have Sex with Men” was approved by the UNC Institutional Review Board, IRB# 16-1026, initial approval date 09/13/2016.

subject: Financial Fitness Lunch Series Seminars
author: kirkkm
content:
Want to improve your financial fitness in 2018? Join the Office of Human Resources and TIAA for a four-week lunchtime series that will cover budgeting, debt control, managing risk, investment strategies and planning for retirement costs. A trained TIAA facilitator will lead each session.

When

Wednesdays, March 14, March 21, March 28, and April 4 from 11:30 a.m. until 1 p.m.

Where

Room G-202, Medical Biomolecular Research Building

Topics

Week 1 - The Starting Line: Why and How Retirement Savings Should Begin Now
Week 2 - Money at Work: Foundations of Investing
Week 3 - Money at Work 2: Sharpening Investment Skills
Week 4 - Healthy Numbers: Integrating Health Care Into Your Retirement Plan

Participants should plan to attend all four sessions for completion credit; the workshops are designed so that each builds upon the other. These 90-minute sessions are not considered work time. However, with advance supervisory approval, employees may use their lunch hour to help minimize the amount of leave needed to attend each session.

Enrollment

1. Visit connectcarolina.unc.edu
2. Select Training Enrollment under Self Service.
3. Search for “Financial Fitness Lunch Series.”

Learn more

To learn more, visit go.unc.edu/financial-fitness.

subject: Consumer Information – Required Financial Aid Notice
author: bjedward
content:
To:      All Enrolled Students

From:  Rachelle Feldman

            Associate Provost and Director of Scholarships and Student Aid

Re:      Consumer Information

Under federal rules, the Office of Scholarships and Student Aid is responsible for sharing various policies, reports, and other University information with all enrolled students.

If you would like print copies of any of the documents linked below, you are welcome to contact our office or the relevant campus office.

With thanks,

Rachelle Feldman
Associate Provost and Director of Scholarships and Student Aid

——————

Accreditation - http://oira.unc.edu/accreditation/


The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill is accredited by the Commission on Colleges of the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools (SACS).  Additional information about Carolina’s accreditation can be found at the link above.

Academic Programs and Financial Assistance - The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Catalog (http://www.catalog.unc.edu) offers information about the academic programs at UNC-Chapel Hill.  Included are admissions standards, tuition and fees, financial aid information, program and course descriptions, and listings of faculty/instructors for each department.  Students may access financial aid information, including rights and responsibilities of financial aid recipients at http://studentaid.unc.edu/.

 

Campus Security Report - http://www.dps.unc.edu/securityreport/


This includes statistics about reported crimes during the past three years, as well as policies covering campus security and sexual assault. You will find information about the University's drug and alcohol policies, including disciplinary sanctions; criminal sanctions for violation of drug and alcohol laws; health risks of drugs and alcohol; and substance abuse treatment options.  There is also a Fire Safety Report containing statistics and information about fire safety processes at the University, staff information, and educational programs.

Copyright Information and Policies - UNC-Chapel Hill’s copyright policies can be found at http://policy.sites.unc.edu/files/2013/05/Copyright.pdf.  

 

Equity in Athletics (EADA) Report - This report contains participation rates, financial support, and other information regarding men’s and women’s intercollegiate athletic programs.  The report is available on the U.S. Department of Education website at https://ope.ed.gov/athletics/.  Search for University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. 

 

Federal Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) - Information about FERPA compliance and students’ rights under the law is available from the Office of the University Registrar at http://registrar.unc.edu/academic-services/uncferpa/.

 

Student Characteristics and Outcomes - Enrollment figures, student demographic reports, and graduation and retention rates for the general student body and student-athletes is available at  http://oira.unc.edu.

 

Serving Students with Disabilities – Accessibility Resources & Service (accessibility.unc.edu) works to ensure that all University programs and facilities are accessible to all persons.  The office develops programs and services that enable students to meet the demands of University life as independently as possible.  In addressing academic issues and needs, Accessibility Resources & Service partners with the Academic Success Program for students with LD/ADHD (learningcenter.unc.edu).

Vaccine Requirements - Campus Health Services lists the required immunizations for all students at the following link:  http://campushealth.unc.edu/services/immunizations/north-carolina-required-immunications-entering-students.

 

Voter Registration – Detailed information about registering to vote in North Carolina can be found through the State Board of Elections at https://www.ncsbe.gov/Voter-Registration/Registering-to-Vote.  The national voter registration form for registering to vote in other states may be accessed at https://www.eac.gov/voters/national-mail-voter-registration-form/.  Paper copies of voter registration forms are available in Davis Library.  The Office of Accessibility Resources and Service offers assistance in registering to vote to any student with a disability.  The deadline for registering to vote in North Carolina is 25 days before the date of the election in which you want to vote.

subject: Effect of Drug Conviction on Financial Aid
author: bjedward
content:
To:                  All Enrolled Students

From:             Rachelle Feldman

                        Associate Provost and Director of Scholarships and Student Aid

Re:                  The Effect of a Drug Conviction on Your Financial Aid

A conviction for the possession or sale of a controlled substance will result in the loss of your federal financial aid. This notice is mandated by federal law and goes to all enrolled students each year.

If you are convicted of any offense under any federal or state law involving the possession or sale of a controlled substance during a period of enrollment for which you were receiving any grant, loan or work assistance, you will not be eligible for any federal grant, loan or work assistance from the date of that conviction for the period of time set forth below.


Possession of a controlled substance

First offense: Ineligible for 1 year
Second offense: Ineligible for 2 years
Third offense: Ineligible for an indefinite period of time

Sale of a controlled substance

First offense: Ineligible for 2 years
Second offense: Ineligible for an indefinite period of time.


A student whose eligibility for aid has been suspended may regain eligibility before the end of the ineligibility period if


The student satisfactorily completes a drug rehabilitation program that complies with criteria established by the Secretary of Education and passes two unannounced drug tests; or
The student’s conviction is reversed or set aside.

Drug abuse obviously has consequences beyond the loss of federal student aid, and the University takes seriously its obligation to protect the campus and help individual students. There are resources available if you or someone you know is struggling with substance abuse.

Visit http://www.dps.unc.edu/securityreport/ for a summary of UNC’s drug and alcohol policies and available resources, or visit Campus Health to learn about options for treatment and other assistance: https://campushealth.unc.edu/services/counseling-and-psychological-services/how-support-student/concern-about-yourself.

subject: INFORMATIONAL FOR A RESEARCH STUDY
author: khmills
content:
Investigators at the UNC Center for Environmental Medicine, Asthma and Lung Biology
are screening asthmatic individuals to see how they respond to wood smoke inhalation when riding a stationary bicycle.

 

Contact

	

Call 919-843-6598 or e-mail smokescreen@med.unc.edu





Requirements

	
You must be between 18 and 45
You must have mild asthma
Women who are pregnant or nursing a baby cannot participate
You must not any orthopedic limitations
You must not smoke



Time Commitment

	

There is a 4 hour long General Screening visit (IRB #98-0799). Then there are 3 visits over a 1 month period.  The first visit will last about 4 hours, the next visit will be for a full day, and you will return the following day for about 2 ½ hours.




Compensation

	

Complete General Screen research study visit $75

3 Smokescreen research study visits at EPA building on UNC campus for up to $400.00

 

IRB #15-1775:  To identify persons who are susceptible to wood smoke particulate-induced inflammation and examine the role of GSTM1 and other factors in this susceptibility.

 

Approved 01/18/2018 by the Biomedical Institutional Review Board.

 

This e-mail is sponsored by the UNC Center for Environmental Medicine, Asthma and Lung Biology

subject: Study Participation Invitation
author: ypchang
content:
Hello there!

 

We are in need of participants who are aged between 25 and 35 and mainly grew up in the US or in Taiwan for an online research study on the relationship between everyday emotion experiences and expressions. The survey includes a 1-hour online questionnaire in which you will listen to 6 voice messages, read 6 pictures of cards, and then answer questionnaires about your feelings, attitudes toward the messages and cards, and your demographics. You will be able to join a drawing to win an emailed gift card after completing the survey. One $200 and 6 $80 gift cards will be provided for approximately 300 participants.

 

If you’re aged between 25 and 35, grew up in the US or in Taiwan, and are interested in our study, please click the link below to go to the survey. Thank you!

subject: Apply to Serve as an Executive Officer of the Executive Branch for 2018-2019!
author: jtblount
content:
Apply to Serve as an Executive Branch Officer for the 2018-2019 academic year by Wednesday, Feb. 21, at 8 p.m.!

Applications for the 2018-2019 Executive Branch Officer Team (EBO) are now available at heellife.unc.edu. The direct link to the application can be found here. The application is open to fees-paying UNC undergraduate students that will be enrolled full time for the entire 2018-2019 academic year. EBO members will serve a one year team beginning April 3, 2018 under the Putnam Administration. 

The following positions serve on the Executive Branch Officer Team (EBO):

USG President
USG Vice-President
USG Treasurer
USG Secretary
USG Chief of Staff
USG Senior Advisor(s)
USG Director of State & External Affairs
Descriptions, role overviews and role requirements can be found in the Student Code here.

The application, interview and selection process is as follows:

February 14 at 8 pm: Application is made available
February 21 at 8 pm: Application closes
February 25: Interviews begin
March 2: Interviews conclude
March 5: Applicants are notified
March 6: Final nominees attend Committees of the Undergraduate Senate
March 20: Final nominees attend Full Meeting of the Undergraduate Senate (to be confirmed)
For more information regarding the application process for the 2018-2019 Executive Branch Officer Team, visit executivebranch.unc.edu/eboapplication. 

--

*Interviews have the potential to be recording (with audio and/or video). This will be confirmed in the interview confirmation process and discussed on a case-by-case basis.

subject: Join the Carolina Community at the annual Eve Carson Lecture Series with Kathy Izard!
author: jtblount
content:
Join the Carolina Community at the annual Eve Marie Carson Lecture featuring Kathy Izard on February 22, 2018 at 6 p.m.!

The Speakers Committee of the UNC Executive Branch is thrilled to welcome Kathy Izard to Carolina to speak as a part of the Eve Marie Carson Lecture series. 

Kathy Izard – the founder of Moore Place, a home for chronically homeless men and women in Charlotte, and author of The Hundred Story Home, a book about finding faith in yourself and in something bigger – will give the annual Eve Marie Carson Lecture at 6 p.m. on Thursday, February 22, 2018 at Moeser Auditorium in UNC’s Hill Hall. 

The Eve Marie Carson Annual Lecture series invites someone who has distinguished themselves through their ideals and accomplishments to Carolina to lecture on a contemporary issue. The lecture series was founded by former student body president Eve Carson and continues today in her memory. Previous speakers include, Robert Gibbs, Rye Barcott, Ping Fu, and Frank Bruni.

The event is sponsored by the Executive Branch of UNC Student Government and funded by the Carolina Women’s Leadership Council.

The Eve Marie Carson Lecture Series seeks to stimulate a community-wide dialogue on contemporary issues and is free and open to the public.

Subject: Payment Card Industry (PCI) Annual Town Hall Meeting

Date:      February 19, 2018

Since last year we have made significant progress with our compliance efforts, thanks to each of you.  It is important to remember that PCI compliance is a process and not an event.

During March, CERTIFI Committee and staff will be presenting a series of PCI Compliance Overview sessions for everyone involved with the processing of credit cards.

Please forward this invitation to your staff involved in the processing of payment cards. This should include managers, supervisors, accountants and staff who directly interact with cardholder data or manage processes and/or contracts that involve cardholder data. Registration is now open at the following link: PCI Compliance Calendar.  Users can go to the calendar and click on the ‘Register Now’ button for the date/event they would like to attend. From there, users will be routed to an enrollment screen where they will complete the required fields and click “Submit Registration.”  After the user has registered, they will receive a confirmation email a few moments later.

All sessions will take place in Toy Lounge in Dey Hall. More sessions may be added to the schedule if necessary.

subject: Carolina Neurostimulation Conference
author: pagejm
content:
Dear Colleagues,
It is with great pleasure that we invite you to participate in the 1st Carolina Neurostimulation Conference (CNC) to be held May 21-23, 2018 in Chapel Hill, NC, USA. This is a premier conference for those working to advance our understanding of dynamics of the brain, body, and behavior, investigating the response to stimulation, and translating discoveries into clinical applications. Hosted by the Carolina Center for Neurostimulation, CNC serves as a platform for networking for all researchers and specialists and exchanging ideas about the latest discoveries and innovations in brain stimulation and clinical treatments. We have a great lineup of speakers including keynotes from Dr. Sarah Lisanby (NIH) and Dr. Kaspar Schindler (Inselspital). Central topics for discussion and presentations include TMS, tACS, tDCS, and methods such as modeling, imaging, analysis, and devices.
Registration:
Please register at the link provided here . The deadline for Registration is May 1st 2018
Regular (Faculty, Postdocs, Industry Professionals)
$165
Students (Graduate, Undergraduate)
$95
UNC Members (Registration required)
Free
For a full program, and information regarding registration, travel, and accommodations please visit our conference website. Like us on Facebook for updates.
Abstract Submission for Posters:
In addition to attending the plenary sessions, registrants are invited to participate in the conference’s poster session. Original contributions addressing theory, research, practice, and training/education issues, in any areas of neuromodulation and brain network dynamics are welcome. The deadline for abstract submission is March 15th 2018. Authors will be notified of acceptance in the first week of April. Please follow the guidelines for the submission of your abstract.
Max 500 words and 1 page including title, author(s), affiliation(s), and main body.
Structure: Background, Methods, Results, and Conclusions (References and Funding)
File format: single PDF file converted from the provided template
Email us to submit your abstract (neurostimulation@unc.edu)
Travel Awards for Trainees:
We have funds allocated for trainee travel awards. All trainees (undergraduate students, graduate students, post docs, research associates) who will be presenting posters at the conference are eligible for travel awards. To apply for a travel award please complete the form in this link and email us at neurostimulation@unc.edu along with your CV. Please note that you must attend the conference and present your poster to receive the travel award. The deadline for Travel Awards is March 15th 2018
Transcranial Electrical Stimulation Workshop:
Trainees and conference attendees are encouraged to attend the preliminary neurostimulation workshop on May 21st, 2018. This one-day innovative hands-on transcranial electrical stimulation (TES) workshop will be taught by Dr. Flavio Frohlich. The workshop will focus on transcranial alternating current stimulation (tACS) and transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) with an exciting overview of theory, research, and methods. Click here for registration information.
When completing registration, please be sure to provide feedback regarding your current knowledge of TES as well as some questions or techniques you are interested in. We want this course to be as interactive as possible. Lunch and beverages will be provided.
Sponsors:

UNC School of Medicine Department of Psychiatry
UNC School of Medicine
UNC Psychology and Neuroscience
Neurophet
Brain Vision
Cortec

About the Carolina Center for Neurostimulation:
The Carolina Center for Neurostimulation is part of the Department of Psychiatry at The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and is directed by Dr. Flavio Frohlich. Established in 2017, the Center seeks to revolutionize psychiatry and neurology by studying the dynamics of brain, body, and behavior, investigating the response to stimulation, and translating discoveries into clinical treatments.

subject: DDD: 2018 Travel Mileage Rates
author: shia
content:
Date: Feb. 16, 2018

To:  Deans, Directors and Department Chairs (DDD), University Business Managers (UBM) , MOU Financial Leads (MOU)

From:  Janet Rupert, Director of Systems and Operations

The North Carolina Office of State Budget and Management (OSBM) has released the state mileage allowances for 2018.

Effective Jan. 1, 2018, university travelers are obligated to use a State-owned vehicle or vehicle leased through a state contract. When such vehicle is not available, and/or a personal vehicle must be used, the allowable business standard mileage rate is 54.5 cents per mile for trips that do not exceed 100 miles. For business travel trips that utilize personal vehicles and exceed 100 miles per trip, the employee shall be reimbursed at 33 cents per mile. As this policy has shifted in interpretation over the past few years, we are providing a clarification chart and FAQs below to help in interpreting the new policy. See Policy 1310 for more information. 

Charts and FAQs about the New Mileage:

Round trip does not exceed 100 miles

	

54.5 cents per mile




Round trip exceeds 100 miles

	

Total round trip will be reimbursed at 33 cents per mile

Q: I am attending a conference in Richmond, Virginia, and will travel 310 miles to a conference. How do I calculate my mileage?
A:  All university travelers are obligated to use a State-owned vehicle or vehicle leased through a state contract. If such a vehicle is not available and/or a personal vehicle must be utilized, you will be reimbursed for 310 miles at 33 cents per mile, as the trip exceeded 100 miles.

Q: What if my trip is less than 100 miles?
A: You may be reimbursed for the trip at 54.5 cents per mile, as long as the entire trip is less than 100 miles. If it is more than 100 miles, the reimbursement rate drops to the 33-cent rate for the entire trip.  Under 2018 guidelines, the first 100 miles of a trip are not eligible for the 54.5 cent rate, unless the entire trip does not exceed 100 miles.

Q:  I have already claimed mileage in January before this memo was issued.  Do I have to reimburse the difference?

A:  No.  The ConnectCarolina mileage was updated at 5 p.m. on Feb. 15.  Although the State policy was in effect on Jan. 1 of this year, the new rate will not be applied before it was put into our system so that no retro actions need to be taken.

subject: Imaging Research Study for Families with Children Ages 0-60 months
author: jordannj
content:
Are you expecting or know someone who is?  Do you have a newborn, toddler, or preschooler?   

As part of the Baby Connectome Project at UNC-Chapel Hill's Biomedical Research Imaging Center, we are recruiting families with children (ages 0-60 months) to participate in our research study.

What is the purpose of this research study?

The Baby Connectome Project (BCP) will investigate the physical changes taking place in a baby or child’s brain. This research initiative of the Foundation for the National Institutes of Health is dedicated to learning more about early child brain development. The BCP will provide an unprecedented view of how a healthy human brain develops and works.

Inclusion Criteria

Birth at gestational age 37-42 weeks
Normal birth weight
Absence of any major pregnancy and delivery complications
What does this research study involve?

Your child will have a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of his/her brain completed at different times in his/her development. These scans will be completed at UNC’s Marsico Hall. During this visit, behavioral assessments will be completed and saliva samples will be obtained. You will also be asked to provide history about you and your child’s medical history, and you will complete questionnaires about your child’s behavior.

Scans will be performed while your child is asleep or awake.  No medication or sedation will be used.

Will I be paid for participating?

You will receive $90 for each visit, and parking will be provided at no cost.

Are there any risks?

MRI is a safe and non-invasive way of answering questions about the structural and functional organization of the brain as it develops. It has no known risks and does not use radiation or x-ray.

Why participate in this research study?

You and your child’s participation in this research study will help us learn more about children’s mental, emotional and behavioral development. It may also help us understand the possible causes of learning disabilities and neurodevelopmental disorders.

How can I learn more about joining this research study?

Please contact Jordan Jimenez at jordan_jimenez@med.unc.edu or call 919-843-4640 for more information.

 

This study titled "Baby Connectome Project" has been approved by the UNC Biomedical Institutional Review Board (IRB)- study #16-1943, approved 11/03/2017.

subject: 2018 Federal Withholding Tax Changes and How They May Affect You
author: jlkelly
content:
Dear University Employee,

Beginning with the February 16, 2018, biweekly paycheck, all biweekly and monthly paychecks subject to federal tax withholdings will reflect the 2018 federal tax withholding rates issued by the Internal Revenue Service. The federal tax rate changes are a part of the 2018 tax reform passed by Congress in December 2017.

Employees are not required to take any extra steps regarding this change to withholdings taxes but are encouraged to review their new federal tax withholding rates. If a change is deemed necessary, you can view or update your W-4 and NC-4 forms, which determine your tax withholdings, via the ConnectCarolina SelfService menu.  Instructions can be found at https://ccinfo.unc.edu/featured-resources/online-employee-tax-forms/#w4snc4s.

If you have problems accessing the ConnectCarolina SelfService items, please contact the Help Desk at 962-HELP. Contact Payroll Services at payroll@unc.edu if you are unable to update your W-4 or NC-4 after working with the Help Desk.

Walter Miller
Director of Payroll Services

subject: Ackland Art Museum Course Development/Course Enhancement Grants
author: carolyn
content:
The Ackland Art Museum offers funding to support either a new course or revisions to an existing course that directly engages with the Museum's collection. The Ackland's objective in offering these funds is to further integrate the practice of teaching with works of art into the academic curriculum of the University. Support for these grants comes from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.


The maximum grant available is $5,000. Tenured or tenure-track faculty, fixed term faculty, or lecturers in any discipline may apply. The Ackland's expectation is that the course developed with these funds will be taught three or more times. The course should be taught for the first time during or before the 2019-2020 academic year, and at least twice more within the next five years.


Applicants should submit:


A brief description of the course's objectives, its relationship to the applicant's teaching and research interests, the course's significance for the curriculum, and the type of course (e.g. first year seminar, honors seminar, undergraduate lecture course, graduate course, etc.). The description should include a discussion of the role that works of art will play in the course and the relevant objects or area(s) of the Ackland's collection.

Proposed budget and planning timeline. Budget may include expenses such as: instructor salary; graduate student assistance; supplies; course materials; and research related expenses.

Letter of support from the applicant's department chair.

2-3 page CV.


Applications are due April 2, 2018.


Recipient will be notified April 30, 2018.


Funds will be available after July 1, 2018.


Submit applications to either:


Ackland Art Museum

Academic Programs: Course Development/Course Enhancement Grants


CB#3400


OR


acklandlearn@unc.edu

subject: INFORMATIONAL FOR A RESEARCH STUDY
author: khmills
content:
Investigators at the UNC Center for Environmental Medicine, Asthma and Lung Biology
are screening asthmatic individuals to see how they respond to wood smoke inhalation when riding a stationary bicycle.

 

Contact

	

Call 919-843-6598 or e-mail smokescreen@med.unc.edu





Requirements

	
You must be between 18 and 45
You must have mild asthma
Women who are pregnant or nursing a baby cannot participate
You must not any orthopedic limitations
You must not smoke



Time Commitment

	

There is a 4 hour long General Screening visit (IRB #98-0799). Then there are 3 visits over a 1 month period.  The first visit will last about 4 hours, the next visit will be for a full day, and you will return the following day for about 2 ½ hours.




Compensation

	

Complete General Screen research study visit $75

3 Smokescreen research study visits at EPA building on UNC campus for up to $400.00

 

IRB #15-1775:  To identify persons who are susceptible to wood smoke particulate-induced inflammation and examine the role of GSTM1 and other factors in this susceptibility.

 

Approved 01/18/2018 by the Biomedical Institutional Review Board.

 

This e-mail is sponsored by the UNC Center for Environmental Medicine, Asthma and Lung Biology

subject: Healthy women needed for research study
author: rrblanch
content:
Reproductive Endocrinology at NC Women's Hospital

 

We are currently seeking healthy women to participate in research studies.  Several opportunities are available that offer monetary compensation, ranging from $25-200.

 

You may be qualified if the following applies to you:

- Between the ages of 18-35

- Having regular menstrual cycles, every 25-35 days

- Not using birth control pills, hormonal contraceptives or IUD

- Not currently pregnant, or trying to become pregnant

-Flexible schedule

 

The ultimate goal of this research is to better understand the factors that allow implantation to occur so that we may improve clinical outcomes of fertility patients.  If you are interested, please feel free to contact us for more information at uncreproductive@gmail.com.

 

Biomedical IRB study #05-1757 “Molecular Regulation in Reproduction;” approved 01/07/2018

subject: DDD - Payment Card Industry (PCI) Annual Town Hall Meeting
author: jlkelly
content:
To:          Deans, Directors and Department Chairs

From:     DeAhn Baucom, Chair - CERTIFI Committee

Subject: Payment Card Industry (PCI) Annual Town Hall Meeting

Date:      February 13, 2018

Since last year we have made significant progress with our compliance efforts, thanks to each of you.  It is important to remember that PCI compliance is a process and not an event.

During March, CERTIFI Committee and staff will be presenting a series of PCI Compliance Overview sessions for everyone involved with the processing of credit cards.

Please forward this invitation to your staff involved in the processing of payment cards. This should include managers, supervisors, accountants and staff who directly interact with cardholder data or manage processes and/or contracts that involve cardholder data. Since attendance will be mandatory, we wanted to make these dates available as soon as possible.

The following are the dates for the planned information sessions:

Wednesday, March 7         10:00am – 11:00am

Thursday, March 8              3:00pm – 4:00pm

Thursday, March 15           10:00am – 11:00am

subject: Child Optical Imaging Study
author: hareed
content:
Hello, 

The Neurocognition and Imaging Laboratory at the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill is looking to recruit preschool aged participants for an ongoing study about the development of decision making and how it may influence predictions of academic achievement.


Eligibility:



 3 to 5 years old
 And has NO diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder or any diagnosed developmental disorder


Study Details:

This study includes a 60 minute visit to our research lab at the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill. During this visit the child will be asked to complete three tests of executive function with a brief break between each task. They will then be asked to complete two more brief tasks of applied numbers and words, all the while wearing a functional near infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) headband.

 

Parents will be expected to attend this session and will be asked to fill out questionnaires about their child’s development.



Parents will receive $25 for participating in the study and the child will receive a gift for their time and cooperation

 

Contact: For more information, please contact us at OpticalChild@med.unc.edu.


This biomedical research study (IRB#17-0214) was approved by the UNC-CH on April 12, 2017.



This message is sponsored by: Department of Psychiatry

We are conducting a research study of how participating in a dance workshop can help people with diabetes. Our workshop offers a new form of diabetes therapy and peer support.

To participate in the study, you must:

subject: Hettleman Prizes for Artistic and Scholarly Achievement by Young Faculty
author: briordan
content:
TO:         Members of the Faculty

               The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill                                                                

FROM:   Chancellor Carol L. Folt

DATE:    February 12, 2018

RE:         Hettleman Prizes for Artistic and Scholarly Achievement by Young Faculty

 =========================================================

I invite you to submit nominations for the 2018 Hettleman Prizes for Scholarly and Artistic Achievement by Young Faculty.  These prizes, made possible by the generosity of Phillip (UNC Class of 1921) and Ruth Hettleman, recognize scholarly and artistic achievement by junior tenure-track, or recently tenured, members of the faculty.  Four recipients will be selected for the awards of $5,000 each.

Those eligible to be nominated are assistant professors in their third or fourth years who have been recommended for reappointment for a second term, any second term assistant professor, and any associate professor who will not have been in rank as an associate professor for longer than three years at the end of this academic year.

Nominations should include electronic submission of the following, unless otherwise noted:

Nominating Letter
Nominations may be made by appointing units or by members of the University community from within or outside the nominee’s department.  The nominating letter should explain why the nominee’s work is “groundbreaking.”

Nominee’s Curriculum Vitae
Documentation
Articles that the nominee has written, papers that the nominee has given, and/or photographs of art that the nominee has produced.  Electronic and digital submissions are preferred.  If hard copy submission is necessary, please submit seven copies.

Letters of Evaluation
These letters can come from within or outside the nominee’s department, as well as from other institutions.  Letters from the outside do not have to be written explicitly for the Hettleman Award; they can be ones collected for tenure and promotion decision, reappointment considerations or letters written for other awards.  Letters should emphasize and critically evaluate the distinctive contribution of the nominee’s scholarship to his or her discipline.  They must make clear to an audience of intelligent laypersons the scholarly or artistic significance of the nominee’s work.  It is hoped that each scholarly project will already be in the public domain, but manuscripts accepted for publication or in galley form will be considered. 

The deadline for submission is Friday, March 23, 2018. Please submit electronic nominations to Hettleman_award@unc.edu and hard copy material to the Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research, 312 South Building. 

Vice Chancellor for Research Terry Magnuson and the selection committee, which is comprised of six professors -- three from the Division of Academic Affairs and three from the Division of Health Affairs – will forward a list of recommendations to me. The announcements of the prizes will be made at the first Faculty Council meeting of the fall term of 2018.

Thank you for taking the time to help recognize and reward the work of Carolina’s most promising young faculty.

subject: Cleaning out offices? Request your temporary recycling bin today!
author: willconn
content:
Moving offices or doing a file purge? Please reserve temporary bins for recyclables by filling out an OWRR service request or calling 919-962-4699.

OWRR can deliver as many bins as needed, and these bins can accommodate higher-than-normal volumes of recyclables without filling up the permanent recycling bins too quickly. Temporary bins can be emptied multiple times before they are taken away. Please contact us at least 48 hours before you will need the bins delivered.

Please follow the regular recycling guidelines for mixed paper. By North Carolina Statute, all University records belong to the public, even if they are confidential. However, not all documents must be kept in perpetuity. Please follow the University Archives and Records Management Services (UARMS) Record Retention Schedule and Guidelines when purging files.

If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to contact OWRR at 919-962-1442, email recycling@facilities.unc.edu or visit go.unc.edu/officecleanout.

subject: Research study for adults with osteoarthritis or joint pain, aching or stiffness
author: bahorski
content:
Are you an adult with osteoarthritis or pain, aching, or stiffness in your knees or hips? 

You may be interested in a research study to help researchers learn about partner support and physical activity.  

The UNC Thurston Arthritis Research Center is conducting a research study for people with hip or knee osteoarthritis (or arthritis-related joint symptoms) and their spouse or partner. We are interested in learning how couples discuss and overcome barriers to increasing physical activity. Research shows that becoming more active can help people manage joint pain and stiffness, in addition to having other health benefits.

Participants will attend a 2 ½ hour, one-time meeting that may help them make changes to lead a more physically active lifestyle. Couples can earn up to $150 for participating in the study.

Couples will be asked to:

Participate in a videotaped conversation with their partner about physical activity
Complete an activity based on the recorded conversation
Fill out brief questionnaires
Couples will not be engaging in any physical activity during the session

You may be eligible to participate if you are…

An adult with osteoarthritis or joint symptoms, such as pain or stiffness, in your hips or knees
At least 40 years of age
Married to or living with your partner
English speaking
Are doing less than 150 minutes of physical activity per week

In addition, both you and your partner must be willing to join the study and attend the study meeting together in Chapel Hill, NC.

For more information or to find out if you are eligible, please call our toll free number at (844) 966-7538. To fill out our online screening survey, go to http://go.unc.edu/PALIS. You can also email us at palis@med.unc.edu.

This study (IRB # 16-2207) is approved by the Office of Human Research Ethics Biomedical Institutional Review Board until August 8, 2018.  This announcement was first approved by the Institutional Review Board on 1/31/17.

This message is sponsored by the Thurston Arthritis Research Center.

subject: Director Named for Frank Porter Graham Child Development Institute
author: briordan
content:
February 9, 2018

To: Deans, Directors, and Department Chairs

From: Terry Magnuson, Vice Chancellor for Research

Re: Director Named for Frank Porter Graham Child Development Institute

 

Dear Colleagues,

I’m happy to announce that Aysenil (Ayse) Belger, PhD has been named the next director of the Frank Porter Graham Child Development Institute (FPG).

Dr. Belger is a professor and director of the Neurocognition and Imaging Research Lab in the Department of Psychiatry, the director of the Clinical Translational Research Core within the Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities Research Center of the Carolina Center of Developmental Disabilities, and has been a UNC faculty member for 18 years.

Her research focuses on understanding brain function, specifically on the breakdown of brain functions in neuropsychiatric and neurodevelopment disorders. Most recently this has included studying abnormalities in young, autistic children and children and adolescents at high risk for schizophrenia. Her lab explores the behavioral and neurophysiological underpinnings of sensory and cognitive impairments across neuropsychiatric and neurodevelopment disorders. Throughout her career, she has forged faculty collaborations throughout UNC and other institutions to better understand the effects of early childhood adversity on neurocognitive maturation.

Her extensive experience, coupled with her incredible energy, will serve the Institute well as FPG continues to expand its portfolio of research and services. As director, Dr. Belger will provide administrative oversight and work with the FPG leadership team, investigative groups, and staff to advance the Institute’s research, provide technical assistance and consultation, and facilitate community outreach. One of the nation's oldest and largest multidisciplinary centers devoted to the study of young children and their families, FPG is world-renown for not only the research it conducts, but also the efficiency in which this knowledge is then put into practice through the Institutes efforts.

Dr. Belger’s anticipated start date is April 1, 2018. She will be working with Interim Director Stephen Hooper over the next few months to ensure a smooth leadership transition.

Please join me in welcoming Ayse to her new role.

subject: Imaging Research Study for Families with Children Ages 0-60 months
author: jordannj
content:
Are you expecting or know someone who is?  Do you have a newborn, toddler, or preschooler?   

As part of the Baby Connectome Project at UNC-Chapel Hill's Biomedical Research Imaging Center, we are recruiting families with children (ages 0-60 months) to participate in our research study.

What is the purpose of this research study?

The Baby Connectome Project (BCP) will investigate the physical changes taking place in a baby or child’s brain. This research initiative of the Foundation for the National Institutes of Health is dedicated to learning more about early child brain development. The BCP will provide an unprecedented view of how a healthy human brain develops and works.

Inclusion Criteria

Birth at gestational age 37-42 weeks
Normal birth weight
Absence of any major pregnancy and delivery complications
What does this research study involve?

Your child will have a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of his/her brain completed at different times in his/her development. These scans will be completed at UNC’s Marsico Hall. During this visit, behavioral assessments will be completed and saliva samples will be obtained. You will also be asked to provide history about you and your child’s medical history, and you will complete questionnaires about your child’s behavior.

Scans will be performed while your child is asleep or awake.  No medication or sedation will be used.

Will I be paid for participating?

You will receive $90 for each visit, and parking will be provided at no cost.

Are there any risks?

MRI is a safe and non-invasive way of answering questions about the structural and functional organization of the brain as it develops. It has no known risks and does not use radiation or x-ray.

Why participate in this research study?

You and your child’s participation in this research study will help us learn more about children’s mental, emotional and behavioral development. It may also help us understand the possible causes of learning disabilities and neurodevelopmental disorders.

How can I learn more about joining this research study?

Please contact Jordan Jimenez at jordan_jimenez@med.unc.edu or call 919-843-4640 for more information.

 

This study titled "Baby Connectome Project" has been approved by the UNC Biomedical Institutional Review Board (IRB)- study #16-1943, approved 11/03/2017.

subject: Infant/Toddler Nap Study
author: pagejm
content:
Subject: Early Development and Sleep Research Study
Hello,
The Frohlich Lab, a leader in brain network dynamics at UNC, has an exciting research study that your infant/toddler between the ages of 12-30 months can participate in with just 2 short sessions. In this study, we are hoping to learn more about how infant/toddler brains are developing when asleep. The types of activities involved are infant developmental assessments and a non-invasive recording (brain rhythms) during a midday nap.
Participation involves a visit to your home at your convenience and one visit to our center at the UNC Medical School Wing C Building, Room 242.  This location offers free parking. Each visit will take about 2 ½ hours.
We will compensate you $75 for your time. For more information, or to see if your child is eligible, please call Jessica Page at 919-445-0227 or email jessica.page@unc.edu or EDS@med.unc.edu.  You can find out more on our website at http://www.frohlichlab.org/.
We look forward to your participation!
 
The Frohlich Lab
 
This study was approved by the UNC biomedical IRB on 1/13/18 (IRB # 15-1829)

subject: Deadline Extended: Nominations for the 2018 Student Undergraduate Teaching and Staff Awards
author: lambert2
content:
DEADLINE EXTENDED:  The Student Undergraduate Teaching and Staff Awards Committee is accepting nominations for the 2018 SUTASA Awards.  SUTASA are the only teaching and staff awards funded, nominated, and selected entirely by undergraduate students.  You must be an undergraduate student to submit a nomination.

Since 1989, we have awarded six $1,000 teaching assistant awards and three $5,000 faculty awards each year.  We also award one $1,000 staff award to a University employee that is not faculty or a TA.

Please take the time to recognize and reward our faculty and employees who are at the heart of a great undergraduate education.  Nominations are due by 5:00 pm on Friday, February 16th. The awards will be presented at the Chancellor's Awards Ceremony on April 24th.

The nomination form can be found at http://bit.ly/SUTASA_2018.

For additional information, contact the SUTASA Committee at uncsutasa@gmail.com.

subject: Infant/Toddler Nap Study
author: pagejm
content:
Subject: Early Development and Sleep Research Study
Hello,
The Frohlich Lab, a leader in brain network dynamics at UNC, has an exciting research study that your infant/toddler between the ages of 12-30 months can participate in with just 2 short sessions. In this study, we are hoping to learn more about how infant/toddler brains are developing when asleep. The types of activities involved are infant developmental assessments and a non-invasive recording (brain rhythms) during a midday nap.
Participation involves a visit to your home at your convenience and one visit to our center at the UNC Medical School Wing C Building, Room 242.  This location offers free parking. Each visit will take about 2 ½ hours.
We will compensate you $75 for your time. For more information, or to see if your child is eligible, please call Jessica Page at 919-445-0227 or email jessica.page@unc.edu or EDS@med.unc.edu.  You can find out more on our website at http://www.frohlichlab.org/.
We look forward to your participation!
 
The Frohlich Lab
 
This study was approved by the UNC biomedical IRB on 1/13/18 (IRB # 15-1829)

subject: 2-Step Verification Requirement for ConnectCarolina
author: hashk
content:
Beginning on February 15, 2-Step Verification will be required to access the student financial portion of ConnectCarolina. This includes student bill pay and direct deposit account access.

With 2-Step Verification, you protect your account with something you know (your password) and something you have (your phone). Even if a bad guy hacks through your password layer, he'll still need your phone or other second verification method to get into your account information.

How 2-Step Will Change Your ConnectCarolina Experience

How you log in to ConnectCarolina will not change – how your access student financial information within ConnectCarolina will change. When you click to access that portion of ConnectCarolina you will:

Be prompted with a button to “Verify with 2-Step.”
Receive a code or notification to your phone via text, mobile app or voice call to confirm your access request.
Get Started with 2-Step

While you will not see 2-Step prompts in ConnectCarolina until February 15, now is the time to get prepared!

Visit onyen.unc.edu and click on “Register & Manage 2-Step Verification.” The registration process takes just 10 minutes. You will need to have your mobile device and PID available. We recommend downloading the DUO Security app from your phone’s app store for the smoothest 2-Step experience.

To learn more, visit: its.unc.edu/2-step/.

 

Need Assistance?

If you need assistance, please do not hesitate to visit help.unc.edu to chat with a support representative or call the ITS Service Desk at 919-962-HELP.

subject: Living with an anxious family member?
author: reuman
content:
Do you have a family member who suffers with anxiety? 

Are you looking for support and skills for living with an anxious child or partner?

If you are 18 years of age or older and live with a partner or child diagnosed with an anxiety disorder, you might be eligible to participate in a research study to learn coping skills for living with an anxious loved one.

Study participation involves five weekly group sessions, as well as three study assessments. You will receive a cognitive-behaviorally based therapeutic intervention at no cost. Sessions will be held on Tuesday evenings on campus.

For more information, please contact the UNC Anxiety and Stress Disorders Clinic in Chapel Hill, NC.

Email us at anxiety@unc.edu and please include the following information:

(1) First name,

(2) Phone number, and

(3) Times you would be available to have a brief (15 minute) phone call.

This study, titled "A group intervention to reduce accommodation among relatives of individuals with fear-based disorders," has been approved by the UNC Non-Biomedical IRB (Study#17-1396, approved July 18, 2017).

subject: Dance and Diabetes Study
author: jjack
content:
Do you have diabetes? Do you like dance—or would you like to learn how to express yourself through a creative form of exercise?

We are conducting a research study of how participating in a dance workshop can help people with diabetes. Our workshop offers a new form of diabetes therapy and peer support.

To participate in the study, you must:

Have diabetes (Type II)
Be over the age of 18
Be comfortable trying out various dance styles—no prior dance experience is necessary.
Be comfortable discussing and sharing your experiences with diabetes in a supportive group setting.
The study will consist of a baseline visit, 8 dance workshops, and a follow up visits in February through April. 

Where: Baseline visits, follow up visits, and workshop sessions will be held at the Seymour Center in Chapel Hill (2551 Homestead Road). 

When:   Tuesdays from 5:30-7.  Workshops will begin in February and end in April. 

If you are interested in the study, please respond to this survey: https://unc.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/preview/SV_2b097IM10DJLnlX?Q_CHL=preview

 

Contact information for Principal Investigator:

Jordynn Jack

512 Greenlaw Hall

Department of English and Comparative Literature

University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill

Chapel Hill, NC 27599

jjack@email.unc.edu

 

UNC IRB #170843 (non-biomedical) 

Approval date: 12/4/2018

If you are interested, please reply to this email. We will follow up with further information, including information about informed consent, confidentiality, risks, and benefits for this study.

 

Best, 


Jordynn Jack

Study Coordinator

danceanddiabetes@gmail.com

subject: 2018 University Diversity Awards
author: adrigibi
content:
2018 UNIVERSITY DIVERSITY AWARDS

CALL FOR NOMINATIONS

 Dear Carolina Community,

We invite you to nominate individuals for the annual University Diversity Awards. The award serves as an opportunity to recognize the contribution, time and effort of Carolina community members towards advancing an inclusive climate for excellence in teaching, research, public service and academic endeavor.

The University Diversity Awards committee is now accepting nominations for the award. The deadline for submissions is March 2. Awards will be given in six categories:

Faculty
Staff
Undergraduate Student
Graduate/Professional Student
Alumni
Intergroup Collaboration

Awards criteria are:

Outstanding advocate for diversity, equity, and inclusion at the interpersonal, unit and institutional level
Demonstrates a commitment to the advancement of diversity and inclusion at UNC-Chapel Hill and/or in the community through research, teaching, service and collaborative partnerships
Demonstrates a commitment to creating a culture of inclusion within their areas of influence
Implements initiatives which cultivate/advance/model diversity and inclusion within the Carolina community

Nominations can be submitted electronically at UNC 2018 Diversity Awards Nomination.


The award selection committee, made up of faculty, staff and students, will engage in a blind review of applications and apply a broad definition of diversity and inclusion for selection of finalists in each category. Further details about the award and the nomination process are available at https://diversity.unc.edu/programs/awards/.

For further information, please contact Diversity & Inclusion at diversity@unc.edu.

Sincerely,

 

G. Rumay Alexander, Chief Diversity Officer & Associate Vice Chancellor

Diversity & Inclusion

subject: Message from Chancellor Carol L. Folt
author: janerc
content:
Dear Carolina Community:

I am pleased to announce that Laurie Mesibov has agreed to take on the additional duties and responsibilities of Interim Director of the University’s Ombuds Office, effective February 8. I asked Laurie to take on this role when Wayne Blair leaves the position of director today, February 7.  

Laurie, who has worked as the Associate University Ombuds and served alongside Wayne since 2005, will be assisted by Victoria Dowd. Laurie is a long-time faculty member in our School of Government. Her leadership roles include working in the Office of the Provost from 1996-2000; serving as an advisor to the SPA Grievance Panels; and membership on the Faculty Grievance Committee, Faculty Executive Committee, and over 20 years of service on the Truman Scholarship Selection Committee. 

The University Ombuds Office plays a key role in supporting intellectual freedom, promoting personal integrity and justice, and pursuing values that foster enlightened leadership and mutually beneficial interactions between all members of our community. The office is a safe space to discuss any University-related issues, problems, or disputes and is available to all students, faculty, staff, and administrators. The Ombuds Office is also available to all units on campus for conflict management training. 

It is important to have an experienced leader with Laurie’s background and first-hand knowledge of our University’s initiatives continuing the dedicated work of the office. There is no one more capable to take on that responsibility. Laurie’s background makes her uniquely qualified to build on the reputation and record of the University Ombud’s office as a confidential and safe place to visit where all feel welcome. 

A committee has been appointed to search for candidates to lead the University’s Ombuds Office. In the meantime, I am grateful to Laurie Mesibov for assuming the interim leadership role of this critically important office that benefits all members of our campus community.

Sincerely, 

Carol L. Folt
Chancellor

subject: Stress Management Research Study for Teens
author: lynchce
content:
Got stress? Having any struggles with school, family, or friends? We are recruiting teens age 14-17 to participate in a research study to test two different courses for lowering stress and improving health and wellbeing in teens. Courses meet once a week for 8 weeks, and then once a month for 6 months after that. Refreshments will be served at classes and teens will receive up to $175 in Amazon gift cards for participating in this study.

Please contact S.M.A.R.T. Project, UNC Program on Integrative Medicine, smartstudy@med.unc.edu, 919-966-8586 to see if you’re eligible.

This study has been reviewed and approved by the UNC Biomedical Institutional Review Board (Initial approval date, 10/18/16).

IRB#: 16-1864, Study Title: Refinement of Educational Interventions to Decrease Stress and Promote Health and Wellbeing in Adolescents (aka The S.M.A.R.T. Project: Stress Management & Resilience Training for Teens).

This study is funded by the National Institutes of Health, National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health.

subject: Memory and Problem Solving Research Study
author: langella
content:
The Cognitive Neuroscience of Memory Laboratory at UNC is currently recruiting healthy older adults between the ages of 60 and 90 years who are right-handed, native English speakers with normal vision and hearing, and should have no known history of neurological injury or disease. Participants will be asked to read words, view pictures, or listen to sounds, and subsequently to make memory and problem solving judgments. The study session will take no more than two hours. You will receive $20 for your time ($10 per hour).

For further information, please contact the CNM Lab at (919-843-2117 or langella@live.unc.edu) in the Department of Psychology at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

This study has been approved on 5/15/2017 by the UNC Non-Biomedical Institutional Review Board (IRB) (study 06-0370).

content:
Morning of Mindfulness with Paula Huffman, BS, RN, ERYT  
Come to this Morning of Mindfulness to ease your stress by taking out time for yourself as you learn and practice Mindfulness Techniques that can bring benefits to your daily life! 

These practices are also great for anyone experiencing acute or chronic health issues such as insomnia, anxiety, pain, and more. 

This Morning of Mindfulness is open to all levels of practitioners. 

We will include the following:

Identifying Stress Triggers, Manifestations and Coping Mechanisms
Using Mindful Breathing to Tame the Stress Response

The Breathing Space Practice for encouraging living life OFF Auto Pilot

subject: Healthy women ages 18-75 needed for research!
author: eacarter
content:
Dr. Keely Muscatell and colleagues in UNC Chapel Hill’s Psychology and Neuroscience Department are recruiting adults between the ages of 18 and 75 years to participate in a research study.



What is the purpose of this research study?

The purpose of this study is to learn whether there are differences in cognitive functioning in adults diagnosed with breast cancer who have recently completed chemotherapy and healthy adults who do not have breast cancer.

 

Who is eligible to participate?

Healthy women ages 18-75 who do not have a diagnosis or history of breast cancer.

 

What does this research study involve?

The study involves one 2-3 session of computer tasks, iPad tasks and questionnaires.

 

Will I be compensated for participating?

Participants will receive compensation of  $25 for the session in the form of a check, plus parking compensation.

 

Are there any risks?

None of these tests are harmful or painful. You may experience some tiredness or fatigue while completing the computer tasks and questionnaires.

 

Why participate in this research study?

Your participation in this research study will help us learn more about how chemotherapy treatment for breast cancer impacts cognition.

 

How can I learn more about joining this research study?

If interested, please contact Emma at 919-962-2936 or email cancercognitionstudy@unc.edu

with the following information:

 

Subject Line: Cancer Cognition Study

Name

E-mail address

Phone number

Best time(s) to be contacted

 

This study titled “Pilot Study: Chemotherapy and Cognition” has been reviewed by the UNC non-biomedical Institutional Review Board; IRB Study #17-1730; approved 01/17/18.

subject: INFORMATIONAL Research Study Recruitment
author: bshackne
content:
Do you currently have knee osteoarthritis? Are you between the ages of 40 and 75 years old?

We are inviting people with knee osteoarthritis who are 40-75 years old to join our research study.

We are testing whether a short, intense exercise program (called high intensity interval training) helps people with knee osteoarthritis.

 The study involves:

Three in-person visits to collect information about your health and your arthritis symptoms. These visits occur before, at the mid point and after the exercise training program.
Participation in 12-weeks of one-on-one exercise training on UNC main campus.
Each exercise training session lasts 30 minutes.
Study participants must complete two sessions each week for a total of 12 weeks.
The exercise program is tailored to you based on your current fitness level and is guided by our well-trained exercise staff.

Participants will receive up to $114 for completing the research study.

If you are interested in more information, please contact Betsy Hackney at:  bshackne@email.unc.edu  or (919) 966-0574.

This study (IRB # 16-2996) was approved by the UNC Biomedical IRB on 5/9/2017

This message is sponsored by: Thurston Arthritis Research Center/UNC Exercise and Sport Science. INFORMATIONAL email will only be sent to those who have indicated that they do want to receive mass email. To set your informational mass email preference, sign into the UNC Directory at http://dir.unc.edu, login with your Onyen, and select Update Personal Information

subject: Teen Brain and Stress Study
author: hareed
content:
Parents and Mental Healthcare Providers, 

We are currently seeking adolescent males and females for an important research study examining adolescent brain function and development, and the effect of stress.


Eligibility:

 9 to 16 years old
 And have NO diagnosis of autism
And NO diagnosis of bipolar, depression or  psychosis
Have been diagnosed ADD/ADHD/Anxiety/ or Conduct Disorder
And/OR have a parent or sibling diagnosed with Schizophrenia, Schizoaffective, or Bipolar Disorder.
Study Details:

 

Study includes a 3-hour clinical interview and neurocognitive assessment at UNC, a 2-hour EEG (electroencephalography) recording at UNC, and a 4-hour MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) session at Duke. With follow-up visits at 12 and 24 months after the first visit. Participants will be compensated $50 for each visit they participate in.

 
Contact: For more information, please contact our recruitment Project Coordinator, Hannah Waltz, at 919-966-9988 or check out our website: www.cognit.unc.edu


This non-biomedical research study (IRB#13-3857) was approved by the UNC-CH on 8/17/2017.

This message is sponsored by: Department of Psychiatry
