subject: Nominations Requested: 2018 Chancellor's Awards for Excellence in Student Activities & Leadership
author: mdr7
content:
A CALL FOR NOMINATIONS: 



Dear Campus Community, 

 

The Chancellor's Awards Committee invites you to nominate students you know who have demonstrated excellence in student activities and leadership. The Carolina community will recognize these exceptional Tar Heels at the Chancellor’s Awards Ceremony on April 24, 2018, in the Great Hall of the Frank Porter Graham Student Union.

 

Students, staff, and faculty are encouraged to nominate individuals who have devoted outstanding leadership service through their involvement in residential and Greek life, student self-governance, and through their academic careers in the humanities, sciences and social sciences. Nominations for the awards are open to the University until 5:00 pm on February 9th.

 

Following the presentation of student awards, exceptional professors and teaching assistants will be recognized with the Student Undergraduate Teaching Awards (SUTASA). Those who are awarded can be nominated by undergraduate students through typed nominations submitted to the SUTASA co-chairs, a committee made up entirely of undergraduate students, who will select the finalists.

 

Nominate a fellow Tar Heel today:      bit.ly/2018chancellorsawards

 

Sincerely, 

VC Crisp

subject: Hidradenitis Suppurativa (HS) Research Study
author: lmcleod
content:
Hidradenitis Suppurativa (HS) Research Study

 

Are you suffering from Hidradenitis Suppurativa, also known as HS? If so, you may be eligible to try an investigational injectable medication!

 

Subject must:

Be 18 to 70 years of age
Be diagnosed with Hidradenitis for at least one year
Be in general good health
Have had no previous treatment with Humira
Be willing to take injections of investigational medication
Be able to attend 12 visits over the course of 34 weeks at UNC Dermatology Department

 

Subject will:

Receive study medication and skin assessments at no charge
Receive compensation for travel to and participation in clinic visits

 

For more information, please contact:

Laura Keck

UNC Dermatology and Skin Cancer Center

Study Coordinator

Phone: 984-974-3682

Email: lmcleod@email.unc.edu

This e-mail is sponsored by: UNC Department of Dermatology

subject: UNC Aquatics Swim Lessons For All Ages
author: crayers
content:
Looking for quality swim lessons for you or a family member?  Now is the time to get ready for summer swimming fun!





UNC Campus Recreation’s Aquatics program is now offering swim lessons for all levels at affordable rates! Registration for classes is open to UNC students, faculty and staff and to the surrounding communities.




 Lessons are being offered for Spring 2018 on Monday/Wednesday evenings as well as Saturday mornings.  We have lessons available for Parent/Child (6 months to 35 months) level,  preschool (3-5 years old), youth (6-12 years old), and adult levels (13-99 years old). Private and semi-private swim lessons are also available. Prices vary based on the swim level and lesson duration, and Campus Recreation members receive discounted pricing.




 For more information on swim levels, schedules, and registration, please visit http://campusrec.unc.edu/programs/aquatics/programs-classes/


or email uncaquatics@unc.edu





We look forward to getting you in Carolina Blue water!

subject: American Red Cross Lifeguarding Classes
author: crayers
content:
Campus Recreation, UNC Aquatics is offering American Red Cross Lifeguarding certification and recertification weekend courses this semester!

 

Our classes cover all of the information required to get certified in American Red Cross Lifeguarding, First Aid, CPR/AED for 2 years.  Our full course is offered in a Blended Learning format with some work completed online at home prior to meeting with an instructor.  The in-person portion of the training takes a single weekend!




If you need to recertify for your summer job, our recertification course involves meeting with an instructor to go over the skills and information in 1 day.   Participation in this class requires candidates to be currently certified or within 30 days of expiration.  Successful completion recertifies lifeguards for an additional 2 years!


 

If you were looking for that perfect summer job, here is your chance to get ready to enjoy the sun and save lives!  Check out our available dates by visiting:

http://campusrec.unc.edu/program/lifeguarding/http://campusrec.unc.edu/program/lifeguarding/


 

Email uncaquatics@unc.edu with questions!

subject: UNC Galapagos Summer Study Abroad - 2018
author: philpage
content:
Dear Carolina Students-

Interested in the environment, islands, oceans, and special equatorial places?   Please consider studying abroad in the UNC Galapagos Summer Study Abroad program in Summer 2018!!

The program consists of two UNC-credit classes (6 credit hours total) taught by UNC faculty in Geography and Environmental Sciences and Engineering. The courses (GEOG and ENVR/ENEC) are a mix of classroom time and fieldwork in the very special Galapagos archipelago.  You'll spend time everywhere from the water to the highlands on these charismatic volcanic islands.

Please see the linked information for details, or you can also contact Jerri Snyder (jerri@email.unc.edu) or Phil Page (philpage@unc.edu) with questions.

subject: LGBQ Couples Counseling
author: pentel
content:
Do you and your romantic partner both identify as women?

Are you interested in learning skills to improve/strengthen your relationship?

Do you disagree on topics related to being in a same-sex relationship (e.g., who to come out to or how to find a supportive social network)?

If you are both age 21+, the ACCESS Program may be right for you! We provide no-cost therapy specifically designed to meet the needs of LGBQ women. ACCESS stands for Affirming Couples Counseling to Engage Same-Sex partners. This is a treatment research study.

Check out our website: ACCESSprogram.web.unc.edu

Questions? Interested in a screening phone call to determine if you're eligible? Contact Kim Pentel (she/her) at ACCESSprogram@unc.edu with subject line "ACCESS." All inquiries are confidential.

ACCESS is led by a queer therapist in the Psychology and Neurosciences Department at the University of North Carolina. Our team has received training in LGBQ competence. We are passionate about providing a safe space for you and your loved one. We are proud to serve couples from diverse backgrounds.

Study Title: ACCESS: Affirming Couple Counseling to Engage Same-Sex partners. UNC-CH IRB #: 17-2482, Non-biomedical. Date Approved: October 17, 2017.

subject: Help us learn about puberty!
author: ehburnet
content:
Subject/Title: Help us learn about puberty!

Starting at puberty, girls are more than twice as likely to be diagnosed with a mood disorder as boys. The goal of the EVOLVE study is to understand the impact of changing hormones, stress, and brain function on mood symptoms during the pubertal transition.

We are currently seeking adolescent females between the ages of 12 and 14 who are undergoing a healthy pubertal transition and are not currently taking any prescription medications (including hormonal contraceptives). Participants must be comfortable with blood draws.

Participation includes:

Enrollment and interview session
8 weekly hormone measurements
Cognitive-emotional processing and electroencephalogram (EEG) session
Study participation duration is 10 weeks

Compensation for time and effort is available.

For more information, please visit the EVOLVE study website evolvestudy.web.unc.edu, or contact Dr. Elizabeth Andersen at (919) 904-4876.

Click here to check eligibility: UNC EVOLVE Study


This research study was approved by the UNC Biomedical IRB (#17-2173). This email text was approved by the IRB on 1/30/2018.

subject: Movement Biomechanics Research Study in Male Athletes Age 15-28
author: lestanle
content:
Hello!

My name is Laura Stanley, and I am a graduate student at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. I am writing to recruit participants for a research study entitled The Acute Effects of an Isometric Loading Intervention on Lower Extremity Landing Biomechanics in Individuals with Patellar Tendinopathy. This research is supported by the Foundation for Physical Therapy, and will be conducted by researchers from the University of North Carolina in the Department of Exercise and Sport Science. This project has received ethics approval from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Biomedical Institutional Review Board (IRB #17-1731, approval date 9/15/17).

Knee tendon pain, or tendinopathy, is common in athletes participating in sports that involve high volumes of jumping, landing, and cutting. Little is known about how movement biomechanics differ between individuals with and without tendinopathy, and if using simple leg strengthening exercises can influence movement biomechanics. The purpose of this study is to investigate differences in biomechanical and cumulative external load profiles, and the acute response to isometric loading in individuals with and without patellar tendinopathy. We are recruiting male athletes both with and without tendinopathy, between 15-28 years-old, and who are currently participating in competitive sports. 

This study will be conducted via three testing sessions during which we will measure the structure of the patellar tendon using non-invasive ultrasound, assessing knee pain symptoms, tracking physical activity for a one-week period, and evaluating the effects of a simple leg strengthening exercise protocol on movement profiles using motion capture technology. Eligible participants will be compensated $75 for participation.

We would love to provide you with further information on this research study. If you are interested in learning more, please contact me at lstanley@unc.edu (email).

Thank you! 

Laura Stanley PT, DPT, SCS

PhD Candidate, Human Movement Science

The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

Sports Medicine Research Laboratory

Office: 919.962.7187

Email: lstanley@unc.edu

subject: Join the Carolina Community at the annual Eve Carson Lecture Series with Kathy Izard!
author: jtblount
content:
Join the Carolina Community at the annual Eve Marie Carson Lecture featuring Kathy Izard on February 22, 2018 at 6 p.m.!

The Speakers Committee of the UNC Executive Branch is thrilled to welcome Kathy Izard to Carolina to speak as a part of the Eve Marie Carson Lecture series. 

Kathy Izard -- the founder of Moore Place, a home for chronically homeless men and women in Charlotte, and author of The Hundred Story Home, a book about finding faith in yourself and in something bigger – will give the annual Eve Marie Carson Lecture at 6 p.m. on Thursday, February 22, 2018 at Moeser Auditorium in UNC’s Hill Hall.  

The Eve Marie Carson Annual Lecture Series seeks to stimulate a community-wide dialogue on contemporary issues and is free and open to the public. 

The Eve Marie Carson Annual Lecture series invites someone who has distinguished themselves through their ideals and accomplishments to Carolina to lecture on a contemporary issue. The lecture series was founded by former student body president Eve Carson and continues today in her memory. Previous speakers include, Robert Gibbs, Rye Barcott, Ping Fu, and Frank Bruni.

The event is sponsored by the Executive Branch of UNC Student Government and funded by the Carolina Women’s Leadership Council.

subject: Research Study Recruitment
author: mstansbu
content:
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill is seeking volunteers for a research study testing the effectiveness of the medication bupropion to help reduce heavy drinking.   Heavy drinking is a common problem involving consumption of 4 drinks for woman or 5 drinks for man in about a 2 hour period leading to intoxication.

 

You may be able to participate in this new research study if:

 

You are concerned about your drinking
Drinking is having a negative impact on your life
You want to change the amount of alcohol you drink

 

The study will involve a free evaluation and, if you qualify, free support sessions to help you reduce the amount of alcohol you drink.





You will be compensated up to $350 depending on your level of participation. This is a double-blind, placebo-controlled study, meaning that you could be taking the medication bupropion, or a placebo. Participants are monitored by a research team in the UNC Department of Psychiatry under the direction of JC Garbutt, MD.

 

If interested, please call 919-966-0011 or take our online prescreen here: https://unc.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_0kwCKGl0ynl7ZAN


(you may need to cut and paste the link into your browser)

 

Additional information available at: www.uncalcoholstudy.com


 

This study was approved by the Biomedical IRB on 1/5/1018. (IRB# 16-1064)

subject: Research Study - Short Survey for $50 raffle
author: ameleak
content:
Dear Participant,
 
My name is Amelea Kim and I am a graduate student at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in the School of Information and Library Science. I am conducting a research study on overdue fines in the academic libraries at UNC, specifically at the Undergraduate Library (UL).

As such, I am looking for volunteers to fill out a 10-minute survey asking about their experiences with fines at the UL. If you complete the survey and write your name, you will automatically be entered into a raffle for one of two $50 Amazon gift cards that will be awarded at the end of the survey collection period.

By clicking here https://unc.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_3wIlw3AjpaJlnHT and completing the survey, you agree to be a participant in this study.

The survey will ask you questions about your experiences with the UL’s overdue fines policy and is completely voluntary. You may choose not to participate or stop taking the survey at anytime. All possible measures have been taken to protect the confidentiality of your answers.
 
I will report only summaries of the aggregated data.  This means that your responses will be combined with all of the other responses received and will not be able to be identified as yours. Deductive disclosure which is the discerning of an individual respondent's identity and responses through the use of known characteristics of that individual is also possible but unlikely.
 
If you have any questions regarding this survey, you may contact me via email at ameleak@email.unc.edu.

All research on human volunteers is reviewed by a committee that works to protect your rights and welfare. This non-biomedical study, ID 17 - 2654, was approved on 1/26/2018 by the Office of Human Research Ethics at UNC-Chapel Hill. If you have any questions or concerns regarding your rights as a research subject you may contact, anonymously if you wish, the Institutional Review Board at (919) 966-3113 or via email at IRB_subjects@unc.edu with study number 17 – 2654.

Thank you,

Amelea Kim

subject: Mental Health Memos
author: faithn12
content:
Good afternoon, 

Our organization, Mental Health Ambassadors, strives to encourage open dialogue about mental health and familiarize students with a variety of counseling resources on campus. 

As part of this mission, we have created a variety of memos on several mental health issues students may face during their years at Carolina. Topics include: Chronic stress, eating disorders, exam stress and student failure. 

Each memo includes a list of behaviors to look for and tips on how to address the issue. As professors, we encourage you to implement these into your Sakai pages or future syllabi. 

Professors have a profound effect on the college experience. Students interact with faculty daily and build trusting relationships with their professors. Due to the daily interaction students have with faculty, it is likely professors may notice these mental health concerns in their students and have the opportunity to intervene. 

For these reasons, we have attached the memos here and encourage their use in creating a dialogue on campus and ensuring the mental wellness of every student on campus. 

The memos are linked here.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

subject: Flu Prevention on Campus
author: alreid
content:
Dear Faculty, Staff and Students:

Influenza, “flu,” activity continues to increase and is widespread in 49 states, including North Carolina. The flu is a contagious respiratory illness caused by Influenza viruses, which can cause mild to severe illness. The best way to prevent the flu is by getting vaccinated each year. The season can last until May, so there is still time to get vaccinated.

Flu vaccinations are still available at the Student Stores Pharmacy and Campus Health Pharmacy for students, faculty and staff. Or, you can find a flu clinic off campus by going to flu.nc.gov.

Help prevent the spread of the flu on campus by recognizing the symptoms and staying at home. The flu spreads by coughing and sneezing and by touching infected surfaces. Someone with the flu can be infectious one day before symptoms and up to seven days after becoming ill.

Take actions to reduce the spread of germs: 

Stay home until 24 hours after your fever is gone, except to seek medical care.
Cover your nose and mouth with a tissue when you cough or sneeze and put your used tissue in a wastebasket.
Cough or sneeze into your upper sleeve — not your hands — if you don’t have a tissue.
Wash your hands often with soap and water, especially after you cough or sneeze. Alcohol-based hand sanitizers can be used if soap and water are not available. 
Stay healthy by getting adequate sleep, eating nutrient-dense foods and staying hydrated.
Learn more at Campus Health’s website and at flu.unc.edu.

subject: Carolina Adventures Custom Group Programs
author: jjhalsey
content:
Is your organization or department looking for an exciting, challenging, and fun activity to spark growth in your team?


UNC Campus Recreation's Carolina Adventures Program offers group events, workshops, and outings at the Outdoor Education Center Challenge Course, our two on campus climbing walls, and off campus through our Expeditions. More information about Carolina Adventures can be found at http://campusrec.unc.edu/programs/carolinaadventures/.



Challenge Course:

In addition to ground level team building opportunities that have served the UNC community for the past 20 years, the UNC Challenge Course team recently renovated its high ropes course and created the new Tar Heel Towers.  Featuring 11 elements over three different height levels, Tar Heel Towers can accomodate up to 48 participants at a time in groups of four to eight people moving through the course as a single unit.  Each Tar Heel Towers element creates opportunities to develop better communication, increase empathy, focus on strategy development, and gain a clearer understanding of your team's strengths and growth opportunities.

For more information about how to create and reserve your customized Challenge Course experience, please contact David Rogers, Assistant Director of Challenge Course Programs, at challengecourse@unc.edu or 919-843-4632.



Expeditions:

Expeditions are structured to promote a sense of community, leadership, and fun on any of our half-day, full day, or overnight programs.  We offer hiking, stand up paddleboarding, kayaking, climbing, and backpacking trips to various locations near UNC and across North Carolina.  We also offer open enrollment programs exclusively for graduate and professional school students.  All of our programs can be customized to meet your group's needs and learning objectives.

For more information about how to create and reserve your customized expedition, please contact Shane Ambro, Expeditions Coordinator, at shanea@email.unc.edu or 919-843-3233.



Climbing:

UNC Climbing Programs offers different ways for individuals and groups to experience the sport.

Group Events:  Come share a new expereience with a group of friends or colleagues at one of our two on campus climbing walls.  Two hour exclusive climbing events are a great way to bring a little adventure into your everyday lives.

Lunch Time Climb: No Recreation or Climbing membership, no problem.  Staff and Faculty can try out Ram's Head Climbing Wall from 11:00 am - 3:00 pm every Friday without a recreation membership (UNC ID required).  Participants will be given an orientation to the facility and will be climbing in no time.  Equipment is provided at no charge during this period.

For more information on our Climbing programs and opportunities, please contact Russell Hobart, Assistant Director of Climbing Programs at rhhobart@email.unc.edu or 919-843-4795.

subject: INFORMATIONAL FOR A RESEARCH STUDY
author: khmills
content:
Investigators at the UNC Center for Environmental Medicine, Asthma and Lung Biology
are screening asthmatic individuals to see how they respond to wood smoke inhalation when riding a stationary bicycle.

 

Contact

	

Call 919-843-6598 or e-mail smokescreen@med.unc.edu





Requirements

	
You must be between 18 and 45
You must have mild asthma
Women who are pregnant or nursing a baby cannot participate
You must not any orthopedic limitations
You must not smoke



Time Commitment

	

There is a 4 hour long General Screening visit (IRB #98-0799). Then there are 3 visits over a 1 month period.  The first visit will last about 4 hours, the next visit will be for a full day, and you will return the following day for about 2 ½ hours.




Compensation

	

Complete General Screen research study visit $75

3 Smokescreen research study visits at EPA building on UNC campus for up to $400.00

 

IRB #15-1775:  To identify persons who are susceptible to wood smoke particulate-induced inflammation and examine the role of GSTM1 and other factors in this susceptibility.

 

Approved 01/18/2018 by the Biomedical Institutional Review Board.

 

This e-mail is sponsored by the UNC Center for Environmental Medicine, Asthma and Lung Biology

content:
Humanities for the Public Good Critical Issues Award for Collaborative Projects  - Call for Applications

Funds: Collaborative projects around the theme of “Migration & Mobility,” for programs, workshops, lectures, performance, art-making, exhibitions, or other activities or events which connect campus resources and humanistic knowledge or methods with publics beyond the campus. Projects may be at any stage from early planning to implementation and assessment.

Amount: Up to $10,000

Eligibility: Collaborative team includes a faculty member of any rank in a humanities department (including humanistic social scientists) or post-doctoral scholar; an on-campus partner; and an off-campus partner. Funding may be used for costs associated with meetings and events, non-infrastructural supplies, and to defray the time and labor costs of collaborators or participants. Application Deadline: March 9th.


Information Session: February 8th at noon in the Donovan Lounge; please RSVP here.

subject: INFORMATIONAL: Residential Environment, Allostatic Load and Diseases – RENALDI study
author: peugenia
content:
The purpose of this research study is to learn how air pollution levels, parks and green spaces, and lifestyle affect health. The study involves measuring substances in blood and saliva samples called “biomarkers of health”. These biomarkers are naturally produced by the human body in response to stress and disease. The study is conducted by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).

You may be able to take part in the study if you are:

An adult of at least 18 years of age
Live in the Raleigh-Durham-Chapel Hill, NC metropolitan area
Have lived at your current address for at least three years
 

You will be asked to:

Visit EPA Human Studies Facility at 104 Mason Farm Road, Chapel Hill
Complete a questionnaire
Complete simple physical examination
Have blood drawn and collect saliva for analysis of biomarkers of health
You may also be asked to collect a stool sample at home
You may also be asked, within a year after completing this initial survey, to participate in a follow-up study involving four more visits to EPA.
 

You will receive $ 100 for participating in this study. If you participate in a fecal microbiome survey, you will receive $ 75. If you enroll in the follow-up survey, you will receive $ 420 for completing all procedures.

 

Our office hours are Monday-Friday from 8am to 5pm EST.

 

Contact telephone numbers:

919-966-0604 (local)

1-888-279-9353 (toll free)

More information at https://epastudies.org/

 

Approved January 10, 2018, by the Office of Human Research Ethics (OHRE) Biomedical Institutional Review Board. IRB # 17-1981.

This email is sponsored by: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Environmental Public Health Division located on the UNC-Chapel Hill campus

subject: Meet with a CAPTRUST Financial Advisor
author: kirkkm
content:
CAPTRUST Financial Advisors, the independent advisory firm that works on the UNC retirement programs, will be visiting UNC-Chapel Hill conducting on site individual advisory sessions on Jan. 25, Feb. 1, Feb. 7, Feb. 14, Feb. 28 and March 15 at 104 Airport Drive, Chapel Hill, NC in Room 1501-C. Topics covered in the 45-minute individual advisory sessions include, but are not limited to, the following:

Retirement planning
General financial planning
Debt management
Investment education and advice
You also will have an opportunity to create a Retirement Blueprint, CAPTRUST’s new interactive retirement readiness tool. To learn more about the Blueprint you can view a short, informative video by clicking here. These one-on-one sessions are offered to you solely as a benefit; be assured that CAPTRUST’s role is not to sell you anything, but purely to help you make sound investment decisions.

 Learn more about Blueprint

Schedule an Appointment
Visit this link
Choose your location
Choose the 45-minute session you wish to attend
Enter your information and click “Schedule It” (a confirmation email will then be sent immediately)
Note:

A reminder email will also be sent 24 hours in advance of the meeting.
If you need to cancel or change your meeting time, click the link received in the confirmation/reminder email. Then enter your last name and confirmation number.
Be Prepared
To best be prepared for these sessions, please make sure you have the information you want to include in your Blueprint calculations, such as retirement account balances and current contributions to retirement accounts. You will also want to bring login information for your retirement website.

Can’t Make it to Campus?
If you cannot make a live session, but still want to create a Blueprint or need further advice, the CAPTRUST Advice Desk is also available. Appointments can be made with the Advice Desk by visiting www.captrustadvice.com.

Questions?
If you have any questions or need assistance, please call CAPTRUST at 800.967.9948.

subject: INFORMATIONAL: Do You Eat Ocean Fish or Consume Fish Oil Supplements?
author: peugenia
content:
This research study will examine the effects of dietary omega-3 fatty acids in protecting cardiopulmonary function from ambient air pollution in adults. Healthy, nonsmoking, physically active, adults ages 25 to 55 will be screened for dietary intake of omega-3 fatty acids and blood omega-3 index. Qualified subjects either have a high intake of fish from dietary sources or fish oil supplements, OR have a low dietary intake of fish.  Breathing, blood draw, heart rate tests, retinal imaging and brachial artery ultrasound will be performed.  For more information, please visit our web site at www.epastudies.org or call FEFA EPA Recruiting at 919-966-0604.

Approved April 26, 2017, by the Office of Human Research Ethics (OHRE) Biomedical Institutional Review Board. IRB # 16-1048.

This email is sponsored by: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Environmental Public Health Division located on the UNC-Chapel Hill campus.

subject: DO YOU HAVE PROBLEMS WITH LOW MOTIVATION? DO YOU FIND IT HARD TO ENJOY THINGS IN YOUR EVERYDAY LIFE?
author: memclamb
content:
DO YOU HAVE PROBLEMS WITH LOW MOTIVATION?

DO YOU FIND IT HARD TO ENJOY THINGS IN YOUR EVERYDAY LIFE?

The Department of Psychiatry at both Duke and UNC-CH are working together on a research study to help develop new interventions for people who are experiencing low levels of motivation and pleasure.

 

We are looking for people between the ages of 18-50 who are not currently taking any psychiatric medications and/or not currently in psychotherapy and are experiencing symptoms of low motivation and pleasure. Symptoms of low motivation and pleasure can include not wanting to be with other people, not wanting to participate in activities that you previously enjoyed, and feeling numb to the joys of life. Volunteers must be willing to provide informed consent to complete an initial clinical interview, questionnaires regarding mood, anxiety, quality of life, brain scans before and after treatment, and the possibility of two additional brain scans during treatment.

There is no cost to participate.
You will receive up to 15 psychotherapy sessions from a Duke clinician.
You will receive compensation for the portions of the study you complete.
To see if you qualify, complete this online survey: https://redcap.unc.edu/surveys/?s=NN99MR9EA8

 

UNC-CH Biomedical IRB approved on 9/1/17 IRB Number: 16-2268

subject: Participate in a study on how the arts influence socially relevant attitudes
author: kentl
content:
This is a nonbiomedical, multipart research study (IRB# 16-1786; Approved on 9/18/2017) looking at how the arts influence attitudes about socially relevant topics with the opportunity to earn up to $75. As a part of this study, you would complete three surveys about socially sensitive topics. Additionally, you may be asked to attend performances sponsored by the Carolina Performing Arts on campus. This study will require your participation through the semester and into the summer months although you do not have to be on-site at UNC to participate. (Summer activities would consist of on-line surveys only.)

 

For more information, please contact Ariana Rivens a member of our research team at ari76@live.unc.edu.

subject: Now accepting nominations for 2019 Honorary Degrees
author: turnerkm
content:
The Office of Faculty Governance, on behalf of the Committee on Honorary Degrees and Special Awards, is now accepting candidates for UNC honorary degrees to be awarded at the 2019 May Commencement ceremony.

A maximum of five of these prestigious awards will be given to recognize individuals who have rendered outstanding service to humanity in the world arena, in our nation, in the American South, or our State of North Carolina; people who have made outstanding contributions to knowledge in the world of scholarship; people whose talent and creativity in the world of the arts has enriched our lives; and people whose devotion to and support of our University merits our highest recognition.

It is important to note that members of the Board of Governors or staff of the University of North Carolina or any of its constituent institutions are not eligible. These persons become eligible two years after termination of such status. Awards are not conferred in absentia or posthumously.

The deadline for nominations this year is February 19, 2018

Full information about this award, including criteria, eligibility, and the process for submitting a nomination is available at https://facultygov.unc.edu/awards/honorary-degrees/.

subject: A Message from the Vice Chancellor for IT
author: hashk
content:
Dear Carolina Community, 

I am writing to inform you of our plans to expand the use of 2-Step Verification on campus in 2018. This continues the work that ITS has already completed to put select digital resources, such as the online W2, VPN and administrative IT applications, behind 2-Step Verification protection. A great many in our community are routinely using 2-Step Verification successfully today. 

We do, however, need 2-Step Verification in more places. As many of you saw over the 2017 Thanksgiving break, criminals continue to use phishing messages to access accounts. This is true at UNC-Chapel Hill and across higher education. In November 2017, phishers successfully compromised several hundred Onyens and passwords by phishing student, faculty and staff accounts. Criminals used that access to launch thousands of additional attacks here on campus. 2-Step Verification would have stopped these attacks, saved our community the headaches associated with re-authenticating accounts, and saved the University time and money.   

What is 2-Step Verification? 

2-Step Verification -- also called multifactor or two-factor authentication -- is an additional layer of protection for your accounts. 2-Step Verification utilizes something you know (your Onyen and password) and something you have (e.g. your phone).  

Many of you are likely already using 2-Step Verification for online activity with bank accounts, credit cards and personal email accounts. If you've received a code sent to your phone before you could sign in to an account, you have used 2-Step Verification. 

Why is 2-Step Verification Important? 

The main benefit of activating 2-Step is that it significantly increases the protection of your account from hackers. Here’s how that is achieved: 

2-Step adds an extra barrier between your personal information and unwarranted access. To access your account, criminals would need to know your username and password as well as a security code; 
2-Step can help keep criminals from accessing your email, documents, payroll, personal information or research data, even if your Onyen and password have been stolen; 
2-Step requires a unique security code each time your account is accessed on a non-trusted device, application or web browser. 
Action Required 

Our 2018 implementations begin with a focus on student use of Office 365 and ConnectCarolina access. In the coming weeks and months, students will hear more about 2-Step Verification, including how to activate 2-Step, how to set up devices, how to find support and other valuable information. Students should pay close attention to those messages, as they will provide essential instructions for securing accounts. Faculty and staff will hear more about expanded use of 2-Step later this year. 

We all have a role in protecting the digital assets and resources of the University. We appreciate your support and collaboration as we introduce additional digital security measures to keep our campus safe. 

Regards, 

Chris Kielt 

Vice Chancellor for Information Technology and Chief Information Officer

subject: Free Mental Health First Aid training - Available Only for a Limited Time
author: vglinebe
content:
Mental Health First Aid
for UNC Chapel Hill Faculty and Staff

Mental Health First Aid training will be offered at no cost to UNC Chapel Hill faculty and staff until September 2018.  

Mental Health First Aid teaches participants how to recognize and help when a person is experiencing one of five common mental health concerns: anxiety, depression, substance use, bipolar disorder, and schizophrenia.  This 8-hour course uses skills practice and simulations to demonstrate how to offer help in a mental health or substance use crisis through a 5-step action plan, with the ultimate goal of encouraging self-help, social support, and use of appropriate professional care.  

 New sessions are now available for February and March. Sessions are scheduled at varying times and locations throughout campus. Training options include a full day, two half-days, or Saturdays. To find a convenient date and time, and to register, visit: http://ssw.unc.edu/sswevents/mhfa-training  

 To request training for your specific group, contact the Behavioral Health Springboard of the School of Social Work at joflick@email.unc.edu

Please take advantage of this valuable training while we are still able to provide it to the university community at no cost!

subject: Invitation to Participate: Library Science Survey Study
author: tbowser
content:
Dear Student,

My name is Todd Bowser and I am a graduate student in the School of Library and Information Science at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. I am performing a study of library instruction programming efforts focused on first-year students and library staff in the UNC system.

I am interested in your ideas about your experience with research in your first year of college, and what help you have had getting familiar with the library and other information resources that are available to you. My study looks at information literacy courses created for college-bound high school students as part of an academic library’s public service model. No matter where you went to high school, and whether you have had such courses or not, you can be helpful to this study.

I would appreciate a few moments of your time to complete a brief survey. It should take ten minutes or less. Your responses are voluntary and will remain anonymous.

Upon completion, you may enter contact information on a separate form for a chance to win a $25 gift card. Your contact info will not be connected with your survey responses. Responses will be compiled and analyzed as a group.

Click this link to take the survey. (You must be at least 18 years old to participate.)

If you have any questions, feel free to contact me via e-mail at tbowser@live.unc.edu, or at 336-875-9674.

 

Thank you for your time, and have a great semester!

 

Todd Bowser

MSLS Candidate 2016-2018

School of Information and Library Science

University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

 

UNC IRB number: 17-3053
Non-Biomedical
Action Date: 1/8/2018
Study Status: exempt
Administering Dept: School of Information and Library Science

subject: Tartuffe & The Christians: PlayMakers' Double-header - $10
author: rosalie
content:
For less than the price of a movie ticket you can see the kind of show that Broadway wishes it had! PlayMakers is proud to offer $10 student tickets all season long. Start your semester off right with not one, but two plays in rotation that offer the best the of old and new: a madcap runway romp through Molière’s classic comedy Tartuffe and The Christians, an award-winning contemporary drama.

A rich fool, an religious con man, a thwarted love affair, and the unflappable woman who is determined to set them all straight come to vibrant life in David Ball’s new adaptation of Tartuffe. In The Christians, Tony-nominated playwright Lucas Hnath asks, “How much are you willing to give up for what you believe?” as certainty and doubt come to a head for one megachurch pastor and his congregation.

See one. See both. Bring a friend and immerse yourself in the storytelling experience that has remained central to the human experience since the the first “big fish” story ever told.

These stories about both the ridiculous and sobering sides of faith, doubt, and following are both on stage in rotation from February 1 through March 11.

NEW THIS SEASON: Login with your ONYEN to purchase tickets online! Or you can always visit or call the Box Office: 919.962.7529.

For more information, visit our website.

subject: Section 403(b) Plan Universal Availability Notice for 2018
author: kirkkm
content:
The University of North Carolina offers a choice of voluntary supplemental retirement programs so employees can save additional amounts for retirement. Under The University of North Carolina Section 403(b) Plan (“the 403(b) Plan”), eligible employees may elect to defer a portion of their compensation to the 403(b) Plan on a pre-tax or post-tax (Roth) basis.

The 403(b) Plan is designed to help you invest more money today so that you have the income you need in your retirement years. It provides a supplement to either the N.C. Teachers’ and State Employees’ Retirement System or the UNC Optional Retirement Program, the State’s mandatory retirement plans available to permanent employees who work 30 or more hours per week. Moreover, even employees not eligible for one of the mandatory retirement plans may also be able to make voluntary contributions to the 403(b) Plan.

Eligibility
All employees, other than UNC HealthCare employees, who receive compensation reportable on a Form W-2 and pay FICA (Social Security) tax are eligible to participate in the 403(b) Plan, so long as the employee elects to contribute at least $200 each calendar year.

Contributions
An eligible employee may elect to defer a portion of his or her compensation on a pre-tax or post-tax (Roth) basis.

Pre-tax Contributions
Both federal and state income taxes are deferred on the contributions and any earnings until distributed from the Plan. Distributions are taxable as ordinary income for federal and state income tax purposes. Generally, a participant must begin receiving a distribution by April 1 following the later of the year in they turn age 70½ or terminate employment with The University.

Post-tax Contributions (Roth)
Federal and state income taxes are withheld from Roth contributions at the time that they are contributed to the Plan. Contributions are not taxed again at distribution.

Moreover, any earnings on the contributions are never subject to federal and state income taxes upon distribution, as long as a five year period has passed since Roth contributions were first made to the Plan and the distribution is a “qualified distribution”. A qualified distribution is a distribution (i) made on or after the date on which the participant attains age 59 ½, (ii) made to a beneficiary on or after the death of the participant, or (iii) made on or after the participant becomes disabled.

Contribution Limits
Annual contribution limits are set by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). The IRS allows an eligible employee to make an additional catch-up contribution beginning in the year in which he or she turns age 50. For 2018, the calendar year limits under the 403(b) Plan is as follows:

Calendar Year Annual Contribution Limit:

$18,500*

Age 50+ Catch-up Contribution Limit:

$6,000*

*Note: This is a combined limit for pre-tax and Roth after-tax contributions.

Approved Vendors
The University has approved Fidelity Investments and TIAA as the two financial services companies offering options under the 403(b) Plan. Fidelity and TIAA provide a wide range of mutual fund investment options and annuity products through their own funds as well as other investment managers.

Both companies offer resources and tools to help participants plan their investment strategy. Eligible employees should contact each vendor for information about plan investment options and services provided.

Fidelity Investments

1-800-343-0860

TIAA

1-800-842-2252

Enrollment Process
Eligible employees may enroll immediately upon date of hire or at any time. To start the enrollment process, please visit the UNC System Voluntary 403(b) Retirement Program webpage and follow the steps listed:

Step 1 – Complete a Salary Reduction Agreement (SRA) (forms and instructions available on the website)
Step 2 – Enroll in the plan with Fidelity and/or TIAA
Contributions may be designated as a percent of salary or as a flat dollar amount depending on your campus payroll capability. The SRA will apply only to amounts earned after enrolling in the Plan, and an employee’s election under the SRA will continue until the SRA is modified or revoked by the employee.

Modifying a Deferral Election
An eligible employee may increase, decrease or stop his or her future contributions to the plan at any time by completing an SRA. Employees may also change from one vendor to another at any time by completing an SRA to stop contributions with the existing vendor, and following the steps above to enter into a new agreement with another vendor. It is also possible to make contributions to more than one vendor at a time.

More Information
If you have questions about the 403(b) Plan, please contact your campus Benefits Representative or visit the UNC System Voluntary 403(b) Retirement Program webpage.

 

This notice is provided as a source of information and does not constitute legal, tax or other professional advice. If legal advice, tax advice or other professional assistance is required, the services of a professional advisor should be sought. Every effort has been made to make this notice as thorough and accurate as possible. However, there are other legal documents, laws, and regulations that govern the operation of the Program. It is understood that in the event of any conflict, the terms of the Plan Document, applicable laws, and regulations will govern.

subject: Tartuffe & The Christians: PlayMakers' Double-header - 10% Off!
author: rosalie
content:
Get ready for the PlayMakers event of the season! With your UNC Faculty/Staff Discount, you get 10% OFF tickets to PlayMakers’ rotating repertory of plays. Immerse yourself in not just one, but two plays that explore faith and following with Lucas Hnath’s The Christians and Molière’s Tartuffe.

Fall for Molière’s Tartuffe all over again in a new adaptation by David Ball. The man of the house has lost his mind and only his unflappable wife can set him straight. It’s a madcap comedy of religious proportions that will make you laugh until you cry and pray for more!

Certainty and doubt come to a head in The Christians as Pastor Paul gets ready to preach a sermon that will rock the foundations of his church—and his family. This compassionate, nuanced look at faith in America by Tony Award-nominated playwright Lucas Hnath asks, “How much are you willing to give up for what you believe?”

See one. See both. Think theatre and be a part of the conversation.

Both The Christians and Tartuffe run February 1 through March 11 in rotating repertory, so you’ve got plenty of options. To save even more, make a point to see the show while it’s still in previews, February 1–9, when tickets are already up to 20% less.

NEW THIS SEASON: Login with your ONYEN and receive the faculty/staff discount online! Or you can always visit or call the Box Office: 919.962.7529.

For more information, visit our website.

subject: Recruiting: The Microbiota-Gut-Brain Axis and Postpartum Depression Study
author: hsr4888
content:
The Microbiota-Gut-Brain Axis and Postpartum Depression



Would you be willing to help UNC researchers better understand how the bacteria that live in your gut may impact your risk of developing Postpartum Depression?

  

Microorganisms (such as bacteria) reside almost everywhere in and on the human body, outnumbering human cells by a ratio of at least 10:1.  There are 100+ trillion of these microbes in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract alone!  The purpose of this research study is to analyze the microorganisms residing in the gut of pregnant women and to see if the microorganisms differ in those that develop Postpartum Depression. Researchers from UNC Department of Psychiatry hope to better understand the relationship of the gut and the brain and how that changes in pregnancy.  We hope this knowledge will lead to personalized treatments including diet recommendations.

 

ARE YOU…... In the 1st trimester or the 2nd trimester of pregnancy?

IF SO………?... Please call 919-445-2729 or email microbiomestudy@med.unc.edu 

  

All study visits and medical evaluations related to this study will be providedat no cost to participants. This study requires 3 visits to UNC (in the 1st trimester or the 2nd trimester, in the 3rd trimester and at 6-8 weeks postpartum) and 1 visit over the phone (about one week postpartum). $300 compensation.

 

Biomedical IRB Study # 16-0959: The Microbiota-Gut-Brain Axis and Postpartum Depression, P.I. Kimmel, Mary, NIH 1K23MH110660-01 , IRB Approved October 10, 2017.

subject: Message from Chancellor Carol L. Folt: Upcoming UNC System Employee Engagement Survey
author: janerc
content:
Dear Carolina Faculty and Staff:

We make every effort to build and support a diverse and inclusive workplace where our faculty and staff can succeed. The same is true for all institutions in the UNC System. To that end, I am writing today to encourage you to participate in a survey that can help us gauge and enhance your experience as a Carolina employee.

The UNC System Strategic Plan includes a goal to foster diverse and excellent institutions. Toward this goal, for the next five years, each institution in the UNC System will participate in an annual system-wide survey to gather input about workplace engagement.

The survey, which will be emailed to you on January 29, is designed for full-time employees, and the goal is to gain clearer measurements for success that will assist us with the recruitment, retention, and development of the most talented and diverse workforce possible—both as a system and on our campus. We want to develop a workforce that is prepared to meet the changing needs of the University—a priority in the UNC System Strategic Plan and our campus’s The Blueprint for Next strategic framework. In the survey, you will be asked for your thoughts about topics like communications, collaboration, supervision and benefits, among other items. The survey will come from ModernThink LLC, an independent research and consulting firm that specializes in higher education.

I encourage each of you to share your honest feedback, and your responses will remain anonymous. As a thank you, more than 100 respondents will be chosen at random to receive incentives, including tickets to campus events, gift cards and other prizes. Over the summer, we will receive and share reports that summarize the data provided so that we can recognize our successes and begin to address concerns that most directly influence our workplace culture.

If you have questions about the survey, please email engagement@unc.edu or visit our engagement website for information and updates about this important multi-year initiative. Thank you in advance for your participation.

Sincerely,

Carol L. Folt
Chancellor

subject: Do you want to learn to slow down and enjoy your life more?
author: kmeason
content:
Do you want to learn to slow down and enjoy your life more?
These courses are open to those both new to mindfulness practice and seasoned practitioners.
Limited space is still available!
The UNC Mindfulness-based Program for Stress and Pain Management offers training in meditation and mind-body awareness that will teach you how to slow down, set priorities and stay calm, focused and relaxed in the midst of a busy life.  These practices will enhance your body's natural adaptive healing ability and will cultivate the mind's clarity and insight.

This program follows Jon Kabat-Zinn's model and is offered by the Program on Integrative Medicine at UNC (Department of Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation).

 

Monday

Foundations of Mindfulness: Introduction to Mindfulness-Based Stress & Pain Management (MSPM), 6-8:30PM, January 29 through March 19, 2018

Will Frey, CPCC, MEd.

Location: UNC School of Social Work, Tate-Turner-Kuralt Building, room 102, 325 Pittsboro St., Chapel Hill, N 27516

Free parking available, if needed

To register, please click here

 

Tuesday

MSPM, 6-8:30PM, January 29 through March 20, 2018

Kessonga Giscombe, Mindfulness Instructor

Location: UNC Center for Rehabilitation Care, 1807 Fordham Blvd., Chapel Hill, NC 27514

To register, please click here

 

Mindful Self-Compassion with Karen Bluth and Laura Prochnow Phillips

Do you ever feel like you are too hard on yourself? That you have a harsh self-critic inside your head that follows you wherever you go?? Are you a caregiver and feeling burned out? Then this course is for you!

The UNC Program on Integrative Medicine is excited to again be offering the Mindful Self-Compassion (MSC) course this winter. Combining the skills of mindfulness and self-compassion, this course provides a powerful tool for emotional resilience. This course has been offered internationally over the last several years and been met with enormous popularity and success, and here at UNC since last fall. Two of the four trained facilitators in North Carolina are here in Chapel Hill and will be teaching this course (Dr. Karen Bluth and Laura Prochnow Phillips).

 

Tuesday 9:30-12PM, January 30th through March 20th

Location: UNC Hospital, Wing D, room 188

To register, please click here

Free parking available, if needed

Please visit our website, www.pim.med.unc and please like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter!

 

For questions, please email mindfulness@med.unc.edu

subject: Message from Chancellor Carol L. Folt
author: janerc
content:
Dear Campus Community,

In 2016, we announced a series of named scholarships, called Noteworthy Firsts, recognizing the service of courageous people who represent important “firsts” in our history. Today, I am writing with an exciting announcement about a new way Carolina is honoring a special group of people.

Soon, our next class of incoming students will receive their acceptances and those who qualify may find themselves the recipient of a scholarship named for an individual who played an important role in Carolina’s history. These need-based awards are named for Bridge Builders – people whose work, advocacy and personal example forged a more inclusive, unified and aspirational Carolina community.

In the fall, I asked the campus community to help me identify Bridge Builders who helped us fulfill our mission to be the university of the people. From these recommendations, a panel of our leaders identified 19 extraordinary people who truly represented the values that define Carolina. 

The scholarships will recognize people like Larry D. Keith, who paved the way for hundreds of students of color to succeed in the health professions when he served as Director of the Medical Education Development program. Another example is Susie Marshall Sharp, the first woman to serve as Chief Justice of the North Carolina Supreme Court. Nikole Hannah-Jones – a Peabody Award-winning journalist and one of the founders of the Ida B. Wells Society for Investigative Reporting – is another sterling example of service to Carolina and beyond that is recognized through the Bridge Builders scholarship opportunity. A full list of Bridge Builders can be found here.

I encourage you to read the biographies of all the Bridge Builders and learn more about those who helped create the Carolina we know today. I know their stories will motivate you to succeed in your own personal journeys at Carolina.

Sincerely,

Carol L. Folt
Chancellor

subject: New Arts Everywhere App Launches for University Community
author: ashr
content:
Dear Members of the Carolina Community:

There is now a free resource to help you find out about all the arts events and programs at UNC-Chapel Hill.  Launched on January 22, the Arts Everywhere App uses the latest mobile technology to recommend arts events based on your interests and to share what’s trending in the arts across campus. The app makes it easy to invite friends to events, to add what you’re attending to your calendar, and to explore new artists through videos, images and other rich content.

Download at the App Store and Google Play.

Content Feature

125+ events with new content daily spanning the performing, visual and literary arts
20+ departments, units and student organizations represented with more every day
All types of arts experiences including workshops, performances, lectures, exhibitions, readings and installations
Functionality Highlights

Easily share events with friends through social media and text.
Get recommendations tailored to your interests and mood.
Explore new artists with videos, audio, images and rich content.
Find out the top trending campus events and what friends are going to.
Add events directly to your calendar.
Keep track of everything you're going to or like all in one place.
Filter by 75+ tags including date, location, organization, genre, and what's free.
Get Involved: If you have an arts-related program or event to share, contact artseverywhere@unc.edu to find out how to add it to the app.

Arts Everywhere is grateful to the many students, faculty, and staff who have participated in the app’s development. We hope you'll join us in discovering something new each day within UNC’s growing arts community.

Best,

The Arts Everywhere Team

subject: Study Participation Invitation
author: ypchang
content:
Hello there!

 

We are in need of participants who are aged between 25 and 35 and mainly grew up in the US or in Taiwan for an online research study on the relationship between everyday emotion experiences and expressions. The survey includes a 1-hour online questionnaire in which you will listen to 6 voice messages, read 6 pictures of cards, and then answer questionnaires about your feelings, attitudes toward the messages and cards, and your demographics. You will be able to join a drawing to win a $80 emailed gift card after completing the survey.

 

If you’re aged between 25 and 35, grew up in the US or in Taiwan, and are interested in our study, please click the link below to go to the survey. Thank you!

 

https://unc.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_5bdux3chyGk4lTv


 

PI: Yen-Ping Chang (ypchang@unc.edu)

Faculty Advisor: Sara Algoe (algoe@unc.edu)

This study has been reviewed on 12/20/2017 by the UNC Non-Biomedical Institutional Review Board, IRB#17-2505, and the approval will be valid until 10/29/2018.

subject: Awards for students, faculty, staff and and University units
author: rbeatty
content:
The Carolina Center for Public Service is accepting nominations for campus-wide awards honoring undergraduate and graduate students, faculty, staff and University units for exemplary public service and engaged scholarship

The Ned Brooks Award for Public Service honors the contributions and values of Ned Brooks, who has served the University since 1972, making significant contributions to the mission of service and engagement. The award recognizes a UNC-Chapel Hill staff or faculty member who throughout his/her career has, in a collaborative and sustained manner, made a difference in the larger community. Full nominations are due by 11:59 p.m. on Feb. 7.

Three Office of the Provost Engaged Scholarship Awards are given, one each for engaged teaching, engaged research and engaged partnership. The award requires a brief two-paragraph nomination submitted by Feb. 7. Selected nominees will be invited to complete a more detailed submission about their work by Feb. 28. Final selection will be based on both the initial nomination and the nominee application.

Five Robert E. Bryan Public Service Awards will be given for a specific effort (rather than an overall record) exemplifying outstanding engagement and service to the state of North Carolina. Bryan awards recognize an outstanding undergraduate student, graduate student, faculty member, staff member and officially recognized student organization. The award requires a brief two-paragraph nomination submitted by Feb. 7. Selected nominees will be invited to complete a more detailed submission about their work by Feb. 28. Final selection will be based on both the initial nomination and the nominee application.

All nominations are accepted through the Carolina Center for Public Service Application and Nomination Portal. For questions, email ccps@unc.edu.

content:
Hello faculty and students,

Due to the campus closures last week, the Office of the University Registrar along with partner offices have chosen to extend the deadline on the following items:

content:

subject: Research - Researchers Perceptions Regarding Institutional Review Boards: A Helping Hand or Putting up Roadblocks?
author: kseabolt
content:
Researchers Perceptions Regarding Institutional Review Boards: A Helping Hand or Putting Up Roadblocks?


Hello.  We received your email address from your institutions website.  Researchers at the Office of Human Research Ethics at the University of North Carolina aim to study the current perceptions researchers have of Institutional Review Boards (IRBs) in the United States.  You must be 18 years old or older and have conducted Human Subject's Research in order to participate in this research study.  Participation in this research study involves a one-time demographic and study questionnaire which should take approximately 15 minutes total to complete.  Survey results will be completely anonymous to protect your identity.  We will not be able to link your responses to you.  Only the research team will receive your anonymous responses.  You may skip any questions that you do not feel comfortable answering.  Your participation is completely voluntary.


If you agree to participate in the study, please click on the link below to begin the survey:


https://unc.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_4Z6LfS4Wy2SOXnn


If you have any questions about this study, please contact Shahila Sriskanda, MS, CIP (shahila@email.unc.edu) or Kathy Seabolt, CIM, CIC, CIP (kseabolt@email.unc.edu).  If you have any questions or concerns regarding your rights as a subject in this study, contact the UNC Office of Human Research Ethics at 919-966-3113.
comments:
This is a research survey that we are sending to all UNC-CH students and employees who are engaged in research at UNC to validate or disprove perceptions of IRBs.

subject: UNC Recruitment Announcement
author: mfrisch
content:
UNC Recruitment Announcement

 

VOLUNTEERS NEEDED.  Researchers from the UNC TEACCH Autism Program and RTI International are seeking volunteers to help review a survey. 

 

We need help from 3-8 healthy adults aged 18-40.

 

Participation will involve answering questions about a survey for an upcoming study. The survey may help researchers learn which factors are most important to people when deciding whether to participate in research studies using their medical records.

 

We will try to schedule the approximately 60-minute interview at a time convenient time for you. Participants will receive $75.  We hope to complete interviews by February 15, 2018.  

 

If you are interested in participating in this study, please contact MaryKate Frisch at (919)-962-8554 or by e-mail: marykate_frisch@med.unc.edu to schedule an appointment. Thank you!

 

This study, Assessing the Preferences for the Use of Clinical Data Among Individuals with IDD and Their Gaurdians (#16-0489), has been approved by UNC-CH IRB on 8/21/2017.

subject: Peanut allergy study
author: dhamilto
content:
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill’s Food Allergy Initiative is conducting an industry sponsored phase one clinical trial for peanut allergy.  The purpose of this study is to find out if an investigational vaccine for peanut allergy is safe and tolerable for people suffering from peanut allergy.  The product being investigated is a vaccine which is injected under the skin in your arm or in your upper arm muscle.  The drug being used for this study is ASP0892 (ARA-LAMP_vax), and is not yet approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

You may be eligible for this study if you:
Are between 18 and 55 years of age
Have a diagnosed peanut allergy

You should not participate in this study if you:
Have any severe uncontrolled disease (lung, endocrine, renal, cardiac, or immune) or disease which prevents you from using epinephrine.
Are pregnant or nursing or thinking of becoming pregnant.
Are currently receiving immunotherapy treatment
Have asthma which is not well controlled
Require routine antihistamines to control symptoms of environmental allergies
Have a mental condition such as schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, major depressive disorder or take medication for depression.

Other criteria will be determined over the phone with a study coordinator and at the first clinic visit.

The study participation will require you to attend our UNC clinic for 13 visits over a period of 8 to 9 months. Most visits will last approximately 4 hours but some visits will take as long as 6 to 8 hours.  Study participants will be paid up to $1300 to compensate for time needed for completion of all study activities.  A parking voucher will be given to cover the cost of parking at each visit.

It is important to know that this letter is not telling you to join this study. Your participation is voluntary.  If you would like to learn more about this study, please contact the study coordinator, Deanna Hamilton, RN at 919-962-4405 or dhamilto@email.unc.edu.

This research study has been approved by the Biomedical UNC-CH IRB: Study #16-1928 (approved 8/26/17)

subject: Are you a young adult cancer survivor interested in getting more physically active?
author: grabow
content:
Researchers at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill are studying ways to promote physical activity among young adult cancer survivors using Fitbit activity trackers and Facebook. The research team is seeking volunteers to enroll in a 6-week research study that tests a physical activity program designed specifically for young adult cancer survivors.

If you participate, you will receive a Fitbit activity tracker, information about physical activity, a digital smart scale, access to a Facebook group, and a personalized website to use during the study. You will be asked to complete online questionnaires 3 times and an interview after 6 weeks. The entire study can be completed online.

You may be eligible if you:

-- are 18 to 39 years old

-- were diagnosed with cancer (excluding non-melanoma skin cancer) at age 18 or older

-- have completed cancer treatment




Additional eligibility criteria apply.

You will receive up to $45 for completion of all study questionnaires and measurements. If you complete all the study assessments, you will be able to keep the Fitbit activity tracker.




To learn more and see if you qualify, visit http://www.uncweightresearch.org/impact-pilot.

For more information, please call 919-966-5852 or email us at impactstudy@unc.edu.

 

The study has been reviewed and approved by the Public Health Nursing IRB (Study # 16-3409) 1/27/17.

This email is sponsored by: Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center

subject: Something not quite right? You may be eligible to participate in a study in the Prime Research Program.
author: grewen
content:
The UNC Department of Psychiatry is conducting a research study to find out more about mental illness.  If you have had any of the following symptoms in the past few months, are between 12-30 years old, and have not been diagnosed with psychosis, you may be eligible to participate in a study in the Prime Research Program.

 

Do you sometimes feel confused about what is real or imaginary?
Have you felt that things happening around you have a special meaning just for you?
Are you feeling confused by things you hear or see?
Have you noticed unusual coincidences or connections that others do not seem to notice?
Do you ever feel like you just know what others are thinking or that others somehow know what you are thinking?
Are you worried that others are talking about you or laughing about you?
Do you think that others are trying to hurt you?
Do you have a close relative with a psychotic disorder and you’ve had a drop in function over the past year?

 

You may be eligible to receive free study related medical evaluations and monetary compensation.  Study participation includes multiple visits lasting 2-8 hours over 2 years.  These visits will take place at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

 

Visit us at our www.PRIME.unc.edu and click on 'Simple Survey' or call (877) PRIME19 or (877) 774-6319.

 

The Project is funded by the National Institute of Mental Health

 

14-2055 Approved 6-11-2015

Committee on the Protection of the Rights of Human Subjects

The BioMedical IRB

University of North Carolina

subject: 2017 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report now available
author: jlkelly
content:
To:     Deans, Directors and Department Chairs

From:  Aimee Turner, Executive Director, Enterprise Financial Accounting and University Controller

Date:   January 19, 2018

Re:       DDD - 2017 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report now available

The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill has released its Comprehensive Annual Financial Report (CAFR) for the fiscal year that ended June 30, 2017.  This year’s edition is featured online at https://finance.unc.edu/about/reports-data/cafr-2017/ where digital materials are presented through specific sections, or the entire content can be downloaded as a pdf with bookmarks for easier navigability.  We do have a limited number of printed copies, available at request as supplies last.

The CAFR is one way the University is fulfilling its goal of transparency and accountability to the people of North Carolina and beyond.  In addition to the financial statements of the University, the document contains disclosures regarding investments, debt, revenues and expenses.

For the past 22 years, the University has received an award for reporting excellence for the CAFR.  The Certificate of Achievement for Excellence in Financial Reporting is the highest form of recognition in the area of governmental accounting and financial reporting.

Note:  This memo is also being sent to MOU Financial Leads.

content:
NOMINATIONS OPEN FOR 2018 MASSEY AWARDS

 

Nominations for the 2018 C. Knox Massey Distinguished Service Awards are due Feb. 7, 2018.

Chancellor Carol Folt will recognize six recipients for “unusual, meritorious or superior contribution made by an employee, past or present” and the honor includes an award of $10,000. 

Nominations can be submitted at http://masseyawards.unc.edu/nominations/, or contact Carolyn Atkins, Massey Awards Committee Chair, at (919) 962-1536.

The late C. Knox Massey of Durham created the awards in 1980 to recognize outstanding contributions made by University employees. In 1984, he joined the families of his son, Knox Massey Jr., and daughter, Kay Massey Weatherspoon, to create the Massey-Weatherspoon fund. Income from the fund supports the Massey Awards and Carolina Seminars.

subject: Undergraduate service opportunities
author: rbeatty
content:
The Carolina Center for Public Service offers a variety of opportunities in service-learning and community engagement for undergraduate students to connect with communities:

1/24 - APPLES Service-Learning summer internship applications due - APPLES Service-Learning is accepting applications for its summer service-learning internships. APPLES internships are unique, intense experiences at a variety of nonprofit and government organizations. Summer interns receive a $2,500 stipend and academic course credit through a School of Social Work online course. Stipends are intended to defray the cost of living, transportation and course fees. Partial, need-based financial assistance is available. Students are responsible for housing and travel arrangements unless otherwise noted. Apply by Jan. 24 through the APPLES Partner Portal.

1/31 - BPSS enrollment deadline - Spring enrollment for the Buckley Public Service Scholars program is open through Jan. 31. Undergraduate students with at least four semesters remaining at Carolina can enroll. Transfer students must have at least three semesters remaining to enroll. When enrolling, students should sign up for an orientation session. Enroll online through the Buckley Portfolio.

2/6 - Outward Bound - The Carolina Center for Public Service a wards scholarships for UNC undergraduates to participate in a North Carolina Outward Bound 28-day summer course. Recipients receive full tuition for the course and Wilderness First Aid certification. Preference is given to students who are participants in the Buckley Public Service Scholars program, affiliated with the School of Education or involved with Student Life and Leadership. Apply by Feb. 6 through the Carolina Center for Public Service Application and Nomination Portal.

subject: CORRECTION: Social Skills Group for Teenagers and Young Adults
author: dichter
content:
CORRECTION: This group will begin on  Tuesday, January 30.  The date was incorrect in the previous message.

 

We are pleased to announce the next session of our group-based social skills clinic for teenagers and young adults (17 years and older).  This clinical service consists of 8 hour-long weekly sessions, with the next session scheduled to begin on Tuesday, January 30 at 4:00 PM.  This clinic is offered through the Carolina Institute for Developmental Disabilities (101 Renee Lynne Court, Carrboro, NC 27510).  All major insurance providers are accepted.

Sessions will be led by Gabriel Dichter, PhD, an Associate Professor of Psychiatry at UNC and a licensed clinical psychologist.  Dr. Dichter co-developed this treatment approach and has been running this group at the CIDD since 2011.  Dr. Dichter has extensive clinical experience working with individuals with autism spectrum disorder in both individual and group settings.  He will co-lead this group with trainees who are receiving specialized training in autism and other neurodevelopmental disorders.

The group will focus on improving social cognition and social skills.  The class is open to those with a formal diagnosis that impacts their social abilities (such as autism spectrum disorder) as well as to those wishing to improve their social skills.  Because much of the class relies on back-and-forth between class members, participants must have sufficient verbal skills to participate in a group setting.  Sessions will have up to 12 participants.

Contact: Potential patients or caregivers please contact Twyla Peoples at 919-843-1529 or Twyla.peoples@cidd.unc.edu for more information about scheduling and registration.

subject: Message from Provost Bob Blouin
author: janerc
content:
Dear Carolina Community,

I am pleased to announce that we have selected Jonathan Pruitt, a proven leader in financial and operational efficiency, as the next Vice Chancellor for Finance and Operations. Jonathan, who was until recently the chief financial officer for the UNC System, will fill the position that Matt Fajack will vacate in February.

Jonathan will begin his new role on January 29.  He will serve as a valued partner to me and the rest of our senior leadership, helping to implement the Blueprint for Next, the University’s first overarching strategic framework, and new budget and business strategies that will guide and support our growth and future direction.

We are extremely fortunate to be able to fill this critical position quickly and with someone who is already intimately familiar with the University and its operations, as well as the state budget process.  Jonathan’s existing relationships with members of the UNC System and the state legislature will ensure a smooth transition into his new role. At this critical time on our campus, as universities face new challenges in growth and budgeting, Jonathan’s stellar credentials and expertise will help shepherd us through our next chapter and ensure we remain the leading 21st-century public research institution.

As Vice Chancellor of Finance and Operations, Jonathan will be responsible for oversight of campus-wide financial planning and budgeting; treasury and risk management; facilities planning, construction and operations; real estate development; purchasing; public safety; campus enterprises; environment health and safety; and energy services.

Jonathan joined the UNC System in 2006. In his role, he was responsible for the finance and business affairs of UNC General Administration, managing an operating budget of $10 billion. His role required him to work collaboratively with the UNC Board of Governors, state government, UNC General Administration staff and chief financial officers from the 17 campuses of the UNC System to accomplish strategic financial and operational priorities.

Jonathan is from Pikeville, Kentucky, and received his bachelor of arts degree from Centre College and his master of public administration degree from the University of Kentucky. He began his career as a senior associate of finance for the Kentucky Council on Postsecondary Education and as a policy and budget analyst for the Office for Policy and Management.

We are thrilled to have Jonathan on board and I know the Tar Heel community will join me in congratulating him on his new role.

Sincerely,

Bob Blouin
Provost

subject: Call for Concept Papers for Injury/Violence Research Projects for forthcoming Injury Control Research Center Application
author: smarshal
content:
Call for Brief Concept Papers for Injury/Violence Research Studies:

The UNC Injury Prevention Research Center invites UNC-CH researchers to submit concept proposals for small or medium size research projects on injury and violence. Selected ideas will be developed into full research proposals to be included an upcoming funding request for an Injury Control Research Center.

At some point in 2018, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) will release a funding request for Injury Control Research Center applications (upcoming RFA-CE-19-001). In response, the UNC Injury Prevention Research Center will submit a proposal for ongoing funding as a CDC Injury Control Research Center. CDC permits only one Injury Control Research Center application per university.

The UNC Injury Prevention Research Center invites UNC-CH researchers to submit brief concept papers for small to medium size research studies, to be considered for inclusion in our upcoming Injury Control Research Center application to CDC. Studies should be focused on injury and violence prevention. Preference will be given to studies that address Violence, Motor Vehicle Injury, Opioid Disorders and Overdose, and Traumatic Brain Injury. The UNC Injury Prevention Research Center will use a peer-review process to select up to four concept briefs to be developed into full proposals.  The four proposals selected will be included in the forthcoming renewal application of the UNC Injury Prevention Research Center for funding as an CDC Injury Control Research Center.

Concept briefs are due by February 12th, 2018.  We are issuing this call for project concepts in advance of CDC’s release of the request for ICRC applications (upcoming RFA-CE-19-001) to ensure time for development of a highly-competitive center application that includes outstanding project proposals. For futher information, visit: http://iprc.unc.edu/research/call-concept-papers-research-projects-forthcoming-injury-control-research-center-icrc-application/
