subject: Nominations Open for 2018 C. Knox Massey Distinguished Service Awards
author: casquire
content:
NOMINATIONS OPEN FOR 2018 MASSEY AWARDS

Nominations for the 2018 C. Knox Massey Distinguished Service Awards are due Feb. 7, 2018.

Chancellor Carol Folt will recognize six recipients for “unusual, meritorious or superior contribution made by an employee, past or present” and the honor includes an award of $10,000. 

Nominations can be submitted at http://masseyawards.unc.edu/nominations/, or contact Carolyn Atkins, Massey Awards Committee Chair, at (919) 962-1536.

The late C. Knox Massey of Durham created the awards in 1980 to recognize outstanding contributions made by University employees. In 1984, he joined the families of his son, Knox Massey Jr., and daughter, Kay Massey Weatherspoon, to create the Massey-Weatherspoon fund. Income from the fund supports the Massey Awards and Carolina Seminars.

FROM:            Matthew M. Fajack, Vice Chancellor for Finance and Operations

SUBJECT:        New Division Name and Branding 

DATE:              Jan. 16, 2018

As we embark on 2018 I am pleased to announce a new name for our division. We are updating our name to better reflect everything we do to support campus. Starting today, the Division of Finance and Administration is now the Division of Finance and Operations.

The Division of Finance and Operations encompasses 45 units, managed among five departments — Finance, Facilities Services, Real Estate Development, Campus Safety and Risk Management, and Campus Enterprises — that serve and support the University’s teaching, research and public service mission.

The division website URL has been updated to reflect the name change and can now be accessed at fo.unc.edu.

subject: Your 2017 W-2 is now available in ConnectCarolina Employee SelfService Menu
author: jlkelly
content:
Dear University Employee,

Your tax year 2017 W-2 form is now available for viewing via the SelfService menu on the ConnectCarolina home page. Remember that 2-Step Verification is required for online W-2 access (see 2-Step instructions below). In late January 2018, all employees will also receive a printed W-2 for tax year 2017.

Accessing online W-2s offers the following advantages:

Accessing your W-2 form online allows you to print and use it sooner than the paper version issued in late January by Payroll Services.
Active employees can access and print their W-2s at any time, 24 hours a day. The functionality can be especially useful for employees who need to access their W-2 information quickly when applying for personal loans.
The electronic W-2 is just as official as the paper version you normally receive from Payroll Services – no special paper is needed.
Former employees will continue to receive paper W-2s via U.S. Mail and also have the option of accessing W-2s via a guest account in ConnectCarolina. Instructions can be found at help.unc.edu/help/onyens-guest-ids/.

Instructions for accessing your W-2 online using 2-Step:

Visit onyen.unc.edu and click "Register & Manage 2-Step Verification." The registration process for 2-Step takes just 10 minutes. Have your PID available and your mobile device or landline phone with you. Follow the steps to select and confirm your preferred 2-Step method (a text message, landline phone call or a “push” notification). Then visit ConnectCarolina to access your online W-2 via the SelfService menu.

Already registered for 2-Step but have a new device?

Are you already registered for 2-Step, but need a refresher on how to activate a new device? Click the "New Devices" tab on this help document: help.unc.edu/help/duo/ for step-by-step instructions. 

Want to learn more? 

You can visit its.unc.edu/2-step to learn more about 2-Step on our campus, why it's important and how it keeps you and Carolina secure.

Questions or problems?

Help Documentation related to 2-Step, including step-by-step instructions, is available by visiting: help.unc.edu/help/duo/.
Step-by-step instructions and user tips related to viewing and printing W-2 forms can be found on the ConnectCarolina User Information website, Online Employee Tax Forms page: ccinfo.unc.edu/featured-resources/online-employee-tax-forms/.
• If you have questions concerning your W-2 form, please visit our W-2 frequently-asked questions webpage, finance.unc.edu/departments/strategic-sourcing-payment/payroll/w-2/.
If you have technical problems viewing or printing your W-2, contact the Help Desk at 962-HELP.

subject: Unique Leadership Opportunity for First Year Students
author: mbrunton
content:
Hello! 

If you are a First-Year student interested in a unique leadership opportunity, continue reading! 

Each year, the North Carolina Fellows Program welcomes a group of around twenty-five students from the first-year class into our community. But what is the North Carolina Fellows Program?  

NC Fellows is a leadership development group centered around discussion-based learning and exposure to new ideas. Students apply during their first year at Carolina and remain in the program through their senior year. Fellows will interact in the program both with the students in their class year (their cohort) as well as with members from all years in the group.  

At the core of NC Fellows are Monthly Meetings, in which Fellows of all years meet to discuss new topics, listen and interact with speakers, or participate in workshops. Topics run the gamut from issues of social justice to questions of community to explorations of art. These meetings are always accompanied by dinner, so that Fellows can engage in fellowship with one another in a less formal setting. 

Part of what makes NC Fellows so unique is its combination of co-curricular with extra-curricular. In addition to Monthly Meetings, students will also have the opportunity to enroll in multiple leadership development classes at UNC for academic credit. Incoming sophomores will take EDUC 309, a course focused on leadership theory and practice that serves to better acquaint Fellows with the program and their cohort. These studies come full circle in one's senior year with EDUC 317, a capstone course designed to conclude one's time in Fellows.  

In addition to monthly meetings, all Fellows attend an annual leadership retreat at the beginning of the year. The retreat sets the stage for the program as it moves into a new year, while giving Fellows a chance to re-connect with each other and to meet the incoming sophomore cohort. During their junior year, Fellows will also attend an alternative Fall Break oriented around service, adding an additional element of community engagement to their time in the program.  

If any or all of this program sounds exciting to you, we welcome you to apply! Fellows is not restricted to any specific major or discipline. Rather, we seek thoughtful individuals of all backgrounds, those with open minds, self-awareness, passion, and creativity in all forms.  

The application is now open on HeelLife, and can be accessed via this link: http://unc.live/2AcH3Be. The application closes on Jan. 31, 2018. If you are having trouble accessing the application, please send an email to ncfellows@gmail.com. The Interview Day will be on Saturday, Feb. 24th, 2018 from 10 AM to 4 PM. You will be notified if you are selected for Interview Day on Feb. 12th, 2018. If you are selected for Interview Day, you must attend. You will be notified of your final status on March 5th, 2018. Best of luck! 

Sincerely, 

The NC Fellows Selection Committee

subject: Paid Research Opportunity for Runners
author: fjgood
content:
The UNC Neuromuscular Research Lab is conducting a research study on running-related injuries. We are recruiting healthy, physically active volunteers for participation in this study.

If you decide to participate, you will be asked to report to the Neuromuscular Research Lab for 1 testing session and the Applied Biomechanics Lab for 1 testing session.  Each session will last approximately 1 hour. 

During the Neuromuscular Lab testing session you will be asked to complete maximal strength and musculotendinous stiffness assessments of your knee and ankle. During the Applied Biomechanics testing session, you will be asked to complete single leg hopping at 3 different frequencies for 30 seconds and run for 2 minutes at a comfortable speed on a treadmill while lower extremity biomechanics will be collected.

There are some risks associated with participating in this research study, but they are not greater than the risks associate with normal physical activity/exercise.

Subjects will be required to meet the following inclusion criteria:

Age 18-40 years
No injury to either leg in the past 6 months
No history of surgery to either leg
Not currently pregnant
Run a minimum of 15 miles/week for the 3 previous months
No history of chronic neurological condition
You will receive $25 for study completion.

If you meet the criteria above and are interested in participating, or if you would like more information about the study, please contact FJ Goodwin via email at fjgoodwin@unc.edu

Approved Biomedical IRB Information:

Title: "Neuromechanical contributions to lower extremity stiffness during hopping and running in healthy runners"

IRB Number: 17-0098

Approval Date: 10/16/2017

subject: OVCR Announces Creativity Hubs Pre-proposal Winners
author: briordan
content:
January 11, 2018

To: Deans, Directors, and Department Chairs

From: Terry Magnuson, Vice Chancellor for Research

Re: OVCR Announces Creativity Hub Pre-proposal Winners

In October of last year, we launched Creativity Hubs, a key initiative of the Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research (OVCR) in support of Chancellor Folt’s Blueprint for Next. Through this program, we bring together investigators from across diverse disciplines, focusing the power of convergence to yield new knowledge and simulate innovation to solve emerging problems and shape the future.

I’m excited to share with you that after the call for pre-proposals was issued in November, our office received 38 submissions, involving 194 UNC researchers representing 35 departments across 10 schools and the College.

Of those submissions, the OVCR has chosen seven semi-finalists who will go on to develop comprehensive proposals and publicly present their innovative approaches in March. The goals of the semi-finalist proposals include:

Applying novel statistical models to drive healthcare predictive analytics, inform decision-making, and optimize chronic disease treatment.
Addressing “how epigenetics contribute to life” by utilizing chemical biology tools to empower researchers to gain insights in epigenetics to advance fundamental understanding in biology and pathways to treat disease
Collaborating intra-institutionally to examine the long-term effects of environmental exposure on health.
Investigating heterogeneity of the etiology of obesity and its clinical health consequences and responses by conducting integrated science across basic, clinical, and population research.
Bridging humanists and data scientists by providing better access to data tools and methodologies, and developing interventions that correct or limit misinformation to improve social media exchanges and influence public policy on science and health.
Creating a data-driven platform for designing and making bio-mimetic materials to be used in individually tailored medical devices and implants.
Developing novel, affordable and scalable graphene-polymer nanocomposites as membranes for water purification, energy generation, and energy storage applications
Of these novel projects, we hope to fund two finalists in April to receive up to $500,000 in funding from OVCR to execute their proposal over the next two years.

Additionally, Creativity Hub awardees are guaranteed proposal development assistance from the Office of Research Development (ORD) to pursue large-scale, follow-on awards that spring from the program’s funding. Of those pre-proposals that were not selected, many were excellent, and ORD will work with these groups to further build their projects and connect to other funding opportunities.

Please visit the program website to learn more about these innovative projects and creative teams: http://research.unc.edu/creativity-hubs/

I look forward to sharing with you the finalist for the first round of Creativity Hubs in April.

subject: CURRENT THERAPY OPENINGS FOR COMMITTED COUPLES!
author: rosella
content:
Our Couples Clinic at the UNC Department of Psychology and Neuroscience provides services for a wide range of relationship issues including: 
o Relationship Distress         
o Relationship Enhancement
o Sexual Dysfunction
o Couples Experiencing individual physical or mental health problems
o Couples experiencing societal discrimination
The Couples Clinic offers effective psychological interventions with reduced fees based on income. Treatment is provided by doctoral students under the supervision of licensed clinical psychologists. We welcome same gender couples, members of ethnic minority groups, interracial couples, and couples in which the ages of the two partners are quite different.
Because we are a training clinic we can take a limited number of couples at a time, so inquire soon if interested, as the clinic can fill up quickly. We will likely select cases for the clinic within a week of this e-mail announcement.
Couples therapy is available on UNC campus at our Evergreen House clinic, and also at our off-site clinic on Finley Golf Course Road (with ample adjacent parking). We offer day time and evening appointments.
For more information or to request a phone screening for services, please contact us at:                
* http://clinic.unc.edu/initial-contact
* 919-962-6906
To schedule a phone screening. You can also visit our website at: clinic.unc.edu for more information.
Please be aware that if the information you provide indicates that there may be abuse of a child or disabled adult, or that you or another person is in danger, we will need to respond as required by state law.
 
This email is sponsored by: UNC Department of Psychology Community Clinic.

We are looking for women between the ages of 45-60 to participate in a research study looking at how the role of estrogen and stress affect mood symptoms and other changes during the menopause transition.

Participation includes:
One enrollment session
Six lab sessions on site
Study participation duration is 24 weeks

You can earn up to $1,275 in compensation.

For further information, you can go to changes.web.unc.edu. If you would like to participate, call us 919-590-0813 or click here to see if you are eligible: uncchangesstudy.com.

subject: Open Campus Accessibility Meeting
author: kwbryant
content:
We are writing on behalf of the University’s Digital Accessibility Advisory Team (DAAT) to invite students to attend the Campus Accessibility Meeting on Thursday, Jan. 18, from 1–2:30 p.m. at the Carolina Union – Great Hall, on the subject of UNC-Chapel Hill’s digital accessibility compliance efforts.

 As part of a broader assessment of our campus’ accessibility to people with disabilities, the University has engaged The Paciello Group (TPG, www.paciellogroup.com) to help us improve the accessibility of our digital environment.  As part of this engagement, we are working with TPG to create an Accessibility Roadmap that articulates our commitment to accessibility and charts a course for building and sustaining a practice of accessibility.

This Campus Accessivility Meeting is intended to provide the campus community with an opportunity to learn more about our Digital Accessibility Initiative and TPG’s involvement in helping the University define achieveable and sustainable goals and timelines for advancing accessibility. The meeting will be an opportunity for you to hear from them about their work, ask questions about the initiative, and provide your opinions.

If you are interested in attending this event, please RSVP at https://eoc.unc.edu/event/accessibility-open-meeting/

If you need accommodations for the event (e.g., sign language interpreters), please contact Rudy Jones at rudy_jones@unc.edu, (919) 962-9980, or (T) 711 NC RELAY as soon as possible.

For more information on the University’s Digital Accessibility Initiative, visit http://digitalaccess.unc.edu/.

 

Sincerely,

Rudy Jones
Brandon Washington
Tiffany Bailey

subject: Infant/Toddler Nap Study
author: pagejm
content:
Subject: Early Development and Sleep Research Study

Hello,

The Frohlich Lab, a leader in brain network dynamics at UNC, has an exciting research study that your infant/toddler between the ages of 12-30 months can participate in with just 2 short sessions.

 In this research study, we are examining sleep characteristics in infants/toddlers that may have:

-Language delays (i.e., no words at 18 months, limited vocalizations at 12 months)

-Delays in social communication or play                   

-Autism or who are at-risk for autism (have a sibling with autism). 

Children develop and change rapidly during infancy and toddlerhood. We know that sleep is a critical aspect of health and brain development. However, little has been done to document patterns of sleep in young children or examine how brain activity during sleep may differ in children with delays and children with autism.

~You may be eligible if:

Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months with language delays (i.e., no words at 18 months, limited vocalizations at 12 months)
. Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months with delays in social communication or play

.  Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months with an autism spectrum disorder.

Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months who has an older sibling with an autism spectrum disorder.
 

~We schedule the two visits at your convenience and you will be with your child at all times. Each visit will take about 2- 2 ½ hours. The types of activities involved:

. A visit to your home at your convenience: Infant developmental assessments

. A visit to the nap room: Non-invasive recording (brain rhythms) during a midday nap. Your child will be playing with a variety of toys and taking a nap. This location offers free parking. 

We will compensate you $75 for your time. For more information, or to see if your child is eligible, please call Jessica Page at 919-445-0227 or email jessica.page@unc.edu or EDS@med.unc.edu.  You can find out more on our website at http://www.frohlichlab.org/.

We look forward to your participation!


The Frohlich Lab
                        This study was approved by the UNC biomedical IRB on 1/29/17 (IRB # 15-1829)

subject: Director, American Indian Center
author: ddd3
content:
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill invites applications and nominations for the position of Director of the American Indian Center (http://americanindiancenter.unc.edu/), established in 2006 to bridge the richness of American Indian nations and communities with the strengths of Carolina’s research, education, and teaching.  The Center strengthens, nurtures, and applies research and teaching related to American Indians.  It also advances campus diversity by facilitating the inclusion of American Indian perspectives, enriching the overall learning environment.

The Director of the American Indian Center has overall responsibility for the activities, programs, and operations of the Center.  Specific responsibilities include strategic planning in collaboration with University and community colleagues; program development, implementation, and evaluation; outreach and partnership development; and fiscal and administrative oversight.

The position requires significant leadership and administrative experience and a minimum of a Master’s degree, with doctorate strongly preferred.  The successful candidate will be committed to engagement with Native nations and communities and will be able to communicate effectively and build relationships with a wide variety of partners and constituents.

For further information and to apply, go to

http://provost.unc.edu/aic-director.

 The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill is an Equal Opportunity Employer.

subject: Participants wanted for baseball pitching study
author: haydeng
content:
Hello, my name is Brett Pexa and I am a doctoral student in the Human Movement Science Curriculum at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. The research team I am working with consists of Dr. Eric Ryan, Dr. Joe Myers, Dr. Tony Hackney, and Dr. David Berkoff. We are reaching out to you in hopes that you can participate in a research study entitled “Non-invasive Assessment of Overuse Injury Mechanisms in the Adolescent Athlete.”

 

We are looking for healthy male baseball players between the ages of 13 – 18. To qualify for this study, pitcher must be or have been your primary or secondary position. You must not be injured, or have pain or discomfort that has limited your baseball participation for the last 3 months. You can have no previous shoulder or elbow surgery in the past year, and must be able to pitch the age recommended amount of pitches based on USA Baseball’s Pitch Smart guidelines. The purpose of this research study is to determine if ultrasound imaging of the infraspinatus, a shoulder muscle, can show how muscles recover following a bout of baseball pitching.

 

As a participant, you will be required to sign an informed consent document stating you understand all of the procedures and rights as a research subject, and to fill out questionnaires regarding your baseball participation, injuries, and training. The study includes 4 testing visits over the course of 6 days. Your first visit will involve filling out the paperwork and performing the baseline assessment which will consist of a finger stick blood draw, shoulder range of motion and strength measures, and an ultrasound image of your infraspinatus, a muscle critical to baseball pitching. These images are taken with an ultrasound machine. Diagnostic ultrasound creates an image using sound waves, so no radiation or damaging imaging will be used with this study.

 

Following the baseline testing, you will immediately pitch an age prescribed amount of pitches based on USA Baseball’s Pitch Smart guidelines. Once the pitch count is reached, the same testing procedures will be performed again. You will be asked to return on day 1, day 3, and day 5 following your bout of pitching, where the exact same assessments will be performed.

 

Participants can receive up to $100 dollars in compensation. If you are interested or have questions, please contact Brett Pexa by phone or email.

 

Brett Pexa

919-843-2014

pexa@live.unc.edu

 

IRB #: 16-2714

Date Approved: 3/2/2017

Biomedical

subject: Interim Director Named for Frank Porter Graham Child Development Institute
author: briordan
content:
January 8, 2018

To: Deans, Directors, and Department Chairs

From: Terry Magnuson, Vice Chancellor for Research

Re: Interim Director Named for Frank Porter Graham Child Development Institute

 

Dear Colleagues,

Stephen Hooper, PhD, began serving as interim director of the Frank Porter Graham Child Development Institute on January 1, 2018, as former director Sam Odom, PhD, stepped down after 11 years of serving in that position.  

Dr. Hooper has been with the University for over 30 years and currently serves as the chair of the department of Allied Health Sciences, associate dean for Allied Health Sciences in the School of Medicine, and professor of Psychiatry, Psychology, Pediatrics, and Education. He is an international expert in child neuropsychology and has dedicated his research, community outreach, and clinical service activities to developmental disabilities, genetic disorders in children, and pediatric chronic illnesses. He currently maintains federal funding with a variety of agencies including the Institute for Educational Science and the National Institutes for Health.

As Interim Director of FPG, Dr. Hooper will provide overall administrative oversight. He will also work with the FPG leadership team, investigative groups, and staff to facilitate ongoing projects that advance the Institute’s research, provide technical assistance and consultation, and facilitate community outreach.

Dr. Odom will continue to serve FPG as a senior research scientist and as an integral part of FPG’s formidable team of autism experts — a team he himself helped to build as director.

During Dr. Odom’s tenure, he oversaw the generation of more than 600 peer-reviewed publications and hundreds of book chapters, reports, and policy briefs produced by FPG scientists and specialists. He also buttressed FPG’s work to bring research to real-world solutions, supporting projects that impact programs, practices, and systems that serve young children. These include FPG’s Early Technical Assistance Center, the National Early Childhood Inclusion Institute, and evaluations of pre-kindergarten and early learning programs, to name a few.

While the Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research continues to work with the FPG Director Search Committee to identify a permanent director, please join me in supporting Stephen in his new role, and in sending best wishes to Sam on his future endeavors.

subject: Awards and fellowships for undergraduate and graduate students
author: rbeatty
content:
The Carolina Center for Public Service is accepting award and fellowship applications for graduate and undergraduate student opportunities.

The Davis Projects for Peace Award provides $10,000 to full-time undergraduate students to develop local or international community-based projects during the summer of 2018. Applications for the Projects for Peace Award are due Jan. 20, 2018. Learn more at Davis Projects for Peace Award.

The Ronald W. Hyatt Rotary Public Service Award supports innovative public service projects that exemplify the motto of Rotary International, “Service above Self.” A $3,000 award is provided for an international project and $2,000 for a local area project. Student organizations, as well as undergraduate and graduate students, individually or in teams, may apply. Applications for the Hyatt Rotary Public Service Award are due Feb. 8, 2018. Learn more at Ronald W. Hyatt Rotary Public Service Award.

The Mingma Norbu Sherpa Fellowship provides $1,250 to support undergraduate or graduate field study and engaged research in environmental areas at field sites, preferably abroad. Applications for the Sherpa Fellowship are due Feb. 8, 2018. Learn more at Mingma Norbu Sherpa Fellowship.

Apply for each award online at the Carolina Center for Public Service Application and Nomination Portal. For questions, contact ccps@unc.edu.

subject: Message from Chancellor Carol L. Folt
author: janerc
content:
Dear Carolina Community:

Welcome back to campus. We hope everyone had a restful and relaxing break.

As we begin 2018, we will continue to address many priorities and none is more important than protecting the safety of our campus community. The issue of sexual harassment is on the minds of everyone, as we have watched thousands of women across the nation courageously come forward to tell their stories. The #MeToo movement has started a powerful and important dialogue in our nation and around the world, and it’s helping inspire a transformative and positive change in our society.

And we want to make sure our campus isn’t just a part of the conversation, but doing all we can to engage and create positive change right here. This is more than a movement; it’s about creating a culture where all of us can feel free to pursue our passions and dreams without fear of harassment.

We are taking a fresh and critical look at policies and procedures across the University to make sure we are doing everything we can to create an inclusive and respectful culture at Carolina. When we learn about problems, we will take steps to address them and hold people accountable. We also are working to improve prevention measures, including evaluating and enhancing our training programs. Discrimination and harassment are counter to our University’s core values and must never be tolerated, and yet we know that these serious offenses may happen anywhere, including on our campus. If you have experienced sexual or gender-based harassment or any form of discrimination or you know someone who has, we urge you to contact the University’s office of Equal Opportunity and Compliance or report it online. For more information about our policies, programs and resources, please visit Safe at UNC.

We would like to thank the hundreds of people on our campus who work every day to strengthen our culture and help ensure that all of us feel safe to teach, learn and carry out the important work we are here to do. Our University is at its very best when we treat one another with respect and uphold the values we share as a community. We should all expect and tolerate nothing less.

Sincerely,

Carol L. Folt
Chancellor

Robert A. Blouin
Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost

Felicia A. Washington
Vice Chancellor for Workforce Strategy, Equity and Engagement

subject: FREE STATISTICAL CONSULTING
author: marron
content:
Free Statistical Consulting

       The UNC Department of Statistics and Operations Research announces the availability of free statistical consulting.  Our goal is to teach this important skill to graduate students, but you can get some free statistical assistance in the process.

         The course format involves clients giving a presentation about the problem at hand.  This generates a question and answer dialog, which by itself has proven to be useful in helping clients formulate their ideas.  Then typically one student is assigned to work on the actual data, with a final written report expected.

 In the past we have worked with a very wide range of clients, from Masters students needing help with the statistical end of their dissertation, all the way up to distinguished professors.  While there are limits to what can be done in the context of this course, some contacts initially made through this course have led to ongoing joint research, grant proposals and published papers in very diverse fields.

         To sign up for this type of consulting, or to discuss this further, please contact Steve Marron, Department of Statistics and Operations Research, UNC, CB 3260, Email: marron@unc.edu. Additional information is available at the web address:

 http://stat-or.unc.edu/consulting/unc-statistical-consulting-center/

subject: Looking for Healthy Males; Find out testosterone levels and body composition
author: kca11
content:
Hello,

We are currently recruiting healthy men age 30 years and older to participate in a research study in the Applied Physiology Laboratory on the UNC-CH campus, entitled: “A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo Controlled Study to Evaluate the Effects of a Dietary Supplement on Sexual Health Performance, Function and Quality of Life.”

The purpose of this research study is to evaluate the effect of an herbal dietary supplement serum reproductive hormone levels in adult healthy men. To qualify for this study, you must have:

-       30 years or older

-    A body mass index less than 29.9 kg/m2

-       Not have a significant history or current presence of treated or untreated:

o    diabetes mellitus, high blood pressure, thyroid disease, heart disease, kidney disease or liver disease.

-       You must not be using supplements or prescription drugs that may influence study results or have a surgery planned during the duration of the study.

This research study will last approximately 90 days and will require 5 visits to the Applied Physiology Laboratory (Fetzer Hall, Department of Exercise and Sport Science). Participants will complete an enrollment and screening visit to evaluate inclusion eligibility. Subjects will consent, complete a health history questionnaire, a brief physical, and surveys. Once included, participants will undergo baseline testing consisting of a single blood draw, vital signs, body composition, blood flow, and then will be randomly assigned to a treatment (300 mg capsule) or placebo group for 84 days of consumption. 

As a participant, you will be required to sign an informed consent document stating you understand all of the procedures and rights as a research subject. Additionally, you will receive information about your body composition and testosterone levels. Subjects who participate in this study will be compensated  $150.00 for their time upon study completion.   

If you are interested or have questions, please contact me by phone or email. 

Testosterone Research

aplresearch@unc.edu 

919-962-1663

Biomedical IRB Study #: 16-3257 Approved on 11/29/2017

subject: CORRECTION: Social Skills Group for Teenagers and Young Adults
author: dichter
content:
CORRECTION: This group will begin on  Tuesday, January 30.  The date was incorrect in the previous message.


We are pleased to announce the next session of our group-based social skills clinic for teenagers and young adults (17 years and older).  This clinical service consists of 8 hour-long weekly sessions, with the next session scheduled to begin on Tuesday, January 30 at 4:00 PM.  This clinic is offered through the Carolina Institute for Developmental Disabilities (101 Renee Lynne Court, Carrboro, NC 27510).  All major insurance providers are accepted.

Sessions will be led by Gabriel Dichter, PhD, an Associate Professor of Psychiatry at UNC and a licensed clinical psychologist.  Dr. Dichter co-developed this treatment approach and has been running this group at the CIDD since 2011.  Dr. Dichter has extensive clinical experience working with individuals with autism spectrum disorder in both individual and group settings.  He will co-lead this group with trainees who are receiving specialized training in autism and other neurodevelopmental disorders.

The group will focus on improving social cognition and social skills.  The class is open to those with a formal diagnosis that impacts their social abilities (such as autism spectrum disorder) as well as to those wishing to improve their social skills.  Because much of the class relies on back-and-forth between class members, participants must have sufficient verbal skills to participate in a group setting.  Sessions will have up to 12 participants.

Contact: Potential patients or caregivers please contact Twyla Peoples at 919-843-1529 or Twyla.peoples@cidd.unc.edu for more information about scheduling and registration.

subject: Living with an anxious family member?
author: reuman
content:
Do you have a family member who suffers with anxiety? 

Are you looking for support and skills for living with an anxious child or partner?

If you are 18 years of age or older and live with a partner or child diagnosed with an anxiety disorder, you might be eligible to participate in a research study to learn coping skills for living with an anxious loved one.

Study participation involves five weekly group sessions, as well as three study assessments. You will receive a cognitive-behaviorally based therapeutic intervention at no cost. Sessions will be held in the evenings on campus.

For more information, please contact the UNC Anxiety and Stress Disorders Clinic in Chapel Hill, NC.

Email us at anxiety@unc.edu and please include the following information:

(1) First name,

(2) Phone number, and

(3) Times you would be available to have a brief (15 minute) phone call.

This study, titled "A group intervention to reduce accommodation among relatives of individuals with fear-based disorders," has been approved by the UNC Non-Biomedical IRB (Study#17-1396 approved July 18, 2017).

subject: Join the ICAT study at UNC! Read on to see if you are eligible!
author: lnye
content:
Do you or someone you know have a recent diagnosis of a schizophrenia spectrum disorder or psychosis?

Are you/they between the ages of 18-35?

Are you/they interested in earning up to $516 for participating in research at UNC?

Would you/they be interested in receiving free therapy from trained clinicians?

Then contact the I-CAT study at 919-962-4234 or icat@unc.edu


I-CAT is a new type of psychotherapy which involves deep breathing and mindfulness techniques. People who decide to participate will be randomly assigned to either receive their usual treatment services or to 20-28 sessions of I-CAT therapy over a nine-month period (in addition to their usual treatment services). Both therapies will be given free of charge to study participants!

If you would like to learn more about the I-CAT study or find out if you are eligible, contact the study coordinator at 919-962-4234 or icat@unc.edu.




Non-Biomedical IRB #16-1173 approved on 08-09-2016. Funded by the National Institute of Mental Health.

subject: January Carolina Conversation
author: adrigibi
content:
Dear Carolina Community:

Please join us for the first Carolina Conversation of 2018, titled “Am I My Brother’s Keeper?” The event will be held on Wednesday, Jan. 10, from 4:30 – 6 p.m. at the Student Union’s Aquarium Lounge.

The session will examine common ethical issues that emerge in the university environment, barriers to action, and steps all employees can take to create a safe and productive workplace. Universities are not immune to the problems revealed in the #MeToo movement. In fact, stark power differentials, professorial autonomy, and the pressure and rewards of scholarly success add complexities to the usual workplace challenges of upholding personal and organizational integrity. What responsibility do colleagues have to create a culture of respect, fairness and freedom from retaliation or harassment?

“Am I My Brother’s Keeper?” will be presented by Dr. Kim Strom-Gottfried, director, Ethics Education & Policy Management, and Smith P. Theimann Distinguished Professor in the School of Social Work.

All faculty, staff and students are encouraged to participate in this critical discussion. Details are provided in the attached flyer.

Upcoming 2018 Carolina Conversations discussion topics will include:

February: “Talking about UNC History”

March: “Navigating Unlawful Harassment and Uncomfortable Situations in the Workplace”

April: “What Does it Mean to be a Public University?”

Dates for these monthly sessions will be announced in the near future. For more information about Carolina Conversations, please visit go.unc.edu/carolinaconversations.

Sincerely yours,

G. Rumay Alexander
Chief Diversity Officer

subject: Free Mental Health First Aid training available to UNC employees
author: vglinebe
content:
Mental Health First Aid
for UNC Chapel Hill Faculty and Staff
Mental Health First Aid is now being offered at no cost to UNC Chapel Hill faculty and staff. 

Mental Health First Aid teaches participants the common warning signs of anxiety, depression, substance use, bipolar disorder, and schizophrenia.   This 8-hour course uses skills practice and simulations to demonstrate how to offer help in a mental health or substance use crisis through a 5-step action plan, with the ultimate goal to connect persons to appropriate professional care, social support and self-help.  

New sessions are now available for January and February. Sessions are scheduled at varying times and locations throughout campus. Training options include a full day, two half-days, or Saturdays. To find a convenient date and time, and to register, visit: http://ssw.unc.edu/sswevents/mhfa-training  

 To request training for your specific group, contact the Behavioral Health Springboard of the School of Social Work at joflick@email.unc.edu

subject: Fuel your New Year’s Resolutions with Mindful Intention
author: kmeason
content:
Fuel your New Year’s Resolutions with Mindful Intention!

The UNC Mindfulness-based Program for Stress and Pain Management offers training in meditation and mind-body awareness. In these courses, you will learn how to slow down, set priorities, stay calm, focused and relaxed, and improve your ability to meet life’s challenges.  The Mindfulness practice will enhance your body's natural adaptive healing ability and will cultivate the mind's clarity and insight.

UNC Mindfulness more classes coming soon, including the RTP.

Please visit our website, www.pim.med.unc and please like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter!

 RESOLVE*

R- Recognize a hearing for change

E- Engage all your resources

S- Soften your need for speed

O- Open up with what matters to you

L- Learn to make allies of your obstacles

E- Enjoy the twists and turns

subject: Research study for adults with osteoarthritis or joint pain, aching or stiffness
author: bahorski
content:
Are you an adult with osteoarthritis or pain, aching, or stiffness in your knees or hips? 

You may be interested in a research study to help researchers learn about partner support and physical activity.  

The UNC Thurston Arthritis Research Center is conducting a research study for people with hip or knee osteoarthritis (or arthritis-related joint symptoms) and their spouse or partner. We are interested in learning how couples discuss and overcome barriers to increasing physical activity. Research shows that becoming more active can help people manage joint pain and stiffness, in addition to having other health benefits.

Participants will attend a 2 ½ hour, one-time meeting that may help them make changes to lead a more physically active lifestyle. Couples can earn up to $150 for participating in the study.

Couples will be asked to:

Participate in a videotaped conversation with their partner about physical activity
Complete an activity based on the recorded conversation
Fill out brief questionnaires
Couples will not be engaging in any physical activity during the session
You may be eligible to participate if you are…

An adult with osteoarthritis or joint symptoms, such as pain or stiffness, in your hips or knees
At least 40 years of age
Married to or living with your partner
English speaking
Are doing less than 150 minutes of physical activity per week
In addition, both you and your partner must be willing to join the study and attend the study meeting together in Chapel Hill, NC.

For more information or to find out if you are eligible, please call our toll free number at (844) 966-7538. To fill out our online screening survey, go to http://go.unc.edu/PALIS. You can also email us at palis@med.unc.edu.

This study (IRB # 16-2207) is approved by the Office of Human Research Ethics Biomedical Institutional Review Board until August 8, 2018.  This announcement was first approved by the Institutional Review Board on 1/31/17.

This message is sponsored by the Thurston Arthritis Research Center.

subject: Participate in a study on everyday life in the workplace, well-being, and sleep
author: tjolink
content:
Now enrolling participants in a research study on everyday life in the workplace. We will ask confidential questions about your everyday interactions with colleagues as well as your personal well-being. After completing this survey, you will receive $10 plus one entry into a chance drawing of $100.

Upon receipt of your completed survey, you will be scheduled to begin a 10-day sleep study, which will start within a few days. Taking 15-20 minutes each day, you will answer two short questionnaires online and use a sleep app on your smart phone from the convenience of your own home to track your sleep. Participating in both the initial survey and 10-day sleep study – about 4 to 4.5 hours total – would bring compensation to $80, plus earn you entry into 2 chance drawings for $100 each and 1 for $500.

You are eligible to enroll in this survey if you meet the following criteria:

You are at least 18 years old
You must be able to fluently read, write, and speak English
You work outside the home for at least 35 hours/week in one position
The organization you work for has at least four other employees with whom you interact on a fairly regular basis
You have been working at that organization for at least 3 months
You have a smartphone on which you could download a free sleep application
You have daily access to the Internet
You are willing to sleep with your smartphone next to your bed for 10 days – including weekends – for the 10 day sleep-tracking portion of the study
Click this link to find the consent form with more information, followed by the first survey. At the end of the survey, you will have an opportunity to sign up for the second part of the study.

Please email EverydayLifeatWork@unc.edu with questions.

Nonbiomedical IRB #15-2584, approved on 01/05/18.

subject: Seeking Participants for Neuroimaging Study
author: emmunier
content:
We are currently enrolling female participants ages 18-24 in a research study using MRI. 

Study visit involves: 
one, 3.5 to 4-hour session at the UNC Biomedical Imaging Research Center
• filling out surveys 
• MRI scan with a movie and games (no injections or contrast, and no harmful radiation)

Compensation includes: 
• between $65 and $125 total plus parking
• pictures of your brain to take home! 

The purpose of the study is to learn more about the brain and understand how youth and young adults control and manage their feelings and emotions.

You cannot participate if you are pregnant. A routine urine pregnancy test may be collected on the day of your participation to confirm you are not pregnant.

Please feel free to email (youthemotionstudy@unc.edu) or call (919-962-3993) if you are interested in participating! We look forward to hearing from you!

This non-biomedical/biomedical research study was approved by the UNC IRB (IRB# 15-2587) on 1/22/2016.

subject: January Carolina Conversation
author: adrigibi
content:
Dear Carolina Community:

Please join us for the first Carolina Conversation of 2018, titled “Am I My Brother’s Keeper?” The event will be held on Wednesday, Jan. 10, from 4:30 – 6 p.m. at the Student Union’s Aquarium Lounge.

The session will examine common ethical issues that emerge in the university environment, barriers to action, and steps all employees can take to create a safe and productive workplace. Universities are not immune to the problems revealed in the #MeToo movement. In fact, stark power differentials, professorial autonomy, and the pressure and rewards of scholarly success add complexities to the usual workplace challenges of upholding personal and organizational integrity. What responsibility do colleagues have to create a culture of respect, fairness and freedom from retaliation or harassment?

“Am I My Brother’s Keeper?” will be presented by Dr. Kim Strom-Gottfried, director, Ethics Education & Policy Management, and Smith P. Theimann Distinguished Professor in the School of Social Work.

All faculty, staff and students are encouraged to participate in this critical discussion. Details are provided in the attached flyer.

Upcoming 2018 Carolina Conversations discussion topics will include:

February: “Talking about UNC History”

March: “Navigating Unlawful Harassment and Uncomfortable Situations in the Workplace”

April: “What Does it Mean to be a Public University?”

Dates for these monthly sessions will be announced in the near future. For more information about Carolina Conversations, please visit go.unc.edu/carolinaconversations.

Sincerely yours,


G. Rumay Alexander
Chief Diversity Officer

subject: LGBQ Couples Counseling
author: pentel
content:
Do you and your romantic partner both identify as women?

Are you interested in LGBQ affirming couples counseling?

Are you experiencing challenges in your relationship, in part due to facing LGBQ related stressors? 

If you are age 21+ and live together, you may be eligible to receive no cost, affirming couple therapy specifically for LGBQ women. 

To learn more:
1) Check out our website: ACCESSprogram.web.unc.edu
2) Questions? Interested in participating? Contact Kim Pentel (she/her) at ACCESSprogram@unc.edu, with the subject line “ACCESS.” All inquiries are confidential.

We are proud to serve couples from diverse backgrounds. Our team has experience and training working with LGBQ couples and we strive to provide a safe space for you and your loved one.

This is a therapy research study. Study Title: ACCESS: Affirming Couples Counseling to Engage Same-Sex partners. UNC-CH IRB #: 17-2482, Non-biomedical. Date Approved: October 17, 2017.

subject: NOMINATIONS FOR UNIVERSITY AWARDS FOR THE ADVANCEMENT OF WOMEN
author: clarec
content:
Call for Nominations: 2018 University Awards for the Advancement of Women

Deadline: Friday, January 26th, at 5pm. See http://womenscenter.unc.edu/about-us/awards/ for more details.
 
On behalf of the Offices of the Chancellor and the Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost, the Carolina Women's Center is pleased to call for nominations for the 2018 University Awards for the Advancement of Women.  These awards recognize contributions by people of all genders to the advancement of women at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
 
Each year, the award recognizes a faculty member, a staff member, a graduate or professional student or postdoctoral fellow, and an undergraduate. The faculty and staff recipients each receive $5000. Each student recipient receives $2500. Awardees are honored in a ceremony during the Carolina Women’s Center’s annual Gender Week Celebration in the spring. Please see the website for requirements and to submit a nomination.
 
Contact clarecounihan@unc.edu with questions.

subject: Reminder: Stadium Drive Closed to Through Traffic
author: sboyle
content:
Attention UNC Students, Faculty and Staff:

This is a reminder that underground utility work for the Central Campus Athletics Project has required the closure of a portion of Stadium Drive Monday, Dec. 18, 2017, through March 1, 2018. During this period, Stadium Drive will be closed to through traffic.

Please drive slowly and with caution, follow detour signs and stay alert to temporary crosswalk locations during this project. Pedestrians should remain alert to changes in traffic patterns and follow signage along Stadium Drive designating pedestrian reroutes. Visit the Facilities Services website for detour maps and project updates.


Chapel Hill Transit has implemented detours on the A, NU and U routes, and bus stops for these routes on Stadium Drive and on South Road at Student Stores and Fetzer Gym will not be served. Visit Chapel Hill Transit for information on alternative stops and route detours.

The Point-to-Point Express will follow a detour schedule when service resumes Monday, Jan. 8.

S4 permit parking will continue to be available on Stadium Drive and can be accessed from the South and Ridge Road entrances. Overflow parking for S4 permit holders is available in the Rams Head Parking Deck on Ridge Road.

For questions about the nature and scope of the Central Campus Athletics Project, contact Mike Bunting, associate athletic director, at mbunting@unc.edu.

For construction questions or concerns, contact Keith Snead, construction manager, at keith.snead@facilities.unc.edu.

For questions concerning transportation and parking, contact UNC Transportation & Parking during regular business hours at 919-962-3951.

subject: Open Campus Accessibility Meeting
author: kwbryant
content:
We are writing on behalf of the University’s Digital Accessibility Advisory Team (DAAT) to invite you to attend the Campus Accessibility Meeting on Thursday, January 18, 2018, from 1:00–2:30 p.m. at the Carolina Union – Great Hall, on the subject of UNC-Chapel Hill’s digital accessibility compliance efforts.

This meeting is a follow-up to the Commitment and Call to Action memo that was sent out to campus on October 11, 2017. As part of a broader assessment of our campus’ accessibility to people with disabilities, the University has engaged The Paciello Group (TPG, www.paciellogroup.com) to help us improve the accessibility of our digital environment.  As part of this engagement, we are working with TPG to create an Accessibility Roadmap that articulates our commitment to accessibility and charts a course for building and sustaining a practice of accessibility.

This  Campus Accessivility Meeting is intended provide the campus community with an opportunity to learn more about our Digital Accessibility Initiative and TPG’s involvement in helping the University define achieveable and sustainable goals and timelines for advancing accessibility. The meeting will be opportunity for you to hear from them about their work, ask questions about the initiative, and provide your opinions.

If you or anyone in your department is interested in attending this event, please RSVP at https://eoc.unc.edu/event/accessibility-open-meeting/.

If you need accommodations for the event (e.g., sign language interpreters), please contact Rudy Jones at rudy_jones@unc.edu, (919) 962-9980, or (T) 711 NC RELAY as soon as possible.

For more information on the University’s Digital Accessibility Initiative, visit http://digitalaccess.unc.edu/.

 

Sincerely,

Rudy Jones

Brandon Washington

Tiffany Bailey

subject: FREE STATISTICAL CONSULTING
author: marron
content:
Free Statistical Consulting

The UNC Department of Statistics and Operations Research announces the availability of free statistical consulting.  Our goal is to teach this important skill to graduate students, but you can get some free statistical assistance in the process.

        The course format involves clients giving a presentation about the problem at hand.  This generates a question and answer dialog, which by itself has proven to be useful in helping clients formulate their ideas.  Then typically one student is assigned to work on the actual data, with a final written report expected.

In the past we have worked with a very wide range of clients, from Masters students needing help with the statistical end of their dissertation, all the way up to distinguished professors.  While there are limits to what can be done in the context of this course, some contacts initially made through this course have led to ongoing joint research, grant proposals and published papers in very diverse fields.

        To sign up for this type of consulting, or to discuss this further, please contact Steve Marron, Department of Statistics and Operations Research, UNC, CB 3260, Email: marron@unc.edu. Additional information is available at the web address:

http://stat-or.unc.edu/consulting/unc-statistical-consulting-center/
comments:
Please help me get the word out on this topic that many will find useful.
Thanks.

subject: Recruitment for Muscle Aging and Quality Study
author: haydeng
content:
Hello,

   My name is Hayden Giuliani and I am a graduate student in the Department of Exercise and Sport Science at UNC. I am conducting a study that is examining how the quality of your muscles influences how your muscles change size when they contract and how this may influence how strong you are and how fast you walk. For this study, we are looking for adult males between the ages of 65-74 years to complete two visits at the Neuromuscular Research Laboratory in the Department of Exercise and Sport Science that will last approximately two hours (visit 1) and 45 minutes (visit 2). To qualify, you must have a BMI of 30 or above (formula below) and do not exercise for more than 3 hours per week.

   You will perform a submaximal and maximal leg extension exercises of your thigh muscles with sensors taped to your muscles, and size and quality of your thigh muscles will be measured using ultrasonography while you are at rest, and during the strength assessments. For completing both visits associated with this study, you will receive $60 and free health information from the testing. Free parking is provided. Please let me know if you have any questions and if you are interested in participating in our study. You can email me at haydeng@live.unc.edu or call me at 919-843-2014.

 

BMI = Weight (lb) ÷ Height (in) ÷ Height (in) × 703

 

Thank you for your time and I look forward to hearing from you!

 

Hayden Giuliani, MA, ATC, CSCS

Research Coordinator - Neuromuscular Research Laboratory

Department of Exercise and Sport Science

UNC Chapel Hill



IRB #: 16-1523

Biomedical

Date Approved (Updated): 09/2017

subject: Reminder: 2-Step Verification Required for VPN
author: hashk
content:
We would like to remind faculty and staff that 2-Step Verification is required to use VPN. During inclement weather days when the University operates on reduced hours or closes, VPN use spikes as many staff and faculty choose to work from alternate locations.  

Register for 2-Step Verification 

Visit onyen.unc.edu and click "Register & Manage 2-Step Verification." The registration process for 2-Step takes just 10 minutes. 

Already registered for 2-Step? 

Are you already registered for 2-Step, but need a refresher on how it works with VPN? Click the "VPN" tab on this help document: help.unc.edu/help/duo for step-by-step instructions. 

Want to learn more? 

You can visit its.unc.edu/2-step to learn more about 2-Step on our campus, why it's important and how it keeps you and Carolina secure. As always, if you need assistance please don't hesitate to contact 962-HELP.

subject: Dental Research Opportunity
author: kristyw
content:
Are you interested in participating in a dental research study?



The General and Oral Health Center is currently recruiting participants for a research study looking at the effects of e-cigarettes on the oral cavity. If you qualify to be in the study, participation will include 1 study visit that lasts about 1.5 hours. The study visit will take place in the GO Health Clinic, located within the UNC School of Dentistry. 

You may be eligible to participate if you:

Are 18-40 years old
Are a current E-Cigarette user with NO previous (within the past 6 months) cigarette usage.
Are generally healthy
Do not require antibiotics prior to dental treatment
Are not taking any inhalant medications within the past month
Participants that complete this study will receive $75.00 and free parking vouchers to the Dogwood visitor parking deck. 

If interested, please contact the Go Health Center:

919-537-3424

www.gohealthcenter.org

gohealthcenter@unc.edu



This study is approved by the UNC Biomedical IRB

IRB Study #: 16-0824/Approved : April 14, 2016

subject: Update on Winter Storm Grayson
author: janerc
content:
Colleagues,

We are currently monitoring the potential for winter weather later this evening and into tomorrow morning. At this point, measurable precipitation is not expected in Chapel Hill; however, areas to the east may see more significant precipitation. Because of the below-freezing temperatures, there is potential for dangerous conditions during the morning commute for individuals driving from east of Chapel Hill. The latest weather briefing from the National Weather Service can be found here.

At this time, we anticipate campus will continue operating as normal for this event. We are encouraging you to allow employees to evaluate conditions in their areas and be flexible if any employees feel they cannot safely make it to campus. As a reminder, the adverse weather policy can be found here.

UNC Facilities has staff on standby to prepare buildings and walkways if necessary. Critical areas such as hospital parking lots and travel lanes will be pre-treated. 

Parking and Transportation will be blocking the top level of parking decks at 7 p.m. today. If there is any change to local/regional public transportation services, the S11 lot will be open and available for employees without parking permits. Any updates or impacts to parking and transportation services will be posted at https://move.unc.edu/news/weather/.

The adverse weather team will continue to monitor the conditions overnight and we will update you if the path of the storm shifts and any major impacts to campus are expected.

Thanks,

Derek Kemp
Associate Vice Chancellor for Campus Safety and Risk Management

subject: Recruiting for Lyme Disease Experience Study
author: sasinger
content:
Hello!

I am conducting a research study to learn about the daily experience of living with Lyme Disease. I hope to gain insight into the diagnosis, treatment, and symptom management processes.

To participate in this study, you must:

Have been diagnosed with Lyme Disease by a healthcare professional
Have experienced Lyme Disease-related health problems for 1 year or longer
Be comfortable speaking in English
Be over the age of 18
The study will consist of a 1-hour long interview on the phone or in person at a location of the participant’s choosing in January, February, or March 2018.

If you are interested, please email me at sasinger@live.unc.edu or call me at (919) 438-3026. I will follow up with further information, including information about informed consent, confidentiality, risks, and benefits to participating in the study.

 

Best wishes,

Sarah Singer

 

Contact Information:

Department of English and Comparative Literature

The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

subject: Needed 5-10 years old children for a hearing study
author: mdev
content:
HEARING RESEARCH STUDY                                                                             

 

We are currently recruiting listeners for a hearing research study.

 

Your child may be eligible to participate in this research study if:

-he or she is between the ages of 5-10 years old

-he or she has normal hearing

-he or she has no history of ear problems

 

The purpose of this research study is to obtain a better understanding of hearing.

 

Participants will sit in a soundproof room and listen to sounds presented over headphones. The research study will take approximately 1-2 sessions of one hour each and takes place in Marsico Hall. Your child will be compensated for his or her time at a rate of $15/hour.

 

If your child is interested in participating in this research study please contact us atHearingLab@med.unc.edu.

 

This study has been approved by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill's Biomedical Institutional Review Board: Study #86-0059. The title for this IRB study is "Development and Plasticity in Normal and Impaired Ears". The most recent approved IRB modification date is 11/13/2013.

subject: Interim Director and Deputy Director Named for the UNC Highway Safety Research Center
author: briordan
content:
Date: January 3, 2018

To: Deans, Directors, and Department Chairs

From: Terry Magnuson, Vice Chancellor for Research

Re: Interim Director and Deputy Director Named for the UNC Highway Safety Research Center

 

Dear Colleagues,

Daniel Carter began as interim director, and Caroline Mozingo as interim deputy director, of the University of North Carolina Highway Safety Research Center (HSRC)on January 1, 2018, as former Director David Harkey, PhD, retired last month.

Daniel Carter served as a senior research associate at the HSRC. He joined the center in 2004 and uses his civil engineering background to address highway safety from the standpoint of infrastructure improvements. His research experience includes the areas of roadway and safety data, countermeasure evaluation and pedestrian safety.

Caroline Mozingo served in her current role as the senior manager of communications, education and outreach for HSRC in January 2012. She leads the center’s internal and external communications, strategic development and education efforts, and supports individual project communications needs. Previously, Caroline served as the communications and marketing manager for the National Center for Safe Routes to School, which is housed within HSRC.

Carter and Mozingo will be responsible for leading the center’s research programs, innovative approaches, and translation of research knowledge into practical interventions. HSRC manages the Collaborative Sciences Center for Road Safety, one of the U.S. Department of Transportation's five national University Transportation Centers. It is also home to several other major initiatives, including the Highway Safety Information System described above, Pedestrian and Bicycle Information Center, Road Safety Academy, and Buckle Up NC, all of which aim to translate research into practice.

Thanks to HSRC — the only transportation center in the country focused solely on highway safety — being on the road today is much safer than it was 50 years ago when the center was founded. Dedicated to the promotion of the multidisciplinary interest in highway safety, HSRC has made a special effort to share expertise and research with communities, students, researchers, and practitioners.

Carter and Mozingo succeed David Harkey, who served as the director of HSRC since 2006, and retired from the university in December. In January, he assumed the role of president of both the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety and the Highway Loss Data Institute.

With over 30 years of experience in the field of transportation safety research, including the past 23 with HSRC, Harkey has managed more than 30 major research projects and authored over 70 articles and research reports for federal, state, and private sponsors. He currently serves as the principal investigator for the Federal Highway Administration's Highway Safety Information System. Managed out of HSRC, this system is the only national database capable of conducting comprehensive risk analysis by linking crash data with roadway inventory and traffic operations data.

A search committee has been established and will be working to identify HSRC's next director. Until the committee identifies a permanent successor, please join me in supporting Daniel and Caroline in their new roles, and in congratulating David on his retirement and his many years of service to the university.

subject: Research study for individuals with dust mite allergy who smoke cigarettes or use an electronic vaping device
author: bgbradfo
content:
IRB #16-1622:  Evaluation of the effect of a nasal allergen challenge with Dermatophagoides farinae extract (dust mites) on nasal airway inflammation in allergic individuals, comparing electronic vaping device users to cigarette smokers and non-smokers.


SUBJECT:  INFORMATIONAL: Research study for individuals with dust mite allergy who smoke cigarettes or use an electronic vaping device

 

The purpose of this research study is to help us understand if people who smoke cigarettes or use an electronic vaping device, and who are allergic to dust mites, have a different response from being exposed to dust mites than people who don’t smoke anything.  
Volunteers must be otherwise healthy but have an allergy to dust mites. Pregnant or nursing females are excluded. You should not be in this study if you have any illness that might interfere with this study or make it unsafe for you to participate, including (but not limited to) heart disease, diabetes, thyroid disease or kidney disease. Mild, well controlled asthma is not an exclusion. If your asthma requires rescue treatment with albuterol every day, or if you have very frequent asthma symptoms, this would be an exclusion. Study participation will include 5 visits over 3 month period, totaling up to 14+ hrs. There is an initial 4 hour screening visit which is separate from the study visits.

 

Contact

·       (919) 966-2879 or email  bgb10@unc.edu

·        submit a questionnaire at  www.med.unc.edu/cemalb

Requirements

·       You must be between 18 and 50.

·       You must be a healthy person with a dust mite allergy

Women who are pregnant, trying to become pregnant, or nursing a baby cannot participate.

Time Commitment

·       A one-time visit for our Screening Protocol (IRB #98-0799)
·       Research study participation will consist of 5 visits over a period of 3 months (depending on scheduling needs).
Compensation

·          Screening Protocol visit $75.00

·          Complete 5 study visits and smoking diaries – up to   $850.00

 

            

Approved 10/06/2017 by the Biomedical Institutional Review Board.  IRB #16-1622

 

This e-mail is sponsored by the UNC Center for Environmental Medicine, Asthma and Lung Biology

subject: Healthy women needed for research study
author: jlphilli
content:
Reproductive Endocrinology at NC Women's Hospital

 

We are currently seeking healthy women to participate in research studies.  Several opportunities are available that offer monetary compensation, ranging from $25-200.

 

You may be qualified if the following applies to you:

- Between the ages of 18-35

- Having regular menstrual cycles, every 25-35 days

- Not using birth control pills, hormonal contraceptives or IUD

- Not currently pregnant, or trying to become pregnant

-Flexible schedule

 

The ultimate goal of this research is to better understand the factors that allow implantation to occur so that we may improve clinical outcomes of fertility patients.  If you are interested, please feel free to contact us for more information at uncreproductive@gmail.com.

 

Biomedical IRB study #05-1757 “Molecular Regulation in Reproduction;” approved 01/22/2017

subject: New Director of Auxiliary Services
author: oliviamj
content:
TO:                         Deans, Directors and Department Chairs

FROM:                   Brad Ives, Associate Vice Chancellor, Campus Enterprises

SUBJECT:              New Director of Auxiliary Services

DATE:                    December 20, 2017

 

Following an extensive search, I am pleased to announce that Scott Myers has become the new director of auxiliary services, effective Dec. 18.

Scott has served as the interim director of auxiliary services since February 2017. He brings with him experience and institutional knowledge gained from 22 years of service with the University, nine of which have been as the associate director of auxiliary services and director of food and vending. As interim director of auxiliary services, Scott supported the University’s partnership with Barnes and Noble and completed a $3.8M store renovation and led the Carolina Managed Print team in completing the transition of multifunction devices to Xerox on campus, resulting in savings of more than $690,000 since initiating the deployment.

In his new role, Scott will continue to provide leadership and direction to more than 800 auxiliary services and contracted employees. His experience with business operations, retail management and design projects will serve to support his department in future initiatives.

I wish to thank the search committee and others in the campus community who were involved in the selection process, and to give special thanks to Cheryl Stout for her role as chair of the search committee.

Please join me in congratulating Scott as the new director of auxiliary services.

subject: New Property Office Director
author: sboyle
content:
To:                 Deans, Directors and Department Chairs
From:             Gordon Merklein, Associate Vice Chancellor, University Real Estate Operations
Date:              Dec. 20, 2017
Subject:         New Property Office Director

I’m happy to announce that, after a comprehensive search, Bruce Warrington is the new Property Office Director, effective Dec. 18.

A Carolina MBA alum, Bruce brings more than a decade of real estate and capital asset management experience to the property office. Most recently, Bruce worked at UNC General Administration as Capital Planning Director. Prior to that, Bruce worked as a real estate Transaction Manager at both Carolinas HealthCare System and the Bank of America. 

In his role as Property Office Director, Bruce will oversee 550,000 square feet of lease property, 90,000 square feet of UNC Foundation and Endowment-owned office and retail buildings, 150 acres of strategic land holdings, and gift properties.

Bruce will lead the existing property office team, including Alex Ashton, Loci Zsuppan and Theo Sullivan. I know Bruce will build on the strong foundation that Jeff Kidd built, and that he looks forward to working closely with staff throughout the Division of Finance and Administration, as well as with others across campus.

Many thanks to Alex Ashton for his leadership during the interim, as well as for the time and effort of the search committee, which included Anna Wu, Mary Beth Koza, Micah Malouf, John Carlson, Andy Johns and Bianca Fankhauser.

Please join me in welcoming Bruce Warrington to UNC-Chapel Hill.

subject: REMINDER - Facilities Services Coverage for Winter Break
author: sboyle
content:
TO:                   Deans, Directors and Department Chairs
                         University Business Managers

FROM:              Anna Wu, Associate Vice Chancellor for Facilities Services

SUBJECT:         REMINDER - Facilities Services Coverage for Winter Break

DATE:               Dec. 20, 2017

UNC-Chapel Hill will observe a ten-day closure of the University during Winter Break 2017. This is a reminder that during this time, Facilities Services will have limited staff resources on call. The following areas may be of interest to your department regarding service coverage during the break:

Housekeeping and Building Services: Staff will be available on an on-call basis to handle emergencies that should arise. Response times may be lengthened due to this status. The on-call service period will begin Friday night, Dec. 22, at 10 p.m., and end Tuesday morning, Jan. 2.

Energy Management: The University will implement a Winter Holiday Energy Saving Initiative to reduce energy consumption and utility costs by lowering temperatures in unoccupied buildings. This cost-effective initiative resulted in savings of $123,000 during Winter Break 2016. It is asked that you turn off all lights and unnecessary equipment and close all windows and fume hood sashes before leaving campus. The Initiative will begin Friday night, Dec. 22, at 10 p.m., and end Monday night, Jan. 1, at 10 p.m.

Exceptions to the Energy Saving Initiative: Research labs, animal facilities and designated health care facilities that are critical to the University’s mission are not included in this initiative. Other building occupants who submitted Exemption Requests by the Nov. 28 deadline have been notified of approved exemptions. However, even in these facilities the Housekeeping and Building Services on-call service period will be in effect.

We appreciate your support and look forward to a successful Energy Saving Initiative over Winter Break 2017. For questions or concerns, contact Energy Management at save-energy@unc.edu.

subject: University Teaching Awards
author: ddd3
content:
TO: Faculty, Staff, and Students

FROM: Dr. Adam Persky and Dr. Viji Sathy, Co-Chairs

University Committee on Teaching Awards

SUBJECT: Teaching Award Nominations

 As we prepare for Winter graduation, please consider nominating deserving teachers for the 2019 University Teaching Awards.  This is a particularly good time to reflect on the past year (or years) and remember teachers who have really made a difference.  All members of the Carolina community are encouraged to nominate candidates for the 2019 awards.

 The awards provide us with a way to acknowledge the central role of teaching at UNC-Chapel Hill by recognizing outstanding teachers and mentors.  Some awards are available to graduate teaching assistants and staff, as well as to professors. Specific categories are shown below. A flow chart has been provided on the Provost’s website to help you identify the best award for the deserving teacher

Board of Governors' Award for Excellence in Teaching, given to a tenured faculty member on each campus for excellent and exceptional teaching at the undergraduate level over a sustained period of time (e.g., most of a career).
Distinguished Teaching Awards for Post-Baccalaureate Instruction (4 awards), given to faculty members for exceptional teaching of graduate students, inside and outside of the classroom.
Awards to Faculty for Excellence in Undergraduate Teaching: Five Tanner Awards, one Friday Award and one Sitterson Award, given to full-time faculty members
Tanner Awards to Graduate Teaching Assistants (5 awards), given to graduate teaching assistants for excellence in undergraduate teaching.
Mentor Award for Lifetime Achievement, acknowledging lifetime contributions to teaching, learning and mentoring beyond the classroom. It is not limited to traditional faculty. Nominations for this award should focus on the candidate's long-term impact on students.
Chapman Family Teaching Awards: Three or four Chapman Family Awards are given to full-time faculty members for excellence in undergraduate teaching.

 Details of each of these awards can be found at http://provost.unc.edu/teaching-awards


 Please read the award requirements carefully to determine eligibility and provide comments in the nomination that will help the committee understand why your nominee is the best candidate for the award.

 Specific examples of particular ways in which the nominee has made a difference are especially effective.  The comments will become part of the nominee's departmental personnel file.  A nomination letter or statement must be included or the submission is invalid and will not be considered. A guidance document can be found on the Provost’s website to help construct an effective nomination letter.

 Nominations are accepted year round, but there are deadlines to observe.

 October 1 is the deadline for nominations for the awards to be announced in spring 2019.  (This allows time for the committee to review the nominees, collect additional information about their teaching and recommend winners to the Chancellor.)  The 2018 winners will be announced soon by the Chancellor and Provost soon.

 Please submit all nominations online at

http://provost.unc.edu/teaching-awards


Thank you for your help in recognizing excellent teaching at Carolina, and congratulations to all students graduating this Sunday.  Well done!
