subject: Message from Chancellor Carol L. Folt
author: janerc
content:
Dear Carolina Community:

It is with great appreciation for his faithful service and excitement for his new opportunity that I share with you that Wayne Blair, University ombuds and director of the University Ombuds Office, has accepted a position as ombuds person for the Asian Development Bank, an international development finance institution dedicated to reducing poverty and increasing the quality of life in Asia and the Pacific. Wayne will be leaving his position in early 2018.

Wayne has been ombuds since coming to Carolina in 2005 when he worked to establish the University Ombuds Office. Since that time, he has built a nationally renowned program based on the principles of confidentiality, neutrality, informality and independence. During his 12-year tenure, Wayne has assisted thousands of students, faculty and staff and provided advice to senior leadership.

Wayne’s many contributions have extended beyond the campus. He developed and briefly led the ombuds program for the Town of Chapel Hill and has continued as a consultant to the program. He also took on leadership and teaching responsibilities for the International Ombuds Association, and ombuds from around the world have turned to Wayne for counsel and best practices.

I am excited for Wayne and his opportunity to pursue this global opportunity. The Ombuds Office will continue to be staffed by Laurie Mesibov and Victoria Dowd, both of whom have worked side by side with Wayne since 2005. I am confident that we can build on the great work Wayne has done and will attract an outstanding successor for this important position. I will announce plans to launch a national search in the new year to identify the best candidates for the role of ombuds.

Please join me in thanking Wayne for his years of successful leadership as University ombuds. He has been an integral member of this campus and a valued colleague. 

Sincerely,

Carol L. Folt
Chancellor

subject: Message from Chancellor Carol L. Folt
author: janerc
content:
Dear Carolina Community:

It is with gratitude for his contributions that I am writing to let you know that Matt Fajack, vice chancellor for Finance and Administration, has accepted a position as the vice president for financial affairs at the University of Alabama. He will leave Carolina in early February to start his new job.

Matt has served as our chief finance and business officer since 2014 and has been an integral part of my senior leadership team. Matt has helped us reimagine the way the University conducts business and has worked to streamline our operations, as we have become a more complex and layered University.

During Matt's tenure, we launched the Three Zeros initiative—a bold goal to reduce our environmental footprint through net zero water usage, zero waste to landfills and net zero greenhouse gas emissions.  He oversaw the transition of our Student Stores operation into modern retail space that is generating millions of dollars for student aid. Matt has also worked with the campus master planning team to ensure that the physical plans for campus are fully aligned with the priorities of our strategic framework.

Matt has built a talented leadership team within Finance and Administration that will continue operating at the highest levels.  Provost Bob Blouin will lead a search for Matt’s successor and will announce his plans in the coming weeks. 

Please join me in thanking Matt for his leadership during the last three years and for all he has done for Carolina. He has been a valued member of my senior leadership team and I wish him well in his next endeavor. 

Sincerely,

Carol L. Folt
Chancellor

subject: Stadium Drive Will Close to Through Traffic Beginning Dec. 18
author: sboyle
content:
Attention UNC Students, Faculty and Staff:

Underground utility work for the Central Campus Athletics Project will require the closure of a portion of Stadium Drive beginning Monday, Dec. 18, 2017, through March 1, 2018. During this period, Stadium Drive will be closed to through traffic.

Please drive slowly and with caution, follow detour signs and stay alert to temporary crosswalk locations during this project. Pedestrians should remain alert to changes in traffic patterns and follow signage along Stadium Drive designating pedestrian reroutes. Visit the Facilities Services website for detour maps and project updates.


Chapel Hill Transit will implement detours on the A, NU and U routes beginning Monday, Dec. 18. Bus stops for these routes on Stadium Drive and on South Road at Student Stores and Fetzer Gym will not be served. Visit Chapel Hill Transit for information on alternative stops and route detours.

The Point-to-Point Express will suspend service for Winter Break Dec. 16, 2017, and will follow a detour schedule when service resumes Jan. 8, 2018.

S4 permit parking will continue to be available on Stadium Drive and can be accessed from the South and Ridge Road entrances. Overflow parking for S4 permit holders will be available in the Rams Head Parking Deck on Ridge Road.

For questions about the nature and scope of the Central Campus Athletics Project, contact Mike Bunting, associate athletic director, at mbunting@unc.edu.

For construction questions or concerns, contact Keith Snead, construction manager, at keith.snead@facilities.unc.edu.

For questions concerning transportation and parking, contact UNC Transportation & Parking during regular business hours at 919-962-3951.

subject: Research Subjects Needed for Antibody Infusion & Bacterial Disease Research Study
author: kamarena
content:
Healthy, non-HIV, male volunteers between the ages of 18 and 35
Subjects will be randomized to receive human antibody infusion or control followed by a controlled bacterial infection.
Subjects required to return to Outpatient Clinical Research Unit at UNC Hospitals for a maximum of 12 visits.
Monetary compensation of up to $1,500 will be provided at completion of research study.

To find out more about this research study, please contact 984-227-2275 or via email: NG_outpatient@med.unc.edu with the following information:

Name
Email address
Phone number
Best time to be contacted

This study titled "IGHID 11705: A Randomized, Open-label, Controlled Clinical Trial to Assess the Efficacy of F598 in Preventing an Experimental Urethral Infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae in Healthy Male Subjects" was approved by the UNC Biomedical IRB on 7/3/2017 with IRB# 17-0566.

subject: Holiday Carolina Blood Drive tomorrow!
author: rbeatty
content:
The Employee Forum and the American Red Cross will host the 19th annual Holiday Carolina Blood Drive, Dec. 12, 7:30 a.m. - 1 p.m. in Fetzer Hall.

Each year, the Red Cross provides 20,000 units of red blood cells to UNC Hospitals. You can help the Red Cross continue to meet this need during the busy holiday season. Giving blood is easy - it only takes about an hour, and saving a life is a great way to get into the holiday spirit.

Schedule an appointment - Speak with a Red Cross representative to schedule an appointment by calling 1-800-RED CROSS. Sign up online at redcrossblood.org with the sponsor code UNC or use the Red Cross Blood Donor App.

Use RapidPass - Blood and platelet donors can save up to 15 minutes at their next donation by using RapidPass to complete their pre-donation reading and health history questionnaire online, on the day of their donation, from a computer or mobile device. Learn more or complete a RapidPass at redcrossblood.org/RapidPass.

Walk-up appointments are also welcome – there will be a pod designated for walk-up donors. Free parking is available in Cobb Deck off Country Club Road, and all presenting donors will enjoy snacks provided by Biscuitville and Carolina Dining Services. Donors will also receive a free, Holiday Carolina Blood Drive  T-shirt. For eligibility requirements, details or to volunteer, visit Carolina Blood Drive.

Join us and give the gift of life at the Holiday Carolina Blood Drive!

subject: ITS Winter Break Reminders
author: hashk
content:
Limited holiday hours 

In observance of Winter Break, Information Technology Services (ITS) will operate on a limited schedule from Saturday, December 23, 2017 – Monday, January 1, 2018. Faculty, staff and students should anticipate extended response times to support requests during this period. We encourage you to address any outstanding IT support needs prior to the start of Winter Break. Support requests can be submitted via help.unc.edu or by calling 919-962-HELP. 

Watch out for phish! 

As we experienced over the Thanksgiving break, phishing attacks greatly increase immediately before and during holidays. Phishers know this is an opportune time of the year, when people are often overtasked and more distracted. We strongly encourage you to question any notifications you receive during this time period, particularly those that encourage you to verify credentials or take other immediate action. As always, you can review the latest verified phishing attempts by visiting: phish.unc.edu.

subject: MLK Celebration 2018
author: adrigibi
content:
MLK CELEBRATION EVENTS ANNOUNCED


UNC-Chapel Hill’s 2018 Martin Luther King Jr. Celebration Week, which honors the bridge-building legacy of Dr. King, kicks off Jan. 14 and includes events that highlight the intersectionality of diversity, inclusion, and social justice. The annual MLK Community University Banquet, the UNC MLK 5K, and the Keynote Lecture and Awards Ceremony will provide the traditional start to a week of activities that will also include a unity dinner, candlelight vigil, artistic interpretations, and opportunities for cross-cultural and intergroup dialogue. All events are designed to celebrate and educate the UNC-Chapel Hill community about the legacy of Dr. King, using the theme, “Voices. Power. Movement.”

The MLK week of events at Carolina is co-led by The MLK Student Planning Committee,  comprised of representatives from Advocates for Carolina, Alpha Phi Alpha, Black Student Movement, Campus Y, Carolina Indian Circle, Carolina Union Activity Board, Carolina Women’s Center, CHispA, Graduate and Professional Student Federation, NAACP, NC Hillel, National Pan-Hellenic Council, ROCTS, and Student Government’s Multicultural Affairs and Diversity Outreach Committee, and The University Office for Diversity and Inclusion.

MLK Community/University Banquet – Sunday, Jan. 14, at 6 p.m., with a reception at 5 p.m., at the William and Ida Friday Center for Continuing Education. Chancellor Carol L. Folt will deliver the keynote. Tickets are $30. To purchase tickets or for additional information, please contact MLK celebrations co-coordinator Ariana Wiggins at arariana@live.unc.edu.       

Day of Service 5K Run – Monday, Jan. 15, at 7:30 a.m. (registration begins at 7 a.m. at the Campus Y). Early bird registration is $25 per person until Jan. 1, 2018, with discounted rates of $20 for students or groups of 10 or more (per person). Per-person registration after Jan. 2 through race day is $30. Register online at bit.do/mlk5k or at rocts.web.unc.edu. In keeping with Dr. King’s bridge-building work, race proceeds will benefit Girls on the Run of the Triangle and Healthy Girls Save the World, an organization founded by a Carolina alumna. For additional information, please contact MLK celebrations co-coordinator Deanna Fayed at dfayed@live.unc.edu.

Lecture and Awards Ceremony – Thursday, Jan. 18, at 7:30 p.m., at Memorial Hall. North Carolina native and former United States Attorney General Loretta Lynch will deliver the lecture. Tickets are free and will be available at the Carolina Performing Arts ticket office on Jan. 3. For group tickets and further information, please contact MLK celebrations co-coordinator Sophia McFarlane at mlk@unc.edu.                    

.

 For additional information about the full roster of events, visit diversity.unc.edu/mlk.

author: jlkelly
content:
To:          Deans, Directors and Department Chairs

From:    DeAhn Baucom, University Cashier

Re:         Campus Deposit Deadlines for Calendar Year End

Date:     December 6, 2017

 

Please note and share as appropriate the following adjusted deadlines related to December 2017 month end processing of cash, checks, credit card and electronic payments submitted through the Cashier’s Office. These adjustments to the usual monthly deadlines are due to the long winter holiday break. We appreciate your attention to these critical deposit deadlines for December month end close.

Cash and Check Deposits:

All cash/check deposits submitted in ConnectCarolina in December 2017 must be received by 9 a.m. Tuesday, Jan. 2, 2018, to be approved with an effective date of Dec. 31, 2017.

NOTE:  University Mail Services will not deliver mail during the winter break -- Monday, Dec. 25, 2017 through Monday, Jan. 1, 2018. Mail delivery will resume the afternoon of Jan. 2, 2018.  Therefore, submitted cash/check deposits must be placed in the night depository outside of SASB North OR hand-delivered to the Cashier’s Office by 9:00 a.m. on Tuesday, Jan. 2, 2018, to be considered a December deposit.  It is unlikely that deposits placed in campus mail late in the week ending Friday, Dec. 22 will be processed as a December deposit.

Credit Card/Electronic Deposits:

Departments must submit deposits by the below deadlines:

For settlements occurring

	

Submitted deposit due




Prior to Wednesday, Dec. 20, 2017

 

	

By 10am of the business day following the settlement day (normal processing deadline)




Thursday, Dec. 21, 2017

	

By 5pm Friday, Dec. 22, 2017




Friday, December 22 through Thursday, Dec. 28, 2017

	

By 5pm Tuesday, Jan. 2, 2018

The Cashier’s office will approve all bank dates through Dec. 30, 2017 by 5pm on Wednesday, Jan. 3, 2018.

NOTE: Please be sure your department has staff available to make necessary corrections to deposits Jan. 3, 2018.

subject: UNC Travel Reminders
author: hunan
content:
Dear Students, Faculty and Staff:

Each year, hundreds of people in the Carolina community travel internationally for important academic, research and outreach opportunities. We also travel abroad for personal reasons. In all cases, we would like to remind you of University requirements and resources that can help inform your plans for safe and productive international travel.

UNC Global Travel Registry 
(http://globaltravel.unc.edu)

Anyone traveling internationally in affiliation with the University must register the trip in the University's Global Travel Registry. The Global Travel Registry is a secure database with itineraries and contact information for students, faculty, and staff traveling abroad. The information in this database assists us in reaching travelers in case of urgent health or safety concerns. Students enrolled in travel programs through the Office of Study Abroad website or through their professional school administrator are automatically enrolled in the registry. For more information, please see https://global.unc.edu/travel-info/global-travel-registry or contact Andrew Hunt in the Office of the Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost at 919.962.3622 or andrew.hunt@unc.edu.

Insurance Coverage Abroad 
http://global.unc.edu/travel-info/travel-insurance-and-risk-management

Anyone traveling internationally in affiliation with the University must also enroll in the international health, evacuation, and repatriation insurance program established by General Administration and administered by GeoBlue. To enroll, please contact Janet Hoernke in Risk Management Services at 919.962.6681 or janet_hoernke@unc.edu. Students participating in programs through the Office of Study Abroad website or through their professional school administrator are pre-enrolled for coverage. For other travel not affiliated with UNC, we encourage you to review your insurance coverage before traveling and, if necessary, consider purchasing a supplemental policy to cover you while abroad.

Travel Warnings and Alerts 
(http://global.unc.edu/travel-info/state-department-travel-warnings)

The University monitors travel warnings and alerts from the U.S. State Department and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and categorizes countries’ travel risk levels accordingly. Travel to countries with elevated risk levels caries certain implications for university-related travel. Click the link above for a list of countries with elevated travel risks as well as information on additional requirements for traveling to these nations.

 For additional travel information, resources, and tips visit: http://global.unc.edu/travel-info.

subject: Infant Feeding Study
author: scarla
content:
We are currently seeking parents and their infants to participate in the LiTTLe Me: Learning Together to Love Mealtime Study, a research study on infant feeding and growth.
The purpose of this research study is to learn about how the interactions between parents and their infants during feeding affect infants’ growth. We also want to learn about the interest in and acceptability of educational training for parents related to feeding their infants. Finally, we want to make sure that the ways we collect data are acceptable for parents and infants.
You and your infant may be eligible if:
Your infant is between the age of 4-9 months old;
Your infant has no developmental delays or disabilities that make it difficult for them to eat, drink, or communicate;
You read, understand, and speak English or Spanish.
The study involves three data collection sessions that take place in your home. Each data collection will last approximately 2.5 hours. Participants will receive a total of $90 for completing the study.
Please call 919-843-8554 or email scarla@email.unc.edu to learn more about the study. All information provided is confidential.
This research study has been approved by the Non-Biomedical UNC-CH IRB on 4/25/2016. IRB #15-2437.

subject: Imaging Research Study for Families with Children Ages 0-60 months
author: jordannj
content:
Are you expecting or know someone who is?  Do you have a newborn, toddler, or preschooler?   

As part of the Baby Connectome Project at UNC-Chapel Hill's Biomedical Research Imaging Center, we are recruiting families with children (ages 0-60 months) to participate in our research study.

What is the purpose of this research study?

The Baby Connectome Project (BCP) will investigate the physical changes taking place in a baby or child’s brain. This research initiative of the Foundation for the National Institutes of Health is dedicated to learning more about early child brain development. The BCP will provide an unprecedented view of how a healthy human brain develops and works.

Inclusion Criteria

Birth at gestational age 37-42 weeks
Normal birth weight
Absence of any major pregnancy and delivery complications
What does this research study involve?

Your child will have a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of his/her brain completed at different times in his/her development. These scans will be completed at UNC’s Marsico Hall. During this visit, behavioral assessments will be completed and saliva samples will be obtained. You will also be asked to provide history about you and your child’s medical history, and you will complete questionnaires about your child’s behavior.

Scans will be performed while your child is asleep or awake.  No medication or sedation will be used.

Will I be paid for participating?

You will receive $90 for each visit, and parking will be provided at no cost.

Are there any risks?

MRI is a safe and non-invasive way of answering questions about the structural and functional organization of the brain as it develops. It has no known risks and does not use radiation or x-ray.

Why participate in this research study?

You and your child’s participation in this research study will help us learn more about children’s mental, emotional and behavioral development. It may also help us understand the possible causes of learning disabilities and neurodevelopmental disorders.

How can I learn more about joining this research study?

Please contact Jordan Jimenez at jordan_jimenez@med.unc.edu or call 919-843-4640 for more information.

 

This study titled "Baby Connectome Project" has been approved by the UNC Biomedical Institutional Review Board (IRB)- study #16-1943, approved 11/03/2017.

subject: What kinds of social relationships affect health?
author: sundeme
content:
Hello, 
 
We know that social relationships with family and friends affect health in interesting and complex ways. But what is it about relationships, and what kinds of relationships, that is so important to consider with regards to health?
 
My name is Megan Evans and I am a graduate research assistant working with Dr. Edwin Fisher at the UNC Gillings School of Public Health. We are conducting a research study about social relationships and health. We are looking for individuals over the age of 18 with one or more of a variety of common health conditions to complete a voluntary survey. I sent the survey out a few weeks ago and was encouraged by the number of responses. I would love to get some more responses to help us better understand these phenomena. If you have not already completed the survey, I am emailing to ask if you are willing to take 15-20 minutes to complete it. If you choose to participate, all of your answers will be held in confidence.
 
If you are interested, please click on the link for the survey: https://unc.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_6xHqpUncSzhVNqt
  
If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact me at sundeme@live.unc.edu.
 
Thanks so much!
 
Megan Evans
Graduate Research Assistant
University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill
 
Non-biomedical IRB #17-1712 approved on 8/14/17

This laugh-out-loud, heartfelt comedy tosses us into the midst of a holiday family reunion in the West Philly home of aging matriarch Dot Shealy. As her grown children come home for Christmas, soul food will fly and tempers will flare, but love will always win out in the end.

subject: 2018 Public Service Awards call for nominations
author: rbeatty
content:
The Carolina Center for Public Service oversees the annual selection of three campus-wide awards honoring individual students, faculty, staff and University units for exemplary public service and engaged scholarship. Nominations are being accepted, and award recipients will be honored at a spring celebration where they receive a monetary award and framed certificate.

The Robert E. Bryan and Office of the Provost Awards require a brief (two-paragraph) nomination submitted online by 11:59 p.m. Feb. 7, 2018. Selected nominees will be invited to complete a more detailed submission about their work by Feb. 28, 2018. Final selection will be based on both the initial nomination and the nominee application. Full nominations for the Ned Brooks Award are due by 11:59 p.m. Feb. 7, 2018. Apply online for all awards at Carolina Center for Public Service Application and Nomination Portal. For details, visit Awards and Fellowships.

Robert E. Bryan Public Service Award

Five Bryan Awards will be given for a specific effort (rather than an overall record) exemplifying outstanding engagement and service to North Carolina that is characterized by:

working in partnership with community members,
inspiring and involving others, and/or helping others to serve,
responding to a practical problem, issue or concern of the state, and
working to assure the impact in the community is lasting. 
Bryan awards will be given to recognize an outstanding:

undergraduate student,
graduate student,
faculty member,
staff member, and
officially recognized student organization.
For more information, visit Robert E. Bryan Awards. 

Office of the Provost Engaged Scholarship Award

The Office of the Provost Engaged Scholarship Award will be given to faculty members or university units for exemplary engaged scholarship in service to North Carolina. The service should be an example of excellence, including responsiveness to community concerns and strong community partnerships. 

Three Provost awards will be given, one each for:

engaged teaching,
engaged research, and
engaged partnership.
For more information, visit Office of the Provost Award. 

Ned Brooks Award for Public Service

The Ned Brooks Award recognizes a staff or faculty member who throughout his/her career has, in a collaborative and sustained manner, made a difference in the community. For more information, visit Ned Brooks Award. 

For questions, contact ccps@unc.edu or call 919-843-7568.

subject: News from The Graduate School
author: sthurman
content:
Dear Colleagues,

I write to inform you that Steve Matson has announced plans to step down as Dean of the Graduate School at UNC-Chapel Hill after a decade of distinguished service in this leadership role.  Steve will return to the faculty of the College of Arts and Sciences, Department of Biology, after his successor is in place. Steve joined the Carolina faculty in 1983 and became Dean of the Graduate School on July 1, 2008.  He is widely respected for his award-winning teaching, mentoring and research in the field of genetics and molecular biology. 

As Dean of the Graduate School, he has advanced the University’s commitment to diversity and inclusion, to access and affordability, to excellence in academics, and to student success across all dimensions of the student experience for UNC’s 11,000 graduate and professional students.

From the beginning of his tenure, he understood that graduate education was changing -- from primarily preparing the next generation of academics to preparing the next generation of academics and business, non-profit and civic leaders.  Under his leadership, the Graduate School developed a number of professional development programs to address this need in graduate education.  Based on the results of an extensive survey of our graduate students, the Graduate School developed the Graduate School Professional Development program, a collection of workshops and courses focused on developing competencies in communication, academic development, leadership, professionalism and career development.

Also during Steve’s tenure, UNC launched the Professional Science Master’s degrees, designed to meet the needs of today’s professionals who want to expand their technical and business knowledge and apply it to emerging professional fields within science and health.

In 2010, through a private gift, the Graduate School established a summer fellowship program for students in academic fields where summer support is limited.  The Summer Research Fellowship Program frees students from teaching and other work responsibilities so they can progress in their research and move more quickly toward degree completion.

And early this semester, the Graduate School launched a graduate certificate in business fundamentals – communications, project management, leadership and financial accounting, reflecting student interest and the needs of the workplace.

Steve also has been a leader in graduate education at the state and national levels.  He was elected to the Board of Directors of the Council of Graduate Schools in 2012 for a 4-year term.  He served as Chair of its Finance and Audit Committee in 2014-15.  He currently serves on the Board of Directors of the Graduate Records Exam (Chair, 2016-17) and on the Board of Directors for the TOEFL Exam.  He has been President-elect (2015-16) and President (2016-17) of the North Carolina Council of Graduate Schools.

We thank Steve for his leadership as the Graduate School has responded to the changes in graduate education and career prospects for master’s and doctoral students.  His vision and commitment have positioned the Graduate School well for years to come.  Please join me in thanking Steve for his service and extend best wishes as he returns to teaching and research.

Sincerely,

Bob Blouin

Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost

subject: Participate in a study on everyday life in the workplace, well-being, and sleep
author: tjolink
content:
Now enrolling participants in a research study on everyday life in the workplace. We will ask confidential questions about your everyday interactions with colleagues as well as your personal well-being. After completing this survey, you will receive $10 plus one entry into a chance drawing of $100.

Upon receipt of your completed survey, you will be scheduled to begin a 10-day sleep study, which will start within a few days. Taking 15-20 minutes each day, you will answer two short questionnaires online and use a sleep app on your smart phone from the convenience of your own home to track your sleep. Participating in both the initial survey and 10-day sleep study – about 4 to 4.5 hours total – would bring compensation to $80, plus earn you entry into 3 chance drawings for $100 each and 1 for $500.

You are eligible to enroll in this survey if you meet the following criteria:

You are at least 18 years old
You must be able to fluently read, write, and speak English
You work outside the home for at least 35 hours/week in one position
The organization you work for has at least four other employees with whom you interact on a fairly regular basis
You have been working at that organization for at least 3 months
You have a smartphone on which you could download a free sleep application
You have daily access to the Internet
You are willing to sleep with your smartphone next to your bed for 10 days – including weekends – for the 10 day sleep-tracking portion of the study
Click this link to find the consent form with more information, followed by the first survey. At the end of the survey, you will have an opportunity to sign up for the second part of the study.

Approved by the UNC Non-biomedical IRB on December 1, 2017; IRB # 15-2584

subject: UNC Aquatics Swim Lessons
author: crayers
content:
Spring 2018 Swim Lesson Registration is OPEN!




The UNC-CH Campus Recreation Aquatics Program offers swim lessons and courses for the entire family.  Registration for swim programs is open to UNC students, faculty, and staff, and to the surrounding communities.

 

A variety of swim lesson programs are being offered, including Parent/Child, Preschool (levels 1-3), Youth (levels 1-6), and Adult (basic to advanced). Private swim lessons, one-on-one with an instructor, and semi-private lessons, custom made for 2 or more individuals, and American Red Cross Lifeguarding classes are also available.

 

Group sessions run Mondays/Wednesdays, as well as lessons on Saturdays at Bowman Gray Memorial Pool. Registration, schedules, and information detailing each of the swim lesson programs is online at: http://www.campusrec.unc.edu/classes-and-programs.

 

Prices vary based on swim level and lesson duration, and Campus Recreation members receive a discount. Current recreation members and non-members can register online at the site above.

subject: Infant/Toddler Nap Study
author: pagejm
content:
Subject: Early Development and Sleep Research Study

Hello,

The Frohlich Lab, a leader in brain network dynamics at UNC, has an exciting research study that your infant/toddler between the ages of 12-30 months can participate in with just 2 short sessions.

 In this research study, we are examining sleep characteristics in infants/toddlers that may have:

-Language delays (i.e., no words at 18 months, limited vocalizations at 12 months)

-Delays in social communication or play                   

-Autism or who are at-risk for autism (have a sibling with autism). 

Children develop and change rapidly during infancy and toddlerhood. We know that sleep is a critical aspect of health and brain development. However, little has been done to document patterns of sleep in young children or examine how brain activity during sleep may differ in children with delays and children with autism.

~You may be eligible if:

Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months with language delays (i.e., no words at 18 months, limited vocalizations at 12 months)
. Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months with delays in social communication or play

.  Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months with an autism spectrum disorder.

Your family has an infant/toddler 12-30 months who has an older sibling with an autism spectrum disorder.
 

~We schedule the two visits at your convenience and you will be with your child at all times. Each visit will take about 2- 2 ½ hours. The types of activities involved:

. A visit to your home at your convenience: Infant developmental assessments

. A visit to the nap room: Non-invasive recording (brain rhythms) during a midday nap. Your child will be playing with a variety of toys and taking a nap. This location offers free parking. 

We will compensate you $75 for your time. For more information, or to see if your child is eligible, please call Jessica Page at 919-445-0227 or email jessica.page@unc.edu or EDS@med.unc.edu.  You can find out more on our website at http://www.frohlichlab.org/.

We look forward to your participation!


The Frohlich Lab
                        This study was approved by the UNC biomedical IRB on 1/29/17 (IRB # 15-1829)

subject: Carolina Cares, Carolina Shares Campaign Extended
author: kwbryant
content:
Dear Staff and Faculty:

The Carolina Cares, Carolina Shares (CCCS) campaign is UNC-Chapel Hill’s campaign in support of the State Employees Combined Campaign (SECC).  At UNC-Chapel Hill we have a tradition of caring and leading in pledge support for charities in the Triangle, across North Carolina and beyond.

Today, on #GivingTuesday2017, I ask you to join me and our colleagues across campus to show others how the Carolina community makes a difference – for children, the elderly, those in need, and all the beneficiaries of the more than 900 charities included in our campaign. We have already raised more than $500,000, and we still have the opportunity to do more of what Tar Heels do best – give!

We have extended this year’s campaign through Friday, Dec. 15, to ensure everyone has the opportunity to donate. Please give as generously as you can, but remember – any contribution, no matter how small, will change someone’s life. 

To make your pledge today follow the steps below for electronic pledges or paper pledge forms:

subject: News from The Graduate School
author: sthurman
content:
Dear Colleagues,

I write to inform you that Steve Matson has announced plans to step down as Dean of the Graduate School at UNC-Chapel Hill after a decade of distinguished service in this leadership role.  Steve will return to the faculty of the College of Arts and Sciences, Department of Biology, after his successor is in place. Steve joined the Carolina faculty in 1983 and became Dean of the Graduate School on July 1, 2008.  He is widely respected for his award-winning teaching, mentoring and research in the field of genetics and molecular biology. 

As Dean of the Graduate School, he has advanced the University’s commitment to diversity and inclusion, to access and affordability, to excellence in academics, and to student success across all dimensions of the student experience for UNC’s 11,000 graduate and professional students.

From the beginning of his tenure, he understood that graduate education was changing -- from primarily preparing the next generation of academics to preparing the next generation of academics and business, non-profit and civic leaders.  Under his leadership, the Graduate School developed a number of professional development programs to address this need in graduate education.  Based on the results of an extensive survey of our graduate students, the Graduate School developed the Graduate School Professional Development program, a collection of workshops and courses focused on developing competencies in communication, academic development, leadership, professionalism and career development.

Also during Steve’s tenure, UNC launched the Professional Science Master’s degrees, designed to meet the needs of today’s professionals who want to expand their technical and business knowledge and apply it to emerging professional fields within science and health.

In 2010, through a private gift, the Graduate School established a summer fellowship program for students in academic fields where summer support is limited.  The Summer Research Fellowship Program frees students from teaching and other work responsibilities so they can progress in their research and move more quickly toward degree completion.

And early this semester, the Graduate School launched a graduate certificate in business fundamentals – communications, project management, leadership and financial accounting, reflecting student interest and the needs of the workplace.

Steve also has been a leader in graduate education at the state and national levels.  He was elected to the Board of Directors of the Council of Graduate Schools in 2012 for a 4-year term.  He served as Chair of its Finance and Audit Committee in 2014-15.  He currently serves on the Board of Directors of the Graduate Records Exam (Chair, 2016-17) and on the Board of Directors for the TOEFL Exam.  He has been President-elect (2015-16) and President (2016-17) of the North Carolina Council of Graduate Schools.

We thank Steve for his leadership as the Graduate School has responded to the changes in graduate education and career prospects for master’s and doctoral students.  His vision and commitment have positioned the Graduate School well for years to come.  Please join me in thanking Steve for his service and extend best wishes as he returns to teaching and research.

Sincerely,

Bob Blouin

Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost

subject: Seeking Volunteers for a study of propranolol to treat TMD pain
author: skcapps
content:
The Center for Pain Research and Innovation at the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill (School of Dentistry) is conducting a clinical research study of treatment for temporomandibular disorder (TMD). The purpose of this study is to learn about a possible treatment for TMD pain. In this study, participants will be randomly assigned (like flipping a coin) to receive a drug for pain or a placebo. The drug being used for this study, propranolol, is approved by the Food and Drug Administration for other health conditions.

You may be eligible for this study if you:

between the ages 18 and 65 years of age
have a diagnosis of TMD, or
have experienced facial pain for at least3months

You should not participate in the study if you:

have uncontrolled high blood pressure, asthma, diabetes, hyperthyroidism, fibromyalgia, or uncontrolled seizures
are currently taking opioid medication
are currently being treated with chemotherapy or radiation therapy
are pregnant or nursing

Other criteria will be determined at the first clinic visit.

The study participation will require you to attend our UNC clinic for 6 visits over a period of 12- 15 weeks. Each visit will last approximately 1-4 hours. Study participants will be paid $360 for completing all data collection activities. A parking voucher to cover the cost of parking a car will be provided at each study visit.

It is important to know that this letter is not telling you to join this study. Your participation is voluntary. If you would like to learn more about this study, please contact the study coordinator, Sonya K. Capps, at (919) 537-3617, visit the study website at https://studypages.com/s/temporomandibular-disorder-tmd-treatment-study-165977/ , or respond to this email.


This research study has been approved by the Biomedical UNC-CH IRB on 10/13/2015: Study # 14-2526

subject: Have a Healthy Holiday!
author: lmangili
content:
Have a Healthy Holiday!

The holidays are a wonderful time of year but they can be stressful.  Did you know that exercise is a great way to reduce stress?  Physical activity is important for your health and well-being, but finding time to exercise can be difficult especially during the holiday season.  The key is to be flexible and make fitness a way of life.  Remember all physical activity, not just formal exercise programs, can add up to a healthier you!  If you are looking for ways to be healthy and active, UNC Campus Recreation offers a variety of opportunities including wellness workshops, fitness classes and fun runs.

 

To find out more visit http://campusrec.unc.edu/special-event/jbj/ for more information.

subject: Caregivers at Carolina: Support for Physician Scientists Program accepting applications for research funding
author: eblloyd
content:
The UNC School of Medicine is one of only 10 U.S. medical schools to receive a 5- year grant from the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation (“DDCF”) that is specifically designed to help retain physician scientists who are facing significant extraprofessional caregiving responsibilities. With the DDCF award, the Dean’s Office has created a “Caregivers at Carolina” Program.  Funding is available for up to $40,000 per year for one to two years to provide direct research support or buy out of clinical time so that the scientist may maintain research productivity during a transient period when caregiving demands are high.  Funds may not be used directly for family care or as bridge funding.  The program will also provide access to mentoring and career development resources.

An Email of Intent is required.

Email a letter of intent directly to Erica_Nouri@med.unc.edu by Thursday, Dec. 7, 2017 before 5p.m. EST.
Applications are now being accepted and are due on Thursday, Dec. 14, 2017 before 5 p.m. EST.

Eligibility Criteria:

Physician Scientist (M.D. or D.O.) at the Assistant Professor or Instructor rank with full time appointment
Full time appointment with UNC SOM
Active U.S. Medical License
Active research funding as PI for clinical research including some salary support.  Experiments that utilize animals or primary tissues derived from animals will not be supported by this program.  Clinical research is defined as the scientific investigation of the etiology, prevention, diagnosis, or treatment of human disease using human subjects, human populations, or materials of human origin if they can be linked to a patient.
PI on extramurally funded research or career development award (not including site PI roles for clinical trials)
Funding may not be used for bridge funding
Sources of salary support must be clearly stated in either the applicant’s CV or in the application
Current, substantial caregiving demands which would typically include, but are not limited to, caring for young children, a sick family member, or eldercare
If requested, IRB approval notification for project(s) mentioned in submitted application
Willingness to complete two required questionnaires on demographics, job characteristics and perceptions of your work environment and well-being.  These de-identified data as well as information on promotion and retention will be shared with the DDCF.  Additional questionnaires may be completed on a voluntary basis over the course of the funding period for this program.
Willingness and ability to participate in program meetings and events.
Applicants must be available to participate in program activities held at the UNC SOM
 Application Materials to be compiled into one pdf file:

[** All documents must be typed in Arial at a font size of 11. Margins, in all directions, must be one inch.]

Two- page (maximum) description of the candidate’s background, research training, current research and funding, planned research, and career goals
Curriculum vitae
One page (maximum) statement of need with specific detail on the nature and extent of caregiving (e.g., type of care, how much) and examples of the impact the caregiving has on the candidate’s research productivity
One page proposal on how the funds would be used, with a budget, and career development milestone that would be achieved with the funds (e.g., grant submitted, research results published).  A second year of funding may be requested but will be contingent on meeting the milestones outlined for the first year.
In addition, in a separate document sent directly from the candidate’s chair or division chief, the application must include:

Letter of support from department chair defining the institutional commitment to the applicant, guarantee of protected research time (current and proposed); specific details regarding hours/week for non-research activities; and significance of candidate’s research and future research potential.
Finally, completion of the Uniform Survey is required to be considered for the award (sent to you upon program receiving Email of Intent). 

Review Process and Criteria:

Applications will be reviewed by an independent committee and evaluated for:

Need/justification related to caregiving
Research training, productivity and evidence that the candidate is on a clear trajectory to an independent research career
Public health significance of the candidate’s clinical research project
Support of the department chair/division chief, including statement of protected research time
Detailed plan for the funds, including budget.
Please submit application materials to Erica_Nouri@med.unc.edu

Following Submission:

Please direct any questions to the Program Directors:Amelia_Drake@med.unc.edu or Susan_Girdler@med.unc.edu

subject: NOMINATIONS FOR UNIVERSITY AWARDS FOR THE ADVANCEMENT OF WOMEN
author: clarec
content:
Call for Nominations: 2018 University Awards for the Advancement of Women

Deadline: Friday, January 26th, at 5pm. See http://womenscenter.unc.edu/about-us/awards/ for more details.
 
On behalf of the Offices of the Chancellor and the Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost, the Carolina Women's Center is pleased to call for nominations for the 2018 University Awards for the Advancement of Women.  These awards recognize contributions by people of all genders to the advancement of women at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
 
Each year, the award recognizes a faculty member, a staff member, a graduate or professional student or postdoctoral fellow, and an undergraduate. The faculty and staff recipients each receive $5000. Each student recipient receives $2500. Awardees are honored in a ceremony during the Carolina Women’s Center’s annual Gender Week Celebration in the spring. Please see the website for requirements and to submit a nomination.
 
Contact clarecounihan@unc.edu with questions.

content:
Do you like comics? Are you a gay or bisexual man? Tough Talks wants to hear from you!

The Tough Talks Comic Book Contest is looking for 16-29 year old gay or bi men to create and submit stories about HIV disclosure in the form of comics. It can be about your own experience or someone else’s. We’re looking for both HIV+ and HIV- guys to participate. Participation is entirely online.

Check out our website at http://www.toughtalkscontest.com/ for more information and to sign up!

Individuals who submit comics have a chance to win a daily ($10), weekly ($50) and grand prize ($100). All entries are confidential. The comics go towards building the Tough Talks virtual reality program.
 
No art skills are necessary to participate!

subject: Keep Holiday Stresses at bay with Morning of Mindfulness
author: kmeason
content:
Keep Holiday Stresses at bay with

Morning of Mindfulness

At a time for spreading peace and love, stress is the last thing you want, take a moment to ease your stress by taking time for yourself as you learn and practice Mindfulness Techniques that can bring benefits to your daily life! 

The Morning of Mindfulness will teach practices that are also great for anyone experiencing acute or chronic health issues such as insomnia, anxiety, pain, and more. 
 
Morning of Mindfulness is open to all levels.
We will include the following:

Identifying Stress Triggers, Manifestations and Coping Mechanisms
Using Mindful Breathing to Tame the Stress Response
Practice the Mind Body Connection through the Body Scan Practice

subject: 19th annual Holiday Carolina Blood Drive
author: rbeatty
content:
The Employee Forum and the American Red Cross will host the 19th annual Holiday Carolina Blood Drive, 7:30 a.m. - 1 p.m. Tuesday, Dec. 12, in Fetzer Hall.

Giving blood is easy - it only takes about an hour and saving a life is a great way to get into the holiday spirit. The Red Cross is making the donation process even smoother this year; walk-ups will have a designated blood donation pod, and donors can use Rapid Pass to save time giving blood. Blood and platelet donors can save time at their next donation by using RapidPass to complete their pre-donation reading and health history questionnaire online, on the day of their donation, from a computer or mobile device. Try RapidPass to save up to 15 minutes off donation time. Learn more or complete a RapidPass at redcrossblood.org/RapidPass.

Schedule an appointment

Speak with a Red Cross representative to schedule an appointment by calling 1-800-RED CROSS. Sign up online at redcrossblood.org with the sponsor code UNC or use the Red Cross Blood Donor App. For eligibility requirements, details or to volunteer, visit Carolina Blood Drive.

Free parking is available in Cobb Deck off Country Club Road, and all presenting donors will receive a free, customized Holiday Carolina Blood Drive Red Cross T-shirt.

Students, consider taking a study break to donate blood - snacks will be provided. For UNC-Chapel Hill employees, time spent donating and volunteering is considered work time with permission from a supervisor.

Just one donation can help save three lives. Please join us and give blood at the Holiday Carolina Blood Drive!

subject: LGBQ Couples Counseling
author: pentel
content:
Do you and your romantic partner both identify as women? 
Are you experiencing challenges in your relationship, in part due to facing LGBQ related stressors? 
Are you interested in LGBQ affirming couples counseling? 

If you answered "yes", you are both age 21+, and you have lived together for 6+ months, you may be eligible to receive affirming couple therapy specifically tailored for LGBQ women. The ACCESS Program (Affirming Couples Counseling to Engage Same Sex partners) is a treatment being delivered at the University of North Carolina. Therapy is provided at no cost.

For more information, contact Kim Pentel, M.A., an LGBTQ researcher, at ACCESSprogram@unc.edu. All inquires are confidential.

 

This is a therapy research study. Study Title: ACCESS: Affirming Couples Counseling to Engage Same-Sex partners. UNC-CH IRB #: 17-2482, Non-biomedical. Date Approved: October 17, 2017.

subject: Comic Book Research Study looking for participants. Win prizes!
author: ksoni
content:
Do you like comics? Are you a gay or bisexual man? Tough Talks wants to hear from you!

The Tough Talks Comic Book Contest is looking for 16-29 year old gay or bi men to create and submit stories about HIV disclosure in the form of comics. It can be about your own experience or someone else’s. We’re looking for both HIV+ and HIV- guys to participate. Participation is entirely online.

Check out our website at http://www.toughtalkscontest.com/ for more information and to sign up!

Individuals who submit comics have a chance to win a daily ($10), weekly ($50) and grand prize ($100). All entries are confidential. The comics go towards building the Tough Talks virtual reality program.
 
No art skills are necessary to participate!

Non-Medical IRB study # 14-0345, Approved 9/18/2017

subject: Stress Management and Resilience Training for Teens (SMART)
author: lynchce
content:
Does your teen have stress? Having any struggles with school, family, or friends? We are recruiting teens age 14-17 to participate in a research study to test two different courses for lowering stress and improving health and wellbeing in teens. Courses meet once a week for 8 weeks, and then once a month for 6 months after that. Refreshments will be served at classes and teens will receive up to $175 in Amazon gift cards for participating in this study.

 

Please contact S.M.A.R.T. Project, UNC Program on Integrative Medicine, smartstudy@med.unc.edu, 919-966-8586, to see if your teen eligible!

This study was approved by the UNC Biomedical Institutional Review Board (Approval Date, 7/13/16). IRB#: 16-1864, Study Title: The S.M.A.R.T. Project: Stress Management and Resilience Training for Teens. This study is funded by the National Institutes of Health, National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health.

subject: Mental Health First Aid training available to UNC employees
author: vglinebe
content:
Mental Health First Aid
for UNC Chapel Hill Faculty and Staff

Mental Health First Aid is now being offered at no cost to UNC Chapel Hill faculty and staff. 

Mental Health First Aid teaches participants the common warning signs of anxiety, depression, substance use, bipolar disorder, and schizophrenia.   This 8-hour course uses skills practice and simulations to demonstrate how to offer help in a mental health or substance use crisis through a 5-step action plan, with the ultimate goal to connect persons to appropriate professional care, social support and self-help.  

New sessions are now available for December and January. Sessions are scheduled at varying times and locations throughout campus. Training options include full day, two half-days, or Saturdays. To find a convenient date and time, and to register, visit: http://ssw.unc.edu/sswevents/mhfa-training  

 To request training for your specific group, contact the Behavioral Health Springboard of the School of Social Work at joflick@email.unc.edu

subject: Voluntary Self-Identification Opportunities
author: kwbryant
content:
Dear Faculty and Staff:

This communication is to alert you that you now have the ability through ConnectCarolina to self-identify your race/ethnicity, as well as your status as a veteran and/or an individual with a disability. As a federal contractor, the University is required to annually report aggregate information to the federal government. Having this information also helps the University better serve all the members of our community, as we strive to provide a working, learning and living environment that is welcoming and inclusive.

Accordingly, the Equal Opportunity and Compliance Office is asking that you voluntarily self-identify in these three areas. The reporting processes are quick and easy, and all information you provide will be kept confidential and will be used only by the Equal Opportunity and Compliance Office for reporting purposes, consistent with federal regulations. Updates should be made by December 11 so we can gather the data before the end of the calendar year.

Sign into ConnectCarolina (http://connectcarolina.unc.edu) with your UNC Onyen and password. Under the Self Service heading, you will see options to self-identify race/ethnicity, veteran status and disability status.

If you have questions or feedback, or need assistance, contact the Equal Opportunity and Compliance Office at eoc@unc.edu or 919-966-3576. Further, if you believe that you require an accommodation based on your status as an individual with a disability or a disabled veteran, you may also contact EOC for assistance. 

Thank you in advance for your participation.

Sincerely,

Brandon Washington
Director of Equal Opportunity and Compliance

subject: Something not quite right? You may be eligible to participate in a study in the Prime Research Program.
author: grewen
content:
The UNC Department of Psychiatry is conducting a research study to find out more about mental illness.  If you have had any of the following symptoms in the past few months, are between 12-30 years old, and have not been diagnosed with psychosis, you may be eligible to participate in a study in the Prime Research Program.

 

Do you sometimes feel confused about what is real or imaginary?
Have you felt that things happening around you have a special meaning just for you?
Are you feeling confused by things you hear or see?
Have you noticed unusual coincidences or connections that others do not seem to notice?
Do you ever feel like you just know what others are thinking or that others somehow know what you are thinking?
Are you worried that others are talking about you or laughing about you?
Do you think that others are trying to hurt you?
Do you have a close relative with a psychotic disorder and you’ve had a drop in function over the past year?

 

You may be eligible to receive free study related medical evaluations and monetary compensation.  Study participation includes multiple visits lasting 2-8 hours over 2 years.  These visits will take place at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

 

Visit us at our www.PRIME.unc.edu and click on 'Simple Survey' or call (877) PRIME19 or (877) 774-6319.

 

The Project is funded by the National Institute of Mental Health

 

14-2055 Approved 6-11-2015

Committee on the Protection of the Rights of Human Subjects

The BioMedical IRB

University of North Carolina

subject: Facilities Services Coverage for Winter Break
author: sboyle
content:
TO:                 University Faculty and Staff
FROM:            Anna Wu, Associate Vice Chancellor for Facilities Services
SUBJECT:       Facilities Services Coverage for Winter Break
DATE:             November 17, 2017

UNC-Chapel Hill will observe a ten-day closure of the University during Winter Break 2017. During this time, Facilities Services will have limited staff resources on call. The following areas may be of interest to your department regarding service coverage during the break:

Housekeeping and Building Services: Staff will be available on an on-call basis to handle emergencies that should arise. Response times may be lengthened due to this status. The on-call service period will begin Friday night, Dec. 22, at 10 p.m., and end Tuesday morning, Jan. 2.

Energy Management: The University will implement a Winter Holiday Energy Saving Initiative to reduce energy consumption and utility costs by lowering temperatures in unoccupied buildings. This cost-effective initiative resulted in savings of $123,000 during Winter Break 2016. It is asked that you turn off all lights and unnecessary equipment and close all windows and fume hood sashes before leaving campus. The Initiative will begin Friday night, Dec. 22, at 10 p.m., and end Monday night, Jan. 1, at 10 p.m.
           Exceptions to the Energy Saving Initiative: Research labs, animal facilities and designated health care facilities that are critical to the University’s mission are not included in this energy saving initiative. However, even in these facilities the Housekeeping and Building Services on-call service period will be in effect.

If you have a special need or event during the break that will require an exemption from the 2017 Winter Holiday Energy Saving Initiative or will require Housekeeping and/or Building Services staff, please submit an Exemption Request by 5 p.m. Nov. 28, 2017.

Please do not submit exemption requests via the Facilities Services Service Request portal or directly to Facilities Services personnel. Building occupants will be notified of approved exemptions by 5 p.m. Tuesday, Dec. 5, 2017.

For questions or concerns, contact Energy Management at save-energy@unc.edu.

Thank you for supporting this important initiative.

subject: Administrative Review of Frank Porter Graham Child Development Institute
author: briordan
content:
DATE: November 16, 2017

TO: UNC-Chapel Hill Faculty and Staff

FROM: Stephen Hooper, Chair, Frank Porter Graham Child Development Institute Review Committee

RE: Administrative Review of Frank Porter Graham Child Development Institute

On behalf of the committee appointed to review the performance of the FPG Child Development Institute, I am pleased to invite your participation in the review process.

The committee is being chaired by Dr. Stephen Hooper, Associate Dean of Allied Health Sciences, stephen_hooper@med.unc.edu

Other members are:

Anita Brown-Graham, Professor of Public Law and Government, brgraham@sog.unc.edu

Eric Houck, Associate Professor, Education Leadership and Policy Studies, eahouck@email.unc.edu

Andrea Hussong, Director, Center for Developmental Science, hussong@unc.edu

Meghan Shanahan, Assistant Professor, Maternal and Child Health, shanahan@unc.edu

Sam Meisels, Director, Buffett Early Childhood Institute, smeisels@nebraska.edu

As required by University regulations, the Vice Chancellor for Research has requested an administrative review of the FPG Child Development Institute. It is important for the committee to learn how the FPG Child Development Institute’s performance as a leading center is viewed by staff and faculty at UNC-Chapel Hill. Areas for review include vision, long-range planning, management, and leadership with respect to advancing the mission of FPG. The committee invites your comments on these and related issues.

We encourage you to contribute to this review in any of the following ways:

You may provide written comments to the chair or other committee members. The review committee will treat your comments as strictly confidential. By law, all written communication - whether on paper or by email - becomes a confidential part of file of the FPG review. As such, comments become part of the permanent record, and can be accessed by a public records request. University regulations prohibit considerations of anonymous letters in the review process.
You may telephone or meet privately in person with committee members. Oral communications (by telephone or in person) and the committee's notes generated from these conversations do not become part of the permanent record, but may be reflected in the committee's report. The committee will include a list of individuals with whom we spoke for the official record, but we will not make specific attributions of input received. If you wish to have your comments attributed to you, please send an email to the Committee Chair, Stephen Hooper.
You may meet with the committee during one of the two open public hearing sessions to receive comments. These times are:
 November 29th, 2017 from 9-11am in 307D Bynum Hall
December 4th, 2017 from 11-1pm at Frank Porter Graham, Sheryl Mar North 140
 If you wish to meet with the Committee on one of these dates, please contact the Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research, (FPGReview@unc.edu) to schedule a specific time (approximately 10-15 minutes time slots). Please note that persons may declare at the beginning of their appearance their wish to remain anonymous, insofar as attribution in the committee minutes of specific comments; however, a master list of attendees appearing before the Committee will become part of the official records. Request for a meeting time must be made no later than COB November 22, 2017.

 

The deadline for submitting comments regarding the performance of the FPG Child Development Institute to the Committee is Dec. 15th, by 5:00pm. We appreciate everyone’s assistance with this very important process.

Andrea Hussong, Director, Center for Developmental Science, hussong@unc.edu

Meghan Shanahan, Assistant Professor, Maternal and Child Health, shanahan@unc.edu

Sam Meisels, Director, Buffett Early Childhood Institute, smeisels@nebraska.edu

As required by University regulations, the Vice Chancellor for Research has requested an administrative review of the FPG Child Development Institute. It is important for the committee to learn how the FPG Child Development Institute’s performance as a leading center is viewed by staff and faculty at UNC-Chapel Hill. Areas for review include vision, long-range planning, management, and leadership with respect to advancing the mission of FPG. The committee invites your comments on these and related issues.

We encourage you to contribute to this review in any of the following ways:

You may provide written comments to the chair or other committee members. The review committee will treat your comments as strictly confidential. By law, all written communication - whether on paper or by email - becomes a confidential part of file of the FPG review. As such, comments become part of the permanent record, and can be accessed by a public records request. University regulations prohibit considerations of anonymous letters in the review process.
You may telephone or meet privately in person with committee members. Oral communications (by telephone or in person) and the committee's notes generated from these conversations do not become part of the permanent record, but may be reflected in the committee's report. The committee will include a list of individuals with whom we spoke for the official record, but we will not make specific attributions of input received. If you wish to have your comments attributed to you, please send an email to the Committee Chair, Stephen Hooper.
You may meet with the committee during one of the two open public hearing sessions to receive comments. These times are:
November 29th, 2017 from 9-11am in 307D Bynum Hall
December 4th, 2017 from 11-1pm at Frank Porter Graham, Sheryl Mar North 140
 If you wish to meet with the Committee on one of these dates, please contact the Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research, (FPGReview@unc.edu) to schedule a specific time (approximately 10-15 minutes time slots). Please note that persons may declare at the beginning of their appearance their wish to remain anonymous, insofar as attribution in the committee minutes of specific comments; however, a master list of attendees appearing before the Committee will become part of the official records. Request for a meeting time must be made no later than COB November 22, 2017.

 

The deadline for submitting comments regarding the performance of the FPG Child Development Institute to the Committee is Dec. 15th, by 5:00pm. We appreciate everyone’s assistance with this very important process.

subject: Paid research opportunity for individuals with ACL injury
author: troyb
content:
The UNC Neuromuscular Research Lab is seeking paid volunteers for a research study on anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury and reconstruction surgery. Individuals who have injured their ACLs are at a heightened risk of developing knee osteoarthritis, partly because of weakness and dysfunction in the quadriceps muscle. Current rehabilitation approaches are often not effective for restoring quadriceps function due to a neuromuscular factor called arthrogenic muscle inhibition and the fact that the best ways to treat it are unclear.

 Applying vibration to a muscle improves its function and may be an effective way to treat quadriceps dysfunction following ACL injury and reconstruction. The purposes of this research study are to determine if two types of vibration (whole body vibration and local muscle vibration) improve quadriceps muscle function, proprioception (sensation of how your joints are positioned), and walking gait biomechanics in individuals with ACL injuries.

 If you decide to participate, you will be asked to report to the Neuromuscular Research Laboratory on the UNC-Chapel Hill campus for 3 testing sessions. One session will last approximately 45 minutes while the other two will last about an hour and a half. During these testing sessions you will be asked to complete 3 separate tests: 1) quadriceps muscle function, 2) walking gait biomechanics, and 3) sensory function/proprioception. You will then receive an intervention (whole body vibration, local muscle vibration, or control/no vibration) designed to improve these characteristics, and these tests will be repeated. You will also be asked to complete 3 online surveys regarding the details of your initial injury and surgery, your level of physical activity, and any symptoms you currently experience.

 There are some risks associated with participating in this research study, but they are not greater than the risks associated with normal physical activity/exercise.

 To be eligible to participate, you must meet the following inclusion criteria:

Age 18 – 35 years
History of ACL injury and reconstruction in only 1 of your legs within the last 6 months to 5 years
No history of ACL graft rupture or revision surgery
No history of injury to either leg within the last 6 months other than ACL injury and reconstruction surgery
No history of neurological disorder such as stroke, multiple sclerosis, or cerebral palsy
Cleared by a physician for return to physical activity, and currently physically active, participating in at least 20 minutes of physical activity 3x per week
Not currently pregnant
 Your total participation in the study will last approximately 3 hours and 45 minutes, and you will receive $125 for participating.

 If you meet these inclusion criteria and are interested in participating, please contact Chris Johnston at cdjohnst@email.unc.edu.

 This study was approved by the UNC-CH Biomedical Institutional Review Board on 5/18/2015 (IRB# 15-0838).

subject: Vision Core Research Study
author: cbv33
content:
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill’s Department of Exercise and Sport Science is seeking volunteers for a research study examining relationships among various assessments of visual system function and performance. We are looking for volunteers who meet the following criteria

Must be at least 18 years of age
Must participate in 30 minutes of moderate to vigorous physical activity at least 3 days per week.
The study will consist of:

One in-person session lasting approximately two hours where you will be asked to complete the following:
One questionnaire
7 non-invasive visual function and performance assessments
Brief balance test
Brief electroencephalography assessment (consists of wearing a special cap while standing)
You will receive $20 as compensation for your time.
At your earliest convenience, please reply to this email to let me know if you wish to participate. 

If you have any questions about this study before you make a decision to participate, please do not hesitate to ask by replying to this email, or by calling 919-962-0409 and asking to speak with someone from the Gfeller Center Vision Core. We hope you will consider participating in this study and we look forward to hearing from you!

Thank you, 

Christina B. Vander Vegt, MS, ATC
Research Assistant and Doctoral Student
Mathew Gfeller Sport-Related Traumatic Brain Injury Research Center 

This study was approved by the Biomedical IRB on 11/10/2017 (IRB# 17-1471)
This message is sponsored by the Department of Exercise and Sport Science

subject: Travel Tips for Thanksgiving
author: ahsimmon
content:
Getting home for Thanksgiving:  It's as easy as pie!

Charlotte bound? 
Ride with other UNC students on BreakShuttle. Buy your ticket online.

Need to get to the airport? 
Free shuttle from UNC to RDU Airport. Reserve your seat for P2P!

Staying in the region?
Ride the bus across the Triangle, to the Piedmont Triad, or to Chatham County.

Going across NC or out of state? 
Take GoTriangle Route 400 or 405 to Durham to catch Amtrak, Greyhound, or Megabus.

Looking for a carpool? 
Use your Onyen login to find ride matches at unc.sharetheridenc.org.

Happy Thanksgiving!

subject: Comic Book Research Study looking for participants. Win prizes!
author: ksoni
content:
Do you like comics? Are you a gay or bisexual man? Tough Talks wants to hear from you!

The Tough Talks Comic Book Contest is looking for 16-29 year old gay or bi men to create and submit stories about HIV disclosure in the form of comics. It can be about your own experience or someone else’s. We’re looking for both HIV+ and HIV- guys to participate. Participation is entirely online.

Check out our website at http://www.toughtalkscontest.com/ for more information and to sign up!

Individuals who submit comics have a chance to win a daily ($10), weekly ($50) and grand prize ($100). All entries are confidential. The comics go towards building the Tough Talks virtual reality program.
 
No art skills are necessary to participate!

IRB study # 14-0345, Approved 9/18/2017

subject: 2018-2020 Nannerl Keohane Distinguished Visiting Professorship - Request for Nominations
author: hunan
content:
Faculty and administrators at The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and Duke University are invited to nominate outstanding scholars, artists, or practitioners for the Nannerl Keohane Distinguished Visiting Professorship. Nominations are welcome for academic years 2018-19 and 2019-20.  Nominations are due by January 31, 2018. 

The Keohane Professorship recognizes the remarkable contributions of Dr. Nannerl Keohane during her term as President of Duke University, and the unprecedented level of collaboration she and UNC Chancellor James Moeser created between these two great institutions.  The award was created in 2004 by Chancellor Moeser and was funded by Carolina graduate Julian Robertson and his late wife, Josie, of New York (parents of Spencer Robertson, Duke ’98, and Alex Robertson, UNC ’01) and the William R. Kenan, Jr. Charitable Trust.  

Initially, proposals were accepted on any topic; however, in 2016, the professorship directed its focus on proposals that allow the two universities to work together to extend their capacity in specific areas.  In 2016-17 and 2017-18, areas of focus were data science; entrepreneurship and innovation; and the arts.  For 2018-19 and 2019-20, the focus areas will be as follows:

The Environment: Energy, Water, and Land Resources
Citizenship and Opportunity in the Context of Race, Religion, and Culture
Optimizing Well-being through Precision and Population Health Care
Using Data Science to Solve Complex Problems
These focus areas correspond with the strategic priorities as expressed in Duke’s Collaboratories initiative and with UNC’s Creativity Hubs.  Nominations that magnify the work of the Collaboratories and Creativity Hubs will be given preference.

  

Goals of the Professorship 

Promote inter-institutional collaboration and the enhancement of intellectual life at both universities by strengthening established collaborations or encouraging new ones;
Contribute to the teaching missions of both UNC and Duke—in particular to the undergraduate curriculum—through a self-standing course or the co-teaching of one or more courses, or through a carefully planned series of guest appearances in a number of courses;
Share the work of the Visiting Professor widely through public lectures or performances.
 

Structure, Activities, and Funding

Recipients typically spend a semester or the equivalent of a semester in the program; however, proposals will be accepted for residencies of varying lengths based upon the schedule of the nominee and the collaborations proposed.  Past recipients have catalyzed cross-campus undergraduate and graduate programs, conducted joint projects with Carolina and Duke research centers, taught joint Carolina and Duke courses, and delivered major public addresses.

The recipient is entitled to a payment of $60,000 US dollars (before taxes) for a full semester residency or $30,000 for a half semester residency (or its equivalent). Fringe benefits are also provided at a rate of 10% of the stipend payment. The recipient may request reimbursement for a maximum amount of $20,000 US dollars ($10,000 for a half semester residency) for costs associated with the Professorship, which could include housing, travel (including dependents), research, and other related expenses. Stipend and expense levels for recipients visiting for other periods of time may be negotiated; however, each professorship must involve a period of time sufficient to allow the goals of the professorship to be met.  For reimbursement, the award recipient must provide the necessary documentation and receipts of the expenses within 30 days of the conclusion of the Professorship. The award is contingent on the ability of the recipient to receive the funds.  International recipients are responsible for obtaining the necessary visa in order to receive payment.  Sponsoring departments also will receive $5,000 per visitor for expenses associated with public lectures or performances.

 

Responsibilities of the nominating units

The Department(s) hosting the recipient is responsible for all other costs related to instruction, office, and clerical support (copying, space, office phone, etc.). All arrangements should be handled by the host Department(s). Such arrangements could include (though are not limited to) helping the recipient access resources such as IT support, University libraries, equipment, campus parking, as well as providing any appropriate advice on housing and living in the local community.  For international recipients, the Department(s) hosting the recipient must assure that the visa process is appropriately handled by the recipient.  The nominating Department at UNC-CH will be responsible for making all expense reimbursements and payroll arrangements for the recipient during the term of the professorship.

 

Nomination Process

Each nomination must describe how the professorship will achieve the three main goals of the professorship as listed above and must state its relationship to one of the four focus areas specified for 2018-2020.  Each nomination must be made jointly by faculty members and/or administrators from both institutions, and must be accompanied by the signatures of the relevant Department Chairs or other administrators at both institutions.

Nomination letters should be as specific as possible and include descriptions of the following: 

how the nominee will advance inter-institutional collaboration and intellectual life at Duke and UNC-Chapel Hill in the specified area of focus;
the nominee’s qualifications, including how s/he has demonstrated the ability to work across departmental or institutional boundaries;
programmatic benefits that would arise from the professorship and a plan for assessment of impact;
new initiatives that will arise from the professorship and serve both UNC and Duke.
Please also include the nominee’s CV.

Nominations must be received no later than Friday, January 31, 2018 and should be sent electronically to susan.booth@duke.edu.   Questions about the Professorship may be addressed to Carol Tresolini (carol_tresolini@unc.edu) or Noah Pickus (noah.pickus@duke.edu), Co-Chairs of the Nannerl Keohane Distinguished Visiting Professorship Joint Advisory Committee.

The joint advisory committee shall make its recommendations to the Provosts of each institution in February 2018, and the two Provosts shall make the final selection.  We anticipate awarding a total of six professorships during the two-year period spanning academic years 2018-19 and 2019-20.
