subject: Updates to SHRA Disciplinary Action Policy
author: kirkkm
content:
On Sept. 7, 2017, the State Human Resources Commission approved revisions to the SHRA “Disciplinary Action Policy” (formerly, “Disciplinary Action, Suspension and Dismissal Policy”).

Reason for Policy Change

Although these revisions do not significantly change current policy and practice, there is a significant restructuring of the policy. Some aspects of the disciplinary process that were undefined in the former policy have been articulated in the new policy to foster greater consistency of practice. Because practices at individual institutions may have evolved independently over time within the parameters of the former policy, this policy revision may require some modifications to current institutional procedures. 

To ensure consistency with the Disciplinary Action Policy, revision details from the Office of State Human Resources are outlined below:

1. Policy Name Change

Disciplinary Action Policy (formerly, “Disciplinary Action, Suspension and Dismissal Policy”).

2. Documented Counseling Session

The revised policy expects a documented counseling session to occur prior to issuing a written warning for unsatisfactory job performance, unless Human Resources allows for an exception due to the nature of the incident(s).

3. Advance Notice to Attend a Pre-Disciplinary Conference

The revised policy sets a minimum 24 hours advance written notice to an employee prior to holding the pre-disciplinary conference. This was undefined in the former policy.

4. Lifespan of a Disciplinary Action

Written warnings, suspensions, and demotions remain active for 18 months, and this active period extends if another disciplinary action is issued in that timeframe. The revised policy also sets the maximum extended period up to an additional 18 months. This means that no individual action will be active longer than a total of 36 months.

The lifespan of active actions issued prior to Nov. 1, 2017, remain active as provided by the policy in place prior to Nov. 1, 2017.

5. Allowed Participants in the Pre-Disciplinary Conference

The supervisor or other person chosen by agency management to conduct the conference; that person will be a representative from Employee & Management Relations, Office of Human Resources.  
A management representative must be present at management’s discretion; that person may be the supervisor or an alternate management representative.  
The employee;
University procedures may provide for one additional neutral party, if agreed upon by the employee and management.
If the person conducting the conference chooses, security may be present.
No other parties may be present at the PDC.
6. Employee Assistance Program (EAP)

Please note that references to the Employee Assistance Program and related fitness for duty procedures apply to the agency’s separate EAP program and not to the University’s EAP programs.

subject: Participants for Music Therapy Study
author: tresupan
content:
Hello,

We are contacting you because the Frohlich Lab is starting a new study that examines the physiological impact of Music Therapy interventions on heart-rate variability and stress hormone levels.

We are looking for healthy, reliable, males and females, age 18-34, with no history of neurological or cardiovascular illness, to participate in a UNC research study.

In this study, participants will undergo two music therapy interventions: one involving active music-making, the other involving passive listening.  The study involves two 1 hour experimental sessions, spaced a week apart.  The study compensates $10 per experimental session and will take place in the UNC Medical School Wings.  For more information, or to see if you’re eligible, please email your name, phone number, and best time to call to tresupan@live.unc.edu.

This biomedical study was approved by the UNC IRB on 11/07/2017 (IRB # 17-2508).

Thanks,

The Frohlich Lab

subject: Is “The Change” making you lose interest in things you used to enjoy?
author: anitaa
content:
Help us learn about how hormones improve mood by joining our research study.

You may be eligible if:

You are a woman age 44-55;
Your periods are irregular;
You’ve had a period in the last year.
If you’re feeling down, sad, or annoyed, you may qualify for our study. Women in this study take either estrogen or Duavee, a medicine for hot flashes. Duavee is made of estrogen and another medication that blocks estrogen’s effects on the breast and uterus, which makes it an ideal option for women seeking relief from hot flashes and mood changes. 

Our study involves taking medication for 3 weeks, having 2 brain scans at UNC, and doing 6 study visits.  Payment for completing this study is $500.  To see if you would be a good fit, please visit www.PEERSstudy.org or call 919-966-5243.

This study was approved on 10/17/2017 by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Biomedical IRB, Study# 13-3572.

subject: Pediatric Psoriasis Research Study
author: lmcleod
content:
Pediatric Psoriasis Research Study

 

Is your child suffering from moderate to severe plaque psoriasis? If so, your child may be eligible to try an investigational injectable medication!

 

Subject must:

Be 6-17 years of age
Be diagnosed with plaque psoriasis for at least 6 months
Be in general good health
Have had no previous treatment with etanercept
Be willing to have an injection of investigational medicine every four weeks during the study
Be able to attend one screening visit, one baseline visit, then monthly clinic visits at UNC Dermatology Department over the course of 33 months
 

Subject will:

Receive study medication and skin assessments at no charge
Receive compensation for travel to and participation in clinic visits
 

For more information, please contact:

Taylor Zuber

UNC Dermatology and Skin Cancer Center

Study Coordinator

Phone: 984-974-3682

Email: taylor_zuber@med.unc.edu

This e-mail is sponsored by: UNC Department of Dermatology

Study Type: Biomedical

IRB#: 16-3321

Approval Date: 12/16/2016
